PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That there is a need for an Independent and Multi-cultural Broadcasting Corporation to give a firm legislative and financial basis for the SBS Network.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should pass Senator Vigor's Bill with all expediency.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Macklin (from 33 citizens), Mason (from seven citizens) and Vigor (from 146 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there is widespread community concern about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia.
Your petitioners, most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
(1) Block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia and
(2) Ban the import of cobalt-60 and caesium 137 and caesium 134 to be used to irradiate food products,
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Rifle Range, Malabar, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That over 67,000 men, women and students enjoy the pursuit of their sport and recreation every year at the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar and have done so since 1967.

2. The people of Sydney through their membership of 41 clubs headquartered at the Anzac Rifle Range together with a number of other community, school and commercial groups, the police and armed forces will lose this community facility if the Federal Government proceeds to sell the Range to private developers.
3. The Australian Bicentenary Fullbore Rifle Championships are to be conducted at the Anzac Rifle Range in April 1988 as part of the celebration of Australia's Bicentenary.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should ask the Federal Government to retain the Anzac Rifle Range for the continued use and enjoyment of the people of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Michael Baume (from 209 citizens) and Richardson (from 228 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Prohibition of the Exportation of Uranium to France Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the only activity now taking place in the South Pacific which the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty bans is the testing of nuclear weapons by France at Mururoa and that the export of uranium by Australia to France undermines the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to adhere to the Australian Labor Party's policy, as set out in the Customs Amendment (Prohibition of the Exportation of Uranium to France) Bill which prohibits the supply of uranium to France until France stops testing nuclear weapons in the South Pacific.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification (ID) cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the system:
(a) is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud and, to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud;
(b) will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private nature:
(c) will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the taxpayer; and
(d) cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended and in fact provide the opportunity for blackmail and other forms of misuse.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective and less obnoxious methods.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military and Intelligence Facilities in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens shows that the citizens of the Northern Territory recognise-
(i) that nuclear peace for the world will come through adequate, supervised disarmament of nuclear weapons;

(ii) that arms limitation arrangements between the United States and the Soviet Union specifically provide for verification, and the general purpose of the facilities at Pine Gap contribute to this objective;

(iii) among the functions performed are the provision of early warning by receiving from space satellites information about missile launches and the provision of information about the occurrences of nuclear explosions which assist in nuclear test ban monitoring, supports nuclear non-proliferation measures and contributes to global stability-

and urge the Australian Government to give an unequivocal commitment to renew the lease on the joint defence facility for a further term of ten years when the present lease expires on 19 October 1987.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft Operational Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the Superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions
equal employer and employee Trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Michael Baume (from 277 citizens) and Crichton-Browne (from 17 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Gold Mining Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the welfare of many employees and their families depends upon a healthy, expanding gold mining industry.
That the success of many small businesses in gold mining towns also depends upon the continued profitability of gold mining and prospecting operations.

That the Federal Government's proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining and prospecting represents a threat to the profitability of these industries and therefore will cause widespread unemployment and depression throughout the whole gold mining industry.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Federal Government to reject any proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining or prospecting thereby ensuring that the spectacular growth of the industry over recent years is continued.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Country Hour
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

that any decision by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to reduce the local content of the programme, the ``Country Hour'', would represent yet another severe blow to Western Australian rural people;
that even under current programming Western Australian country people receive little locally produced radio, and

in view of the inefficiencies in the operations of the ABC disclosed by the Auditor-General, your petitioners call upon the Government to improve the efficient operation of the ABC before it reduces the local content of important rural programmes such as the `Country Hour'.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Administration Charge
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the imposition of the $250.00 Administrative charge will:
(1) Prove a dis-incentive for all students-particularly part-time and mature age students-from continuing their tertiary studies.
(2) Lead to higher levels of youth unemployment as fewer students will now enrol in tertiary studies.
(3) Impose economic hardship upon the student population at large.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should vote to reject the imposition of the Administrative charge, or, at the very least, vote to impose a lower fee on students who are not full-time.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Khao-I-Dang Refugee Camp: Thailand
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

The Thai Government recently announced that Khao-I-Dang refugee camp will be closed on 31st December, 1986. More than 25,000 Cambodian refugees who survived the ``Killing Fields'' of the Khmer Rouge and entered Thailand after 1979 are still resident in Khao-I-Dang. We hold grave fears for the future and safety of these refugees who will be relocated to camps along the Thai-Cambodian border when Khao-I-Dang is closed.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should uphold its enviable humanitarian record and act with all haste to facilitate the acceptance and resettlement of as many of these refugees as possible, including a proportion of those who have no relatives to sponsor them.

PETITION.TITLE: Ethnic Schools Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Ethnic Schools Program which provides for a teaching of community languages is vital to the sense of identity of all ethnic groups in Australia.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to continue funding the Ethnic Schools Program at a level which will fulfil the needs of the ethnic communities in this important area.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully brings to your attention:
That in light of the importance of the Gimbat and Goodparla pastoral leases for biological, geographical, cultural and recreational purposes-

the Commonwealth adheres to its policy of extending Kakadu National Park as outlined in the Governor-General's opening speech to Parliament on February 25, 1985 and immediately acts to declare the entire areas as Stage III of Kakadu National Park;

the Government recognise the extreme importance of the Coronation Hill and Big Sunday sites complex and traditional affiliation of Aboriginal people to the area by ensuring that the area is made available for claim by traditional Aboriginal owners;
no mining is permitted in Stage III of Kakadu and that existing mining leases be disallowed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Merger of Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Special Broadcasting Service

SPEECH.SPEAKER: VIGOR

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the following petition, which is not in conformity with Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form and does not contain a prayer at the end thereof, from 2,981 citizens who oppose the amalgamation of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service:

SPEECH.PARA: We the undersigned strongly oppose the merger of SBS (radio and television) with the ABC. We believe the financial reasons for the decision to merge are ill conceived, as evidenced by the Report of the Government's own Connor Committee of Review.
The Ethnic Communities of Australia cannot understand why the Government proposes this merger without any consultation with the communities most severely affected.
The Government must be aware that Ethnic Communities and other Anglo-Celtic Australians will not stand by and watch multi-culturalism in this country being reduced to tokenism.
The amalgamation of SBS and the ABC constitutes the end of autonomous ethnic broadcasting in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) confirms its support for the Kangaroo Management Program conducted by the Australian Government in conjunction with all State Government management programs;

(b) recognises the program as the most humane method of containing kangaroo numbers to a level that will allow the pastoral and grazing industries to function and ensure the continuation, protection and survival of various species of kangaroos;

(c) calls on the manufacturers of Nike, Puma, Adidas and Mitre sports shoes, among others, to investigate the scientifically managed schemes controlled by the Australian and State Governments before ceasing the manufacture of running shoes from kangaroo leather;

(d) calls on world sporting champion runner, Sebastian Coe, and Arsenal striker Charlie Nicholas, and other sporting champions to reject untruthful claims by Greenpeace and Fund for Animals condemning the Kangaroo Management Programs;

(e) rejects the emotional and untrue allegations made by animal welfare groups who are using the Kangaroo Management Program to promote their organisations and their officials' life styles with disregard for facts and expert scientific evidence; and

(f) warns the international community that if the Government management programs are sabotaged by the actions of these irresponsible animal welfare groups, less humane methods of management will occur to contain the kangaroo population at a level that will allow graziers and farmers to exist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes that, following the October 1986 worst-ever deficit of $1.7 billion, the balance of payments current account deficit for the first four months of the 1986-87 financial year of $6 billion is mainly due to a huge rise in Australia's interest bill on overseas borrowings, which is now close to $1 billion a month;

(b) further notes that every monthly deficit increase (averaging $1.5 billion a month in 1986, or almost $40,000 a minute) also increases the debt on which interest must be paid, thereby worsening our deficit even further, particularly while the Federal Government maintains its policy of record high interest rates aimed at holding up the value of the Australian dollar;

(c) recognises that foreign investors have welcomed the last few disastrous monthly current account deficits because they ensure that the Government must maintain its high interest rate policy, which provides these investors with the highest and safest return in the world, for so long as the Reserve Bank provides a floor under the Australian dollar at US60 cents;

(d) warns the Government that the present strength of the Australian dollar is no indication of foreign confidence in our economic future and, on the contrary, is despite a general expectation that Australia is moving into a recession.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Quarantine (Animals) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1986 No. 283 and made under the Quarantine Act 1908, be disallowed.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notices of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall withdraw Business of the Senate Notices of Motion Nos 1, 2, 3 and 5, standing in my name for the next day of sitting, for the disallowance of the Futures Industry Regulations (Amendment) as contained in Statutory Rules 1986 No. 150, the Sex Discrimination (Operation of Legislation) (No. 1) Regulations as contained in Statutory Rules 1986 No. 191, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Regulations as contained in Statutory Rules 1986 No. 206 and the Apple and Pear (Conditions of Export) Regulations (Amendment) as contained in Statutory Rules 1986 No. 219. I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee has been considering delegated legislation relating to the use by officials of photographic identity cards; the need for a sunset clause to allow for the possible future application of the Sex Discrimination Act to certain decisions that would otherwise be permanently exempted from that Act; whether the use of the name and emblem `Worksafe Australia' affects the property rights of any other pre-existing user of that name; and questions concerning avenues of appeal against decisions of a statutory body. The Committee's concerns about all these matters have been met by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). The Committee thanks them for their willingness to explain matters to the Committee and for their undertakings to make important amendments to delegated legislation to protect the rights of individuals. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short summary of the Committee's scrutiny of these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Sex Discrimination (Operation of Legislation) (No. 1) Regulations

The Sex Discrimination Act 1984 refers to certain other Acts, to decisions under which the sex discrimination provisions would not apply, either permanently in some cases, or for 2 years in others. The Act also provides that the Regulations can extend that 2 year exemption. These Regulations extended the 2 year exemption in respect of certain Commonwealth Acts and Territory legislation in such a way as to exempt permanently decisions under that legislation from the scope of the Sex Discrimination Act. In correspondence, the Attorney-General explained why these permanent exemptions were necessary:

in regard to certain Defence and National Service legislation: the Government's policy is that women not undertake combat related duties nor be subject to national service; and the cost is high ($4.5 million per annum) of extending to widowers certain benefits available to widows;

in relation to the Marriage Act 1961 and the lack of uniformity in the marriage age: the apparent community preference for an increase to the higher male level of the age at which females may marry could disadvantage females; therefore the status quo has been maintained;

in regard to the National Health Act: the need to preserve consistency between these provisions and those in the Social Security Act regarding the different ages (65 for males and 60 for females) at which males and females become entitled to certain pensions; and the 9 month waiting period before a female contributor to a health insurance scheme becomes eligible for hospital benefits for an obstetric condition is considered justified to protect the economic viability of the health insurance schemes;

in relation to the Student Assistance Act and provisions which discriminate on the grounds of sex and marital status regarding eligibility for assistance: the cost ($350 million per annum) of extending independent status to all students;

in relation to the War Gratuity Act and the fact that (i) de facto spouses must satisfy a test of dependency which legal spouses need not, and (ii) widows obtain certain advantages over widowers: extensive cost would arise if the sex discrimination was removed; the nature of the payments is such that in time they will naturally cease;
in relation to the Adoption of Children Ordinance: male or female adopters must be over different ages before they may adopt (18 and 16 years of age);
in relation to Registration of Births-discrimination as between single and married fathers when registering a birth (the mother's consent is required for the former); and

in relation to divorce, family, and criminal law on Christmas Island, the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Norfolk Island-various provisions including some which are the subject of discussions with the Muslim community.

The Attorney-General told the Committee that in respect of many of the foregoing matters they were the subject of some ongoing review or would be reviewed in the near future. The Committee considered that a number of the permanent exemptions involved issues of some moment and potential controversy; further, the objects of the Sex Discrimination Act should not be seen to be unduly weakened by delegated legislation at a time when complex issues, crucial to the ideals of sex equality, were still under review. The Committee asked the Attorney-General to substitute a 2 year sun-set clause for permanent exemptions. Thus for a further 2 years the matters referred to above would continue to be exempted from the requirements of the Sex Discrimination Act but during that time the reviews and inquiries mentioned above could continue in a purposive way, possibly leading to a different approach to some of the issues in 2 years time. After giving the matter careful consideration the Attorney-General agreed to the Committee's request and undertook to make an amendment subjecting the exemption regulations to a 2 year sun-set clause.
Futures Industry Regulations (Amendment)

The Futures Act 1986 provides that an inspector can require the production of certain books of account, etc., on producing such evidence of authority as is prescribed. The Regulations prescribed ``a document that is issued by the Commission . . . that states that the person may require the production of books'', etc. The Committee considered that, in the interests of privacy and to deter impostors, some means of official photographic identification should be produced before the person should be required to give someone access to confidential commercial documents. Also, the Committee queried the subjective nature of the drafting in service of documents provisions (service on a person who is `apparently' an appropriate recipient, rather than on a person who `is or is reasonably believed to be' such a person). The Attorney-General undertook to raise these matters with his colleagues of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities.
National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Regulations

These Regulations provided that the Commission could use the name `Worksafe Australia' and an associated emblem. Other persons were prohibited from using these, or names and signs resembling them. The Committee wished to establish that no other persons had pre-existing compensible proprietary rights to use these names, because the Regulations did not provide for such compensation. By contrast, the Australian National Airlines Regulations (S.R. 1986 No. 201), regarding the names `Australian Airlines' and `Australian Cargo', expressly protected the rights of any prior users of the names, and provided for compensation on just terms for any `acquisition of property' in the right to use the names. The Minister for employment and Industrial Relations explained that searches had revealed that neither the name `Worksafe Australia' nor any similar name nor the logo had been registered as a business name or symbol. The name has since been registered in the name of the Commission. In the Minister's view therefore, there was no compensible acquisition of property from any person and, in the light of advice, he did not believe that the Australian National Airlines Regulations were a model which needed to be followed in this case.
Apple and Pear (Conditions of Export) Regulations (Amendment)

The regulations enabled the Apple and Pear Corporation to charge licence fees for services rendered in reviewing export performances. However, the Regulations did not provide that such periodic reviews could be undertaken and there was therefore, some question as to the legality of the fees. The Minister for Primary Industry agreed to amend the Regulations to provide expressly for the review each calendar year of licencees' export performance. The Minister also agreed that he would have no objection to making available by the AAT the exercise of the Corporation's discretion relating to the duration of an export licence. There were however, fundamental policy reasons for not providing administrative review of Corporation decisions to specify the ports and from which a licencee would be authorised to export, or to approve of importers at the export destination.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, left yesterday on official duty in Japan. He will return on 21 November. In his absence the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hurford, is the Acting Treasurer. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, left on 15 November for France and China and the Special Minister of State, Mr Young, is Acting Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations until Mr Willis returns on 4 December.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to the survey by the National Australia Bank Ltd and the Australian Chamber of Commerce which reports higher costs and a significant fall in profitability for the tertiary sector of the economy in the September quarter. Does the Minister share the concern of Mr Brian Hamley of the National Australia Bank, who described as `disturbing' the fact that 41 per cent of respondents expected a decrease in capital expenditure? Noting that the survey found that the level of demand was the main factor affecting capital investment plans, does the Minister agree that the current high interest rates regime is a major factor in suppressing demand, as well as being a factor operating on investment plans in its own right? How long can interest rates remain at present levels without causing long term damage to the economy? What action, if any, does the Government propose to take to ease interest rates?

—Of course I share Mr Hamley's concern. The Government has made it quite clear for some time that because of the changed trading conditions in which we find ourselves there will be slower economic growth in 1986-87 than there was in 1985-86, and that that is appropriate. There have been no developments which change that view. The survey shows that respondents are not anticipating-this was a part of the survey which Senator Chaney did not advert to-any major downturn in the December quarter. It is, of course, true that planned capital expenditure is low, but this is consistent with the forecasts in the Budget. Other surveys show private sector forecasts for 1986-87 are not significantly weaker than the Budget forecasts, and those forecasts, of course, represent the professional judgment of officers of the Department of the Treasury. With regard to the question of the current interest rates regime, Senator Chaney will well know that I am not in the business of predicting interest rate movements, and I can add nothing to what I have said on previous occasions.

—I ask a supplementary question. I understand the Minister's reluctance to predict interest rates, but, as the Government has been actively involved in policies which affect interest rates, I ask: Does the Government have in mind taking any action which would ease the pressure on interest rates? I do not ask the Minister to predict the precise movements, but are Government policy settings which do affect interest rates going to be changed to ease the pressure in that area?
—The answer to that question is: When the Government deems that to be appropriate.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. It relates to the current problems at the Australian War Memorial. Several newspapers have reported comments by the Director that the matters between him and the Minister are essentially trivial and technical by nature. Could the Minister inform the Senate whether these matters are indeed trivial?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of unauthorised Press statements have been made by the Director in contradiction to a request by the Australian War Memorial Council that he not issue any Press statements. He has asserted that the matters in dispute are both trivial and technical. That does not accord with the facts. In fact, four separate reports have been prepared during this year. The first one was commissioned by the Director himself and is known as the Arthur Young report. It was a badly flawed document. It cost some $60,000 and it clearly shows that it did not understand the procedures, the role and the powers of the Council. However, the report did find serious deficiencies in the administration of the Australian War Memorial, as did the Auditor-General's report, the O'Connor report and the Ken Jones report.

ANSWER.PARA: All those reports were prepared independent of government and all were designed to establish whether the Council of the War Memorial and its Director were operating in accordance with proper administrative functions. I do not think anyone could dismiss those reports as trivial or technical and not of some substantive nature. As I have already tabled the other three reports, I now table the Arthur Young report so that the Senate and the public at large can see whether there are reasons to believe that the matters require the Government's attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I again refer the Minister to the minute from a member of his staff advising that the Minister wanted a ceremony arranged at the Australian War Memorial to mark the proclamation of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. Does the Minister accept the finding of the Jones inquiry that `this would suggest that even if the Minister did not personally direct that the function be held at the AWM, the advice emanating from his office certainly indicated that this was his wish'? Does the Minister also accept that the director of public relations in his own Department confirmed `the decision to hold the function at the AWM was not taken by the Department, but by the Minister's Office'? If the Minister does not dispute these comments, why does he continue to claim, as he did in the Senate on 29 May and again last Friday, that the organisation of the function was not at ministerial direction? Is he saying that he does not take responsibility for the actions of his staff?

—It is obvious that Senator Lewis does not understand the difference between `request' and `direction', although he is a solicitor, a legally trained person. As I indicated to him on the last occasion he asked me a somewhat similar question, the matter of determining where the ceremony for the proclamation of the Veterans' Entitlements Act would take place was a matter for the Department. Having made that decision, the question of examining who was to be invited and in what form the ceremony would take naturally was one undertaken in consultation between my personal staff and the Department as well as with officers of the Australian War Memorial. Never at any stage did I direct that the ceremony take place at the Australian War Memorial. It was not until we had supplied our files to Mr Jones that a letter was discovered on file. Air Vice-Marshal Flemming and others associated with the Australian War Memorial were not aware of it. We made it freely available to Mr Jones. On the basis of that letter he drew a prima facie conclusion that my office was aware of the fact that there was to be a function at the Australian War Memorial for the proclamation ceremony. If all the Opposition has to say in respect of the total maladministration of the Australian War Memorial is that that was done at my direction, it is failing in its duty as an opposition.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry seen the September 1986 edition of the newsletter of the Livestock and Grain Producers Association entitled `The Primary Report'? What does it say about the proportion of farms which are vulnerable to bankruptcy and what are the key factors causing that vulnerability?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the issue of the publication in question. I am very pleased that the official report of the LGPA has put the magnitude of the farm problem in better and more accurate perspective than it is normally put. To demonstrate that I would like to read a few extracts from the report. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: It should be remembered that close to 30 per cent of farmers have no debt and it is likely that these farmers will actually have benefited from the nation's high interest rate environment.
It goes on to say in later pages:

The implications of a fall in land prices for the rest of the farm community may not be as severe as first thought. The average farm value in Australia is around $720,000, and with debts averaging $80,000 per farm, the average equity ratio is 89 per cent.
I repeat: The average equity ratio is 89 per cent. The report goes on to say:

Suppose land prices fall by 20 per cent and debts increase by 20 per cent overall. This would mean a drop in average farm value to $576,000 and a rise in average debt to $96,000. But the resultant equity ratio would still be high at 83 per cent, indicating the resilience of farm sector balance sheets to major swings in return.

I have not had those figures verified by Government sources but they seem to approximate official Government estimates of the farm equity situation. As I said earlier, I am delighted to see a farm organisation, if not putting the facts absolutely correctly, making an accurate assessment of the facts and putting the problem in its proper perspective. The report goes on to say:

Some farmers may complain about the conservative attitudes of bankers in the valuation and approval of rural loans, but it would seem that this conservativeness has been of help for the sector as a whole in the present crisis.

A bit of conservatism in the valuations and land prices would have been of considerable help to the minority of farmers who are in severe financial difficulties today. Almost without exception, the reason that people in that small minority are either insolvent or approaching insolvency is that within the last few years they have paid far too much for land. The reason they paid far too much for land was attributable principally to two factors: Firstly, the availability of soft loans, soft in terms of borrowing conditions, largely from the Primary Industry Bank of Australia Ltd following its establishment in 1979; and, secondly, the expectation of untaxed capital gains. In other words, had there always been a decent capital gains tax in operation in Australia, as there now is in spite of the efforts of the Opposition, a very high proportion of that minority of farmers who are presently faced with insolvency would not be in the trouble they are now in. Encouraged by this Opposition to believe that they could go on harvesting capital gains untaxed forever, among things, led them to bid up the price of farm land to excessive and unsustainable levels and is the direct cause of their present financial problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. Is the Government supporting the recommendation of the Industries Assistance Commission that no assistance be given to citrus growers except for helping them to get out of business? What future does the Minister envisage for this industry in the light of the fact that growers' incomes have dropped dramatically in the last year due to massive releases of frozen orange juice concentrate by Brazil on to the world market and since the Government is lowering tariffs and imposing a new 20 per cent sales tax on fruit juice? Does the Government plan a similar fate for all other primary, mining and manufacturing industries when they are similarly affected by world trade wars and the protectionist policies of major world trading powers? What is the relative cost of preserving our capital investment in the citrus industry compared with the cost of unemployment, the future effect on our balance of payments and our total dependence on imports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney pointed out by way of interjection that this is a very good question. It is also a very large question. I am flattered that Senator Vigor believes that I would have the wisdom or the patience to answer it in any detail. First, the question clearly arises from the fact that there has been an IAC report on the citrus industry. That report was received by the Government on 16 October and publicly released on 5 November. The fact that an IAC report on a particular industry has been released does not mean that the Government has taken any decision on that report. The IAC is a recommendatory body. It makes recommendations to the Government on the levels of assistance that should apply to particular industries. It does not make Government decisions.

ANSWER.PARA: I am also asked what future the Government sees for the industry. That is a very long part of the question, but I inform Senator Vigor that today the Australian Customs Service made a preliminary finding on the dumping from Brazil of citrus extract. Provisional measures will operate from tomorrow to protect the industry against dumping. I am also asked what fate is planned for other industries. I make the point that the Government is aiming to assist the long term export and development potential of Australian industry generally.

If Senator Vigor listened when we had debates on these issues he might recognise what the Government has been doing for the medium to long term future of export industries. I am also asked about the relative cost of preserving capital investment in the citrus industry. I am not able to answer that in precise terms, but the Government does not intend to allow the industry to collapse. As with other industries, we aim to assist its growth potential in its more competitive areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Education seen the editorial in the Canberra Times of Wednesday, 12 November titled `Nation Lags in Science' in which the editorial makes an assessment of the need for more skilled labour, especially scientists, if Australia is to strengthen its manufacturing sector? Does the Minister agree that our education systems have a major role to play in encouraging more people to opt for science? The editorial also suggests that something ought to be done to make science an important part of the school curriculum and that girls should be given more encouragement to undertake science courses. What initiatives are planned to achieve those goals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly agree with the points made in the Canberra Times editorial, as indeed I agreed with a similar statement made by the deans of science faculties a couple of weeks ago. When I spoke to that same group over a year ago I think similar points were raised. The Government recognises that there is a shortfall in scientific knowledge and skills in our community and our economy is the poorer for it. The school system is the obvious place to start in correcting this deficiency. We have been working on this for over three years now and there are a number of major initiatives which should help to bring more students into the science area, skill them and keep them there for their working lives.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course one of the major shortcomings has been that girls, consciously or unconsciously, have been channelled away from the science subjects in their secondary years. As a result, their participation in higher education science courses is very much lower than it ought to be and their participation in the scientific community is correspondingly lower. We have sponsored a number of projects aimed at raising girls' consciousness of the need to study science and the vocational attractions of studying science. For example, my colleague Barry Jones and I launched a Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation project for girls in science in which successful women scientists have taken time to go into schools to talk to girls about their careers, what skills they need, what satisfactions they get from science and so forth. I have heard very favourable comment on that project.

In a major sense we are going to tackle the question of girls and science through our national strategy for the education of girls. This national initiative was agreed by all State Education Ministers except the Queensland Minister at the last meeting of the Education Ministers Council and it has since been endorsed by the major non-government systems. One of its main thrusts will be to use a number of strategies to get more girls participating in science throughout their education but particularly in the secondary years and to be oriented towards further science courses after they leave school.

As to the general capacity of our students to be scientifically literate, we are addressing that problem by developing a project we are calling a science for all project carried out by the Schools Commission and the Curriculum Development Council. It will aim to get all school children scientifically literate and will be an important starting point to raising the status and impact of science in schools. As well as our efforts in the school level, of course we are doing many things to improve the number of science graduates, such as giving priority through the allocation of new student places in universities and colleges to science and technology courses. The Government is very well aware of the problems raised in the Canberra Times editorial. We are taking action to combat these problems and we hope that we will have the co-operation of the education community and the wider business community in our efforts.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to his answer to me last Friday. He said in relation to his tabling the previous day of the statutory declarations by officers of the Australian War Memorial:

QUESTION.PARA: I did not endorse their response, and I do not resile from my responsibilities in that respect.
The Minister will recall that when he tabled the declarations on Thursday he described the officers concerned as:
. . . people who, in my view, are innocent in respect of any of the problems that exist in the Australian War Memorial.

Does the Minister seriously suggest that these words do not amount to endorsement of the actions of those officers? How can the Minister possibly justify attacking the Director of the War Memorial while refusing to investigate allegations concerning other officers at the War Memorial and accepting their version of events very much linked to his own criticism of the Director?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue that Senator Reid raises arises from a misconception about the documents which I tabled in the Senate last week. When the allegations were made in the House of Representatives in an adjournment debate I checked with some of the officers concerned, who denied any wrong-doing, and I made the statement accordingly. I also suggested to them that they should put their responses in writing and subsequently I tabled in the Senate a copy of the statutory declarations from two of the three persons who were in Australia at the time. Having done that I said in answer to a subsequent question that I could not and did not endorse all that was in the documents. I do not intend to endorse what is in the documents and it is not my responsibility to deal with pages and pages of responses from any member of the Public Service. That responsibility rests not with the Minister but with the Council of the Australian War Memorial, which is charged with the administration of the Australian War Memorial. That matter is already on the Council's agenda. When it has resolved the current difficulties I am sure that, if there is any substance in the allegations made by Mr Everingham on that occasion and which were repeated on Friday afternoon, that will be a matter for the Council to determine.

ANSWER.PARA: I am satisfied about the integrity of the officers concerned and I indicated that in my earlier response. It is my responsibility, however, in respect of the Director, to draw what I consider to be matters affecting the general administration of the War Memorial to the attention of the Australian War Memorial Council. The Council has had the matter on its agenda on numerous occasions and is meeting again this afternoon in the hope of resolving the difficulties. That is the correct responsibility of the Council and the powers of the Minister in these matters are very limited as a direct result of the passage by the Parliament of the Australian War Memorial Act 1980.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is the Minister aware of the disagreement in the community over the decision by the Government to provide clean needles to intravenous drug users? Can the Minister elaborate on the reasons behind the Government's decision? Can he make clear that the savings that will result by the introduction of this preventative measure, both in terms of dollar costs and reduced numbers of people with acquired immune deficiency syndrome or hepatitis, for example, far outweigh the cost of the needles, and that the measure is not an encouragement or promotion of drug use or abuse?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the controversy which arose from the statements by Dr Blewett in a television program and elsewhere that there should be a greater availability of clean needles and syringes for intravenous drug users. This courageous recommendation was backed strongly by participants at the Second National AIDS Conference in Sydney a fortnight ago. I think it is important to remember that the evidence suggests that an effective vaccine or treatment for AIDS is some considerable way away. Every attempt has been made here and overseas to develop such a vaccine. In the meantime we have to assume that a vaccine is a long way away and every attempt should be made to ensure that our efforts to prevent the spread of this disease are as effective as possible.

ANSWER.PARA: The spread of AIDS and hepatitis B via drug users who rely on the multiple use of dirty needles and syringes is well documented. In fact, in the New York area in the United States of America it is believed that, of the 40 per cent of people presenting with AIDS, almost 50 per cent have been intravenous drug users, and this does not include the number of homosexuals who are also IV users, which would expand that figure considerably. The spread of AIDS via IV drug abuse and via the IV drug using population in Australia is likely to lead to a second and more rapid phase of the AIDS epidemic in Australia, as has happened in other countries. Whether we like to admit it or not, IV drugs use is not confined to one particular class in our society or to one sex group in our country. The rapid spread of the virus through the majority of IV drug users, further spread through sexual contact and, even worse, further spread through the large numbers of children born to this group of people, will assist the rapid dissemination of the disease through the community. We do know that the system of exchanging new needles and syringes for old ones was introduced in the Netherlands in 1984 and, two years later, the Netherlands has one of the lowest rates of AIDS amongst intravenous drug users of any country in Europe, despite its large homosexual population. While the current rate of infection amongst intravenous drug users in Australia is low, except in South Australia where some 24 per cent of people found to have AIDS were IV drug users, it is important to face up to the fact that an explosive risk is represented to the community through this.

State health authorities have been approached by the head of the AIDS task force on the need to develop strategies to enhance availability of needles and to seek to educate intravenous drug users in Australia. The Pharmaceutical Society of Australia has adopted a policy recommending that pharmacists should be willing to sell needles and syringes to intravenous drug users in order to curb the spread of AIDS through needle sharing. I think it would be absolutely disastrous for this country or this Parliament to believe that drug use will be increased by the adoption of such measures. It is as silly as saying that advocating safe sex will lead to an increase in homosexual behaviour. What the Minister for Health has done is to take a practical and effective approach to a very serious problem. It is unfortunate that he may be condemned by some individuals in this area who believe that problems go away if we do not consider them. I think we should do everything we can to prevent AIDS becoming an even bigger problem than it is. One of those mechanisms is through the distribution of clean needles and the prevention of the multiple use of needles, as recommended by the Minister for Health.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veteran's Affairs. Is it a fact that solicitors for the Australian War Memorial Council advised the Council, which in turn advised the Jones Inquiry into the Australian War Memorial that the Director of the Memorial had the right to be present and to question witnesses who appeared before that Inquiry? Was the Director denied this right? Does the Minister agree that this amounts to a denial of the principles of natural justice to Air Vice-Marshal Flemming?

—In recent days I have seen a letter written by the solicitors for the Australian War Memorial Council in which they have made the suggestion in the words used by Senator Kilgariff. However, I advise the Senate that the terms of reference were drawn up by the Council of the Australian War Memorial and the conduct of the Inquiry was by Mr Jones. I was certainly informed and consulted about the final draft of the terms of reference and on every occasion, as the minutes of the Council meeting will show, I sought to insist that, when the original terms of reference were drawn up, they be designed to give Air Vice-Marshal Flemming natural justice. That was stressed, particularly by me, on the occasion on which the final terms of reference were agreed to and presented to Mr Jones. So any suggestion that either the Council or the Minister-or, for that matter, Mr Jones-in any way, shape or form sought to deny natural justice to Air Vice-Marshal Flemming is not feasible and is rejected outright.

—I ask a supplementary question. If the Minister says that the Council, he, the Minister, and Mr Jones did not deny Air Vice-Marshal Flemming the right to appear as a witness before the Inquiry, is not this really a denial of the principle of natural justice? Did he not deny it?

—The conduct of the Inquiry was under the jurisdiction of Mr Jones, acting at the request of the Australian War Memorial Council. There is no substance to the suggestion that Mr Jones denied natural justice to Air Vice-Marshal Flemming.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to the story of an interview this morning by Mike Carlton of 2GB with the temporary Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard? I ask whether there are any official figures to verify Mr Howard's claim that the Australia Card `won't put a glove on the cash economy, which is probably costing the exchequer about seven to eight billion dollars a year in lost tax revenue'.

—My attention has been drawn to the interview Mr Howard apparently had with Mike Carlton this morning. Indeed, I have a transcript of it here and I must say that there are some fascinating extracts in it. In regard to the question directly, the assertion that the Australia Card will not put a glove on the cash economy is false and it is false for this reason: Where a payment is being made in a false name to an individual by somebody who is claiming that payment as a deduction from his taxable income-naturally the payer would want to continue claiming against the payer's taxable income the wages payment which had been made-that will no longer be possible under the Australia Card. It will no longer be possible for the recipient of that wage or payment to receive it under a false name. At least to that extent the Australia Card will eliminate--
—How much is attributable to that?

—The honourable senator is the expert on it. I have been asking him for substantiation of the figures he put out two months ago. If the honourable senator can substantiate the wild guesses he put out two months ago, I would be very pleased to receive substantiation.
—You don't know.

—I do not even know the prevailing deficit of Patrick Partners. To the extent that the situation I have identified is part of the cash economy, the Australia Card will wipe it out. As to the rest of the claim that was made by Mr Howard, which is a variant of the claim made earlier by Senator Messner, I put this question: Even if that were true, what does the Opposition propose to do about it? The only thing the Opposition has proposed to do about it so far is to sabotage the Government's attempt, via the introduction of the Australia Card, to wipe out a substantial part of the tax evasion that proceeds in the black economy. However, I would welcome-as I invited Senator Messner to do a while ago-any degree of substantiation that is not too incestuous that the Opposition could present in regard to the magnitude of the claims it is making. I would welcome even more some constructive suggestions from the Opposition on how tax evasion, via the cash economy, could be attacked in ways other than the attack the Government proposed to launch through the Australia Card and which the Opposition, very predictably, is sabotaging. For at least the last decade this Liberal Party has been the friend and protector of tax evasion in Australia and it continues to be so.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Finance, follows the question he has just answered in which he gave an example of a transaction that might be caught by the Australia Card. Would it also be possible if the Australia Card were brought in for any person making payments using black money-that is, money which had not been declared for tax purposes and on which a tax deduction would not be claimed-to make that payment without regard to the Australia Card and for those payments, in a black economy of that sort, simply not to be touched?

—At no stage did I even suggest, let alone assert, that all tax evasion in the cash economy would be eliminated by the introduction of the Australia Card. I said that in those cases where the payer was claiming the deduction against the payer's taxable income, and under those circumstances very likely paying somebody who was using a false name for a bit of moonlighting, the Australia Card would eliminate that type of tax evasion within the cash economy.
—You cannot tell us how much that is.

—I have no doubt that Senator Messner has friends who are much better informed on the question of tax evasion than I am. Indeed, I suspect that most of his friends would be very well informed on the question of tax evasion because they are at the work place--
—Order! I ask the Minister to ignore interjections and respond to Senator Chaney.

—Certainly, Mr President. In the case identified by Senator Chaney-that is, where an individual is not claiming the payment as a deduction from the payer's taxable income, an example of which would be a householder having some work done, such as having a plumber fix up a toilet-it would be very much more difficult to trace. One could not have the same certainty that the Australia Card would eliminate tax evasion there. It will, however, have some deterrent effect because if the recipient of the payment-unless he wants to spend the money immediately, and even then there are ways in which conceivably he could be caught-ultimately deposits funds in a bank account under his own name instead of a false name, as has certainly happened in some instances in the past, there is a longer term possibility, if not a probability, that he will be caught in that way. I repeat the invitation to the Opposition: If the Opposition can make any useful suggestions as to how tax evasion within the cash economy may be dealt with in those instances where the payer is not claiming the payment as a deduction from the payer's taxable income, I would be very grateful to receive them, as I am sure would the Treasurer.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to an article in the Australian on 15 October written by John Spiers concerning the maritime unions and the excellent result obtained by the Maritime Industry Development Committee regarding the agreement on sweeping measures to revitalise the Australian shipping industry. Can the Minister give the reason for this agreement, given the history of strikes and stoppages in past years? Has the Minister any comment to make on the approach adopted here compared with the approach adopted by the so-called New Right in its industrial relations policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The perceptions that members of the general public have about the shipping industry have been characterised, I believe, by the belief that it has out of date work practices. To that extent the Minister for Transport has taken very energetic steps to see what can be done to improve the work practices in the shipping industry. The release of the Maritime Industry Development Committee report shows that those perceptions are out of date and that Australian shipping ought to be seen, as it now is, as developing both responsibly and valuably to the nation. The emphasis that the Minister has placed on this matter is one of co-operation between all sections of the industry-the unions, the ship owners and the Government. It is another example of the way in which matters which have been of concern in the past can be resolved. Negotiations have been conducted in a very constructive way over the past 12 months.

ANSWER.PARA: The way in which the sea-going unions of Australia and the ship owners have approached this problem is a matter for some commen- dation. They have adopted an innovative approach which has resulted in considerable improvements. That has brought about an agreement to reduce the manning levels on new technologically advanced ships to a crew of 21 accompanied by improved trading. This will allow for greater flexibility for mariners to move through the ranks, to improve their efficiency and productivity on Australian ships and to develop our own shipping industry. This is tangible proof of the Government's approach of consultation rather than confrontation and of the way in which confrontation policies, as expressed by the loony Right, will not succeed in light of the positive approach which is taken by the Australian Government. Of course, the Hamer Bill, if adopted, would bring us back to the divisive period rather than the one of constructive co-operation which this Government has initiated, which is succeeding and which has led to a very much improved work environment on the Australian shipping front.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and relates to the defence service home loans scheme and to the changes announced in the 1985 mini-Budget. Have the details which are to be included in tender requests yet been finalised? What will be the cost of implementing the scheme? When will it be implemented and in what form? Why was it not implemented as planned on 1 January 1986? Will the current $25,000 limit be increased and who will be eligible? Is the Minister aware of the great disquiet among the defence forces over the issue? Does he take responsibility for this matter?

QUESTION.PARA: Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I pointed out on Friday that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs does have some difficulty in hearing and I would ask that he be given the opportunity of hearing Senator Newman's question.
—Is it true that the Minister is one of the Ministers to be reshuffled at Christmas?

—My answer to the very inane last part of the question is very short: As far as I am concerned there is to be no reshuffle. The other matters are the subject of Government consideration and it is our desire to approach this question in a way which will maintain the benefits for those beneficiaries, most of whom now have served in the peace time Services. In other words, the moving of the eligibility of veterans from war time to peace time from 1972 onwards has brought about a situation in which the majority of applicants for defence service home loans now comes from the peace time Services. Although it comes under my portfolio responsibility, the Government is anxious to take what steps it can, having regard to the budgetary restraints, to bring about a system that in no way will disadvantage the old eligible persons-that is, the veterans from past wars-and, with the co-operation possibly of the other financial institutions, will maintain the same degree of eligibility, I hope, in a better scheme than that existing at the moment.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Has the Government received widespread support for condemning Peko-Wallsend Ltd for its action in sacking, at 30 minutes notice, the work force of its subsidiary company, Besco Batteries, in Sydney?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the answer to the question essentially would have to be yes, the Government has received wide support on that issue and, if I may say so, some of it has come from quarters which, to me at least, are rather surprising, such as the editorial column of the Weekend Australian. It is particularly surprising when one looks at so much of the other content of that publication. These are extracts from what the Weekend Australian had in its editorial last weekend:

ANSWER.PARA: One of the signs that something is going wrong has been the way in which the Liberal Party has been unable to shake off easily the Government's charges that the party is dominated by New Right thinking.
But Peko's closing of Besco Batteries in Sydney at 30 minutes' notice to a work force with which it had no complaint should be condemned unequivocally.

If a political party believes that a docile worker, with some length of service, against whom there is no complaint, should be sackable with 30 minutes' notice in what most reasonable people would consider an inhuman way, then just what sort of society is the Liberal Party trying to build?

The Weekend Australian posed the question. I would not presume to answer the question, but I certainly would welcome it if Mr Howard would join the Australian newspaper and all the other people who have supported the Government in its criticism of Peko for that decision on the Besco action. But if Mr Howard will not complain about it, perhaps Mr Peacock will.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the Australian Customs Service decision today-which the Minister has already referred to in answering an earlier question-that cash securities or documentary securities will be applied to imports of Brazilian frozen orange juice concentrate. In view of the recent Industries Assistance Commission finding that these imports are setting domestic prices and that the price landed in Australia has crashed from $US1,800 to $US800 a tonne this year, what will be the amount applied to the new Customs securities? As the countervailing tariff applied to the dumped Brazilian product by the United States of America authorities has been public knowledge for some weeks, why did today's statement fail to quantify the measures to be put in place in Australia? What will be the value of these securities?
—I am not sure that in a finding of this kind Customs ever quantifies the amount, but I will have that looked into and will provide the honourable senator with an answer as soon as possible.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has his attention been drawn to a recent article in the financial pages of the Sydney Morning Herald showing that Australian share markets hit a record 42 times during the last 10 months? Does the health of Australian share markets, as demonstrated by those 42 records, contradict claims by the Opposition about the impact of the capital gains tax and therefore tax reform in general? Does the large volume of share transactions-on the latest advice I have it is $6,900m this year compared with $3,500m last year-indicate that many shares previously exempt from the capital gains tax have changed hands and are therefore now subject to the tax, and that investors have caused that to happen voluntarily?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —To that part of the question which asks whether the activity in the share market in recent months contradicts claims being made by the Opposition that there would be a share lock-in, the answer is clearly yes. In particular, it ridicules the following claim by Senator Messner on 4 June:

ANSWER.PARA: The long term effect of that-
that is, the capital gains tax-
is likely to be a stiffening up in the market-place-financial arthritis, if you like-with people hanging on to their assets in order to avoid paying a capital gains tax.

Never mind whatever peculiar theory the Liberal Party happens to be following at any stage, the empirical evidence of what has actually happened since then makes absolute nonsense of that claim. However, this caveat should be lodged: I am not sure what the aggregate level of the share trading activity, that is, the value of sales, in the last almost five months is, but whatever that aggregate figure is it would inevitably contain some element of double counting or even multiple counting. There is no doubt that trading activity, not only in the aggregate levels but also in the numbers of shares-specific or identifiable shares-has been running at extremely high levels, making absolute nonsense of the claims that have been made by the Opposition.

While I am on the subject, it is worth noting that there has been some decline in the share price index in the last few days-I am not sure what has happened today-from an extraordinarily high and record level reflecting a 30 per cent or 36 per cent increase, as I think it has been in the last 12 months. As Senator Maguire's question stated, the record has been broken 42 times this year. These things show that the capital gains tax will not affect healthy share trading but will help to curb speculative excesses of the type that have often happened in the past, that is, when the seemingly ineradicable inclination of some people to gamble on the stock exchange at prices in excess of any realistic long term market value is compounded by the expectation that the gains they make through those trading activities will be free of capital gains tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Share traders always have to pay tax. Don't talk such rubbish.

—I am glad Senator Baume mentioned that. It is possible that under section 26 (a), I think it is, of the Income Tax Assessment Act somebody could be deemed to be a share trader by the Commissioner of Taxation and have to pay tax on his full nominal gains at the marginal income tax rate and would not know until the Commissioner made a declaration whether or not he was going to be classified as a share trader. Under the reformed regime this Government has introduced everybody knows from the beginning precisely where he stands. People will pay tax on any real gains from share trading whether or not the Commissioner exercises his arbitrary discretion to declare them as share traders. One thing which the application of the capital gains tax will do is reduce the highly undesirable compounding effect of the expectation of tax-free capital gains feeding back into further undesirable and unhealthy speculation in the share market. What has happened in the last few months has shown so clearly that everything the Opposition was saying about the application of the capital gains tax locking in the ownership of shares indefinitely is nonsense, just as almost everything else it says about economic questions is nonsense.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PATENT, TRADE MARKS AND DESIGNS OFFICE

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to his comments reported in a recent edition of Computerworld Australia that if Australian businesses were to compete in the international market-place they would have to adopt imported world class technologies. How does the Minister reconcile these comments with the Government's decision to close the technology information office of the Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office, one of the primary functions of which was to provide information about technological developments and thus facilitate the greater use of overseas technology by Australian firms?

—The reference in the Computerworld Australia article to what I said was probably taken out of context. I would not have said in isolation that Australia had to depend significantly on imported world class technology. Having made that qualification, in my view that statement, in a proper context, is quite correct. Australia will have to depend to a significant degree on imported world class technology. With regard to the statement made about the Patent Office and the future of the information technology office in the Patent Office, that matter is peculiarly within the province of my colleague Mr Jones, the Minister for Science. I am not fully familiar with what decision has been made in respect of it. I will try to obtain an answer from Mr Jones and provide it as soon as possible.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence aware of the very popular reception given by the public to the recent military displays by the Royal Australian Air Force during the 1986 Grand Prix, yesterday at Edinburgh in an open day which thousands of people attended, and by the Royal Australian Navy for its jubilee? Is the Minister aware that military displays are a unique public relations exercise on behalf of Australia's defence program? In view of the outstanding success of these military displays, will the Minister consider ongoing public displays by all the Australian defence forces to show the public where its taxes are spent and how unfortunate is the lack of confidence sometimes in Australia's defence systems?
—Senator Elstob has just blown my chance of setting a personal record-getting through an entire Question Time for the first time in 3 1/2 years without answering a question.
—And ours, too.

—I was going to ask you, Mr President, whether it would be in order for me to wear an eyeshade and an earplug in future so I could really enjoy Question Time. Along with other colleagues who would have heard the roars of the FA18s during the Australian Grand Prix, I am aware of the splendid display of the FA18s and F111s on that occasion. I understand that the Minister for Defence approved participation by those aircraft following a request from the South Australian Premier, Mr Bannon. Honourable senators will be aware that the Royal Australian Air Force regularly performs at major public attractions and also at lesser shows and exhibitions. For example, the Macchi Roulettes, honourable senators will be pleased to know, are regular performers at shows throughout Australia. I am assured by the Minister for Defence that opportunities will continue to be taken within current funding levels to have the RAAF perform at major public attractions.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In response to a question from Senator Chaney last week Senator Button said that the horrendous balance of payments deficit for October of $1.735 billion was, I think his words were, on track. With a cumulative balance of payments deficit for the first four months of the fiscal year of around $6 billion, does this mean that the average monthly figures for the next eight months will be $1 billion or less? If not, has the Government amended its Budget estimate of $14.7 billion for a full year? If so, what is the revised estimate?

—I do not think that I used the word `horrendous'. If the honourable senator wants to interpolate that in his question and attribute it to me, I do not think that is correct. I doubt very much whether I said `on track'. I think I said `within the Government's anticipations'-but that does not matter much. The Government expected a not good current account deficit figure in the latter quarter of this year-for September, October and so on. The figure was not entirely surprising. I am not sure of the mathematics. I do not know whether it means that in order to achieve the Budget estimate the current account deficit has to be $1 billion or less for the remaining eight months. I have not done that arithmetic but certainly the figures indicate that the sum will have to be considerably lower than the figures for the last two or three months. I will try to do that arithmetic for the honourable senator and give him an answer at a later time.

—On Friday Senator Vanstone asked a question relating to the effect, if any, of the Sex Discrimination Act on the Family Law Act. The Family Law Act has not been changed because it does not set the marriageable age. That is set by the Marriage Act 1961. The Marriage Act 1961 has not been changed because the operations of the provision relating to the marriageable age in the Marriage Act are specifically reserved by regulations pursuant to section 40 of the Sex Discrimination Act; that is, they grant an exemption from the provisions of the latter Act.

—Earlier in Question Time today Senator Brownhill asked me whether I would quantify the protective measures against the dumping of Brazilian orange juice. I told him it was my view that it was not normal to quantify the figures. I have since been advised by the Australian Customs Service quantification of the amount of injury and the measures necessary to remove the injury is made available to all interested parties but is not available to the public generally.

—On Monday, 10 November 1986, an editorial appeared in the Canberra Times referring to the Parliamentary Privileges Bill 1986 which I introduced into the Senate on 7 October last. The editorial contained a number of misconceptions concerning the Bill. Following discussion with me, the Clerk of the Senate responded to the matters contained in the editorial in a letter to the editor, delivered by hand to the offices of the Canberra Times the following morning. The letter was published in the newspaper on Saturday, 15 November, but with editorial changes which affected its substance in some respects. For the information of the Senate I table a copy of the editorial and a copy of the full text of the letter responding to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, in view of the importance of the matter to which you have just alluded I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, in view of the fact that a significant time has elapsed between the publication of the editorial misrepresenting the Bill and the publication of the letter and the editing of the letter as published, I think that the letter should be incorporated in Hansard and I seek leave for that to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN SENATE
Canberra, A.C.T.
11 November 1986
The Editor,
The Canberra Times
Sir,

Your editorial of 10 November 1986 on the Parliamentary Privileges Bill introduced by the President of the Senate is founded upon misconceptions. It conveys the impression that the Bill aims to change the law. In fact, the Bill aims to give expression to the law as it has been expounded in a number of judgments prior to the judgment of Mr Justice Hunt. It was the latter judgment which sought to change the law by repudiating and overturning the earlier judgments.

There is no guarantee that the judgment of Hunt J. will be followed by other judges and other courts and, as the President pointed out in his second reading speech, two judges, including another judge of the Supreme Court of New South Wales, have already indicated their disagreement with Hunt J. and their preference for the existing interpretation.

The editorial paints a picture of Parliament seeking ``to assert its rights to the detriment of an accused person''. As a matter of record the defence in the trials of the late Mr Justice Murphy submitted that the law of parliamentary privilege prevented the examination of the defendant on evidence given to parliamentary committees. This was in agreement with the submission made to the Court by the President in so far as it related to the defendant and was also rejected by Hunt J.

By quoting the words of Hunt J. the editorial reinforces the misconception that the privilege of freedom of speech has, or was intended to have, some application to public or media comment and discussions.
