That this is a misinterpretation of the existing law was adequately demonstrated by the documents which were presented to the Senate by the President earlier this year. A perusal of those documents would have indicated to you that Hunt J. misinterpreted the existing law in a number of respects. In his judgment he stated that his conclusion might be otherwise where witnesses were under compulsion to testify and lacked the privilege from self-incrimination, thereby ignoring the facts that parliamentary witnesses are under compulsion, because of the nature of the powers of the Houses to compel evidence, and do lack the privilege from self-incrimination. The Bill, and the law as it exists, is designed to avoid the gross injustice of witnesses being compelled to answer questions, to give evidence of a kind not admissible in court proceedings and perhaps to incriminate themselves, and subsequently having their answers used against them, perhaps to convict them, in court.

There are on the statute books many laws, establishing a variety of tribunals, which give them power to compel evidence, remove the privilege from self-incrimination of witnesses before them, but provide that evidence so given is not admissible in court proceedings, either against witnesses or generally. Are witnesses before the statutory tribunals to have a greater protection than those taking part in the proceedings of Parliament?
A. R. CUMMING THOM
Clerk of the Senate

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 17 November, from Senator Lewis:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs either to accept the finding of the Jones inquiry that there was no `misbehaviour' by the Director of the Australian War Memorial or to institute a full and open inquiry to be conducted in accordance with the principles of natural justice as recommended to the Council by its solicitors.'
Senator for the State of Victoria
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs either to accept the finding of the Jones inquiry that there was no `misbehaviour' by the Director of the Australian War Memorial or to institute a full and open inquiry to be conducted in accordance with the principles of natural justice as recommended to the Council by its solicitors.

Mr President, I would not have moved this motion but for the extraordinary ineptness of Senator Gietzelt, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, in the administration of his portfolio as a result of which after four inquiries into the affairs of the Australian War Memorial the Government may now be facing a fifth and very expensive inquiry in order to overcome the problems. Of course, the solutions to the problems are all set out in the report of Mr K. N. Jones on his inquiry into the affairs of the Australian War Memorial. I say at the outset that Mr Jones is held in high regard by senators and members of the House of Representatives on both sides. The report certainly is first class and we make no criticism of it. We criticise only the Minister for failing to adopt the report. The report makes it quite clear that there is no ground upon which Mr Flemming might be dismissed. Mr Jones, being the excellent administrator that he was and is, has set out how the administration of the War Memorial could be altered in order to overcome the current problem. The Minister has failed to accept the advice of Mr Jones notwithstanding that he wanted the inquiry. By failing to accept the report of Mr Jones he has put everyone, in particular the Australian War Memorial Council and Air Vice-Marshal Flemming, into an impossible position.

The Australian War Memorial is far too important to all Australians to become a political football. It belongs to every one of us and in particular to the memory of those who have not returned from war and to those service men and women who have returned from war. It is for this reason that the Parliament established a statutory council to administer the War Memorial. That Council was established to make sure that the interests of all Australians were fully protected. Of course, the government of the day has an interest in the funding of the War Memorial and therefore an interest in its management efficiency and financial responsibility, but the Parliament has delegated management to the Council and that requires the Minister to distance himself from the day to day affairs of the Memorial. Therein lies the first problem: This Minister has not so distanced himself.

Senator Gietzelt will probably protest that he has not tried to interfere in the day to day administration of the War Memorial, but the truth of the matter is that his personal staff have been actively involving themselves in its affairs. A Minister cannot so distinguish himself from his staff; they act in his name. Having an interfering Minister or his staff imposes an extraordinary dilemma on the Council of the War Memorial because it is constantly being told what the Minister wants done, which creates difficulties for it when it would like to do something which is not in accordance with what it believes are the Minister's wishes.

This Minister has made it clear that he has no confidence in Air Vice-Marshal Flemming. Indeed, it seems to have become a personal vendetta. He has consistently refused to acknowledge the main conclusion of the Jones inquiry-that the Director was not guilty of misbehaviour. Senator Gietzelt and I have known each other for some 10 years. We have had conversations about all sorts of things at a committee level, and I say to him that I have been disappointed about his personal selective `quoting' in the chamber of the Jones report in relation to Air Vice-Marshal Flemming. Even as late as Question Time today he smeared the Director by innuendo and selective reporting.

There have always been difficulties at the Australian War Memorial but the truth of the matter is that this Director has been overcoming them. It seems that the Minister has now proposed to the Council that the solution is the retirement of Air Vice-Marshal Flemming. Indeed, the Minister even obtained Cabinet's approval to the payout of $60,000 if the Director would resign. In these circumstances the soft option for the Council to offer Air Vice-Marshal Flemming early retirement and compensation must have appeared as an attractive solution to it, but Air Vice-Marshal Flemming does not want to retire in these circumstances, and understandably so. The problem is that the Minister keeps heaping coals on the fire in his public criticism of the Director. In a radio interview this morning the Minister admitted that his long term objective was that the Director resign.

The criticism of the Director is unfair and unjust in that the Minister keeps highlighting the minor criticisms in the Jones report and never mentions the major conclusions or the praise of the report. Nor does he mention the proposed solutions. It is as if the Minister has not bothered to apply his mind to the proposed solutions in the Jones report. Mr Jones set out how the difficulties and problems could be overcome, but the only solution the Minister sees is that Air Vice-Marshal Flemming should resign because Mr Jones did not report that he should be dismissed. Air Vice-Marshal Flemming is, rightly so, jealous of his professional reputation. It has been acknowledged by many that when he took over as Director there were concerns about the War Memorial, particularly staff shortages. The 1984-85 annual report of the Council of the Australian War Memorial to the Minister indicated the inadequate staffing levels. Those problems have now been overcome.

Even the Minister must acknowledge the vast improvements that have been made under the Director's administration, but all the Minister can think of doing is making nit picking criticisms. I give as an example the Minister's complaint that when Air Vice-Marshal Flemming decided that he ought to review the bank with which the Council was banking, he personally checked on the banks at their front offices instead of going in to see the managers. Let me say that Air Vice-Marshal Flemming is not the only sensible person to take that action because we all know that if a person goes in to see the manager of a bank which wants his custom, the manager will say all sorts of things about how the bank will look after him. The significant thing to do is to go to the front desk and the tellers and check on the sort of service one gets there. That is how one finds out whether the bank will be able to look after one. That is what Air Vice-Marshal Flemming did, but Senator Gietzelt saw reason to criticise him for doing that. It seems to me that the Minister has developed a personal vendetta against Air Vice- Marshal Flemming.

I understand that some of the Memorial staff have complained about his administrative style. Indeed, that is the main criticism by Mr Jones-that he has not operated by the book. That, of course, is a heinous crime to the bureaucracy. But he has got things done-things that otherwise might still have been buried in a morass of paperwork. Again, the 1984-85 annual report tells us that, with the transfer of the War Memorial to the portfolio of Senator Gietzelt, new administrative and parliamentary liaison procedures were developed. I do not know what happened to those new administrative and parliamentary liaison procedures of which Senator Gietzelt was so proud, but it appears that these became clandestine through his personal staff, who developed channels of communication with War Memorial staff, that excluded the Director of the War Memorial. The Minister has not denied that these channels of information existed.

I ask the Senate: What could be more destructive to morale and good administration than having channels of communication between the Minister and staff members that exclude the Director? Either the Minister knew about and condoned those channels of communication or, worse, he did not know what his staff was up to. Either way, the Minister, by his actions, has undermined the authority of the Director by allowing these channels of communications to exist and to continue. As a result, he is responsible for the current strife. Further, the Minister has refused in this chamber to accept his responsibility for the actions of his personal staff or his Department. As late as today, he has claimed to the Senate that directions from a member of his personal staff were not directions from him as the Minister. What absolute nonsense!

Of course, we know that what really upset the Minister was this staff bulletin which, I might say, has written across the top of it, in what I believe to be Tim Fischer's handwriting, `Tim Fischer, MP'. Because that appeared on it, it was thought to be a leak to Tim Fischer, MP. Handwriting experts were even called in to find out who had written those words. The staff bulletin reads:
On Thursday 22 May at 2.30 pm, as a result of a Ministerial direction, the Department will be holding a small function, with afternoon tea . . . to introduce the new Veterans' Entitlement Bill . . .

We know what was the truth of the matter. The truth was that the Minister's office had indicated that there was a ministerial direction to have this function. But the Minister denies it because he says it was not done by him. In fact, it turned out to have been done by a member of his personal staff. Let me say also that the invitations which went out were issued in the name of the Minister of State for Veterans' Affairs, Senator the Hon. A. T. Gietzelt. The invitations to a small function did not go out in the name of the Department. Quite clearly, the Minister knew what was going on, but it was this staff bulletin that really created the great problems for the Minister.

It does not appear to be a coincidence that, on 23 September this year, the Minister failed to reappoint the former South Australian Labor Premier and distinguished soldier, Des Corcoran, to a second term. That occurred only 24 hours before a crucial meeting of the Australian War Memorial Council that would decide the Director's future in the light of the O'Connor report. We have asked the Minister time and again why he refused to reappoint Mr Corcoran to a second term. Indeed, I think Senator Reid has placed a question on the Notice Paper, asking him to tell us why he would not reappoint Mr Corcoran. The Minister, of course, has not answered. At the time the Council was to consider the matter, Senator Gietzelt told Des Corcoran that he would not be reappointed to a second term. Until that stage everyone, including Des Corcoran, as I understand it, believed that he was to be reappointed to a second term.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was told half an hour before he caught the plane.

—Half an hour before he caught the plane, my colleague Senator Jessop tells me, he was told that he would not get a second term. It was just at the time when the Council was considering this matter that Senator Gietzelt announced that he no longer had confidence in Air Vice-Marshal Flemming. Clearly, that public announcement was an attempt to influence what the War Memorial Council was doing. However, on the basis of the O'Connor report, the War Memorial Council did not take action against Air Vice-Marshal Flemming and so it became necessary, in Senator Gietzelt's mind, to have a further inquiry. We have now had the Jones inquiry. If the Minister had accepted the recommendation of Mr Jones this matter could have been over. But no, the Minister has not been prepared to accept the recommendation of that inquiry; he still wants to get rid of Air Vice-Marshal Flemming. In the light of that, Air Vice-Marshal Flemming and his advisers have looked at certain aspects of the Jones inquiry and they have drawn attention to the fact that Mr Jones did not accept the advice of Freehill, Hollingdale and Page, who are the solicitors to the Australian War Memorial. In their letter dated 31 October 1986 to the solicitors for Air Vice-Marshal Flemming, they stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . your client has the right, under the Terms of Reference as they stand, to be present in the circumstances mentioned and to question witnesses.

Of course, in all the principles of natural justice we understand that that is a basic rule. Mr Jones, in his wisdom, decided that he would not conduct his inquiry that way. I am not being critical of Mr Jones for not conducting the inquiry that way but the important point is that if the Minister now wants to take some action, other than what Mr Jones recommended, he must clearly give Air Vice-Marshal Flemming the very rights that Freehill, Hollingdale and Page set out in their letter. There must be provision for the cross-examination of witnesses. Clearly, Air Vice-Marshal Flemming must have the opportunity to be present and, if possible, to be represented and there must be some application of the rules of evidence and, in particular, of giving evidence on oath. Air Vice-Marshal Flemming had requested that he be given the opportunity to be present when evidence was given to the Jones inquiry. He also requested that on these occasions he, or his legal representatives, be given the right to cross-examine witnesses and this right was denied. If the Minister is going to take the attitude which he is taking at the present moment, he must realise that there is a denial of natural justice.

As I said, the actions of Senator Gietzelt have put everyone in an impossible position. He has put the War Memorial Council in an impossible position. It has a report which states that it has no right to dismiss Air Vice-Marshal Flemming, its Director. It has considered the War Memorial's problems with three previous reports and Mr Jones conducted a very detailed investigation, in effect clearing Air Vice-Marshal Flemming, although he set out in great detail, as the Minister has pointed out, a number of areas where matters need to be altered and changes need to be made. However, Mr Jones does not conclude that the Director has been guilty of misbehaviour in accordance with the legislation; so there is no right to dismiss Air Vice-Marshal Flemming. The Council is placed in an impossible position by the Minister saying: `If you cannot dismiss him, persuade him to resign'. It has put Air Vice-Marshal Flemming in an impossible position. How can he resign while the Minister keeps pointing out to all and sundry that he has, in the Minister's opinion, committed some acts indicating personal incompetence? Air Vice-Marshal Flemming will not accept those allegations. If he were to resign that would be some sort of concession or admission that in some way or other he was irresponsible in his behaviour as Director of the War Memorial.

If the Minister had accepted the findings I have no doubt that the matter could have been resolved in the way Mr Jones recommended. But while the Minister keeps insisting publicly that the Director must resign we have an absolute dilemma leaving only one option. As I have pointed out in my motion--

TALK.START.PARA: —Resign.

—My colleague Senator Withers points out that I have overlooked another alternative and that is that the Minister could resign. However, it may very well be that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will rectify that matter later this year. As far as Air Vice-Marshal Flemming is concerned, while the Minister maintains his present course only one option is open in the interest of natural justice and that is the expensive solution of a full and open inquiry conducted in accordance with the principles recommended to the Council by its solicitors. All of this would have been unnecessary except, as I said in my opening remarks, for the extraordinary ineptness of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in handling this affair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that I have acted with patience and propriety in dealing with the issue involving the proper administration of the Australian War Memorial. It is almost two years since the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) transferred the responsibility of the Australian War Memorial to my portfolio after the 1984 election. He did this because of his recognition of the special status of this cherished national institution. The Government recognised that it is not just another museum or gallery. It recognised and acknowledged that there were problems of inadequate resources and poor staff morale that needed particular attention. The reason the Prime Minister responded in this way was that it had been put to him by Sir William Keys, from the Returned Services League, that there was a need for specific attention to be given to this important national shrine. Since that time I have, I believe, taken what steps were available to me to examine the way in which the Australian War Memorial carries out those functions.

SPEECH.PARA: Contrary to what Senator Lewis said, I have given the War Memorial additional staff and additional funds out of my portfolio and I was responsible for convincing the Government, in the tight financial restrictions of the Budget last year, that an additional $1.3m should be made available for the purchase or construction of a warehouse to meet very important deficiencies. The Prime Minister wrote to me in September 1985 drawing my attention to the concerns that had been expressed to him. Very soon after that there was a letter in the Canberra Times of 8 October 1985 from the Memorial's former senior curator of military technology, Mr Heaton, claiming that there had been considerable internal problems in the Memorial over the past 2 1/2 years-the precise time the Director had been in office-and that top management had allowed staff morale to fall to a critically low level resulting in a rapid loss of key staff. That day I received a minute from the Director regarding this letter. Incidentally, I believe that this is the only time, in the two years I have been Minister responsible for the Memorial, that the Director has given me unsolicited advice. In that minute he said that the Heaton letter was based on hearsay and misunderstanding, that all the key staff had left the Australian War Memorial for personal or career advancement reasons, that the Memorial's difficulties were due to factors beyond its control and had, in any case, been largely overcome. Therefore, I used the Director's reassurances in response to a question asked of me in the Senate on that day. The following day the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Tim Fischer, in the adjournment debate in the House of Representatives claimed:
The Minister for Veterans' Affairs was simply wrong in his contention and advice to the Senate yesterday.
He also stated:
. . . his response smacks of a cover-up in the best Yes Minister style or, alternatively, a real failure to investigate the situation fully.

Mr Fischer continued that his information indicated that Heaton's concerns were both relevant and accurate and concluded that I had an absolute responsibility to investigate comprehensively and then take corrective action. Therefore, it is quite preposterous and improper for the Opposition, in this hypocritical way, to suggest that the initiative that I have taken in response to that criticism by the shadow Minister represents some sort of vendetta against the Director. On the contrary; I have taken up the very issues that have been pressed upon me by the Opposition through its shadow Minister. Indeed, my first inquiry into the Memorial's administration was through a minute I sent to my departmental Secretary immediately after, and in direct response to, Mr Fischer's claims. I followed this up with a letter on 18 October last year to the Chairman of the Council which states:

Under the administrative arrangements order I and the Minister with responsibility for administering the AWM Act which gives the Council responsibility for the operations of the Memorial and the Director the powers of a departmental Secretary. I should be grateful for the Council's advice on whether there are management and staff morale problems at the Memorial which need to be addressed and, if so, whether the Council would see value in instituting a suitable form of management review.

After discussing the matter with the Department when I found that there were serious limitations in the power of the Minister, that letter which I addressed last year to Dame Beryl Beaurepaire was followed up earlier this year by a suggestion to the Council of the Australian War Memorial that a management review should be carried out in the terms of the letter. What happened? The Council, on the advice of the Director, decided not to take up that offer. Therefore, it is preposterous that it should be suggested seriously that somehow or other I have personally carried out a vendetta.

This was the first occasion when the accuracy of the Director's advice to his Minister had been publicly called into question. I reiterate: It was called into question, not by me but by the Opposition through Mr Fischer. But this, of course was not the only occasion. There are at least five other examples of what I discovered to be inaccurate and misleading advice from the Director, each of these occasions being sufficiently serious to have the potential to cause me to mislead the Parliament and the Government. I will briefly run through each of these five occasions and give the Senate the gist of what Mr Jones had to say in his report on all these six questions.

Before I do that, let me answer the claim made by Senator Lewis that I have been selective. The only report that he has referred to has been the Jones report. He very selectively quoted what Mr Jones said at paragraph 5.32 on page 62 of the report. Mr Jones said:
I cannot conclude from this Inquiry that there exists misbehaviour by the Director in the terms of Section 24 (1) of the AWM Act as I understand that provision.

So the Opposition hangs its case upon that view of an investigator, as though that is the start and finish of the matter. In fact, of course, under the Australian War Memorial Act the responsibility for determining misbehaviour rest with the Governor-General, not with the investigator and not with the Government.

Let me go back to those issues that I said were subject matters that caused me concern. In February 1985 the Director submitted to me a new policy proposal for acquiring a dedicated storage facility for the Memorial at Fyshwick at a cost of $1.3m. I secured Cabinet's agreement and advised the Director accordingly in June 1985. On 30 October that year the Director proposed to me that, instead of purchasing the Fyshwick warehouse, the Government should build a new warehouse since half of the Fyshwick warehouse was the subject of a new five-year lease. While approving this change proposal, I asked the Director in a minute on 7 November last whether this new lease, or sublease, had been signed because the Memorial had failed to act promptly on receipt of Cabinet's approval of the purchase details. The Director responded:
Approval to purchase was received in a letter dated 21 August 1985 . . .

He said that negotiations to purchase had begun the previous week. That is wrong by precisely two months. The Director knew of Cabinet's approval as early as 4 June 1985. Not only did he lie to me; his laxity and incompetence meant that it was simply not possible to implement the Cabinet decision on a proposal that he initiated.

The Chairman of the Council wrote to me on 8 November last year and again on 13 March 1986 in support of case No. 2 of revising and upgrading the Memorial's management structure. It was said that the case for the revised structure was well made in correspondence to me and to the Public Service Board. But neither letter from the Chairman made any mention of letters to the Director from the Public Service Board on 5 August last year and 19 November last year, both of which expressed serious misgivings about aspects of the proposed restructuring of the staff of the Australian War Memorial. At no time did the Director, either in person or through the Chairman, pass to me any hint of the Public Service Board's misgivings. Indeed, I believe that I was wrongly led to believe that the Public Service Board was in favour of such a proposition. This is another case of the Director lying to me.

On 22 November last year, the Director sought my approval to an extension of time for submissions of the Memorial's 1984-85 annual report, claiming that the financial statements had been completed by 30 August last year and forwarded to the Auditor-General but that pressure of work facing the Auditor-General meant delays in obtaining certification. The reality is that the delay was caused because the Auditor-General had required several revisions and redraftings of these financial statements before he was prepared to grant certification. This is another example of my being misled by the Director.

On 11 February 1986 Mr Fischer placed a question on notice regarding, among other things, the cost of providing a safe staircase in the Memorial exhibition areas-and my ministerial predecessor would know something about that area. The Director's suggested reply stated that the cost of the new staircase was not available to the Memorial. The fact was that these cost figures were readily available from the National Capital Development Commission or the Department of Housing and Construction, simply by lifting the telephone and finding out. In addition, the suggested answer gave no hint that the staircase in question was the subject of a serious dispute between the Memorial and the NCDC. The dispute was publicly aired on behalf of the Opposition by Mr Fischer-as was his right-by putting his question on notice. Honourable senators should be aware that it took three pieces of correspondence from the Secretary to my Department to the Director to extract the necessary information and provide Mr Fischer with an answer that I regarded as satisfactory. Again, I stress to the Senate that it was an Opposition inquiry that gave rise to the misleading and inaccurate advice from the Director.

Finally there is the matter of the VEA proclamation ceremony and the entry in the staff memorial bulletin of 13 May that the ceremony was being held at the Memorial as a result of a ministerial direction. Questions on this matter have been raised with me several times in the chamber. The Director gave me personally on 31 July this year the advice that he had reiterated on a number of occasions in an interview with me and the head of my Department that he had nothing to do with the preparation of the staff bulletin or the use of the words `ministerial direction'. But when we looked at the staff bulletin that had been provided by the staff officer concerned, in the Director's own handwriting were the words `at ministerial direction'. He lied to me again. The fact is that, in his handwritten annotations of 19 May, he instructed the public relations officer to use those words in the bulletin. As honourable senators will be aware, that bulletin was leaked to the Opposition shadow Minister, who used the `ministerial direction' reference as the basis for an attack upon me in the Parliament. When the Director was confronted with this clear evidence of his falsehood, he retracted his earlier statements to me and said he had now recalled issuing the instructions. But it took him more than 72 hours to do that, despite the fact that I had a copy of the original document with his handwriting in my office at that time.

This is a fair indication of how much importance the Director puts on providing his Minister with factual, reliable information. I challenge any shadow Minister, or indeed any Minister of any Government, to say that he would be prepared to rely upon that sort of advice in order to establish the veracity or otherwise of the information given to him which he is obliged to give to the Parliament from time to time.

On the Heaton letter, the Director's advice was, in the words of Mr Jones, `at best inadequate and at worst misleading'. That comment refers also to the warehouse acquisition. What does Mr Jones say? He says:
. . . this matter appears to have been handled very badly . . .

The Director's minute . . . was both untimely and misleading . . . the words used by the Director were misleading . . . The Director's response to the Minister did not in any way address the Minister's questions . . .
In relation to the eastern staircase he said that the Director's advice in relation to this matter was both inadequate and misleading. On the revised Memorial structure Mr Jones said:
. . . the Minister would have good reason to believe that he was given inadequate and misleading information in relation to this matter.
On the annual report Mr Jones said:
The Minister's assertion therefore that he was given inadequate and misleading advice is not unreasonable.

Senator Lewis and members of the Opposition, I ask in what way are witnesses to be questioned on those issues? They are issues of direct relationship between the Director and the Minister. In what way would they ask somebody in the War Memorial to deal with those matters, except the Director himself? The Director himself was asked those questions by Mr Jones. In short, I have been completely vindicated in my concerns that the Director has given me false, inaccurate and misleading information on several occasions. It is not just I who have been misled by the Director. On the matter of the change in the Memorial's banker, it is clear that the Director lied not just to me but also to the previous Minister, the present Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Mr Cohen, the Council, and even Mr Jones himself. He was asked questions by the Council about the banking arrangements. He lied to the Council last week when he was questioned on that matter, when Mr Jones was brought back, and Mr Jones produced written evidence of the answer that had been provided to him by the Director. The Council found that in fact the Director had lied to the Council as late as Wednesday last week. The Chairman of the Council has written today to the head of each political party asking that the matter not be determined at this particular time.

Let us look at the spurious Opposition claim regarding a denial of the rules of natural justice by the Jones inquiry. The Director was given every opportunity to deal with the specific allegation made against him. He was provided with copies of the relevant information. No adverse finding was made against the Director without his first having the opportunity to respond to it. Mr Jones made it clear to the Director that he could make submissions as to the weight to be attached to any material. The suggestion that the Director had been denied natural justice because he did not have the opportunity to interview witnesses does not in any event apply to those issues I have already dealt with, which were issues between the Director and the Minister. No witnesses can refute those issues. It depends on what the documents of the War Memorial clearly disclosed and what the Director said about the advice he gave in those documents.

On page 39 of the inquiry's report we find that the Director was offered the opportunity to respond to specific allegations made by the staff. Obviously he was responsible in some way for leaking those allegations to Mr Everingham. The Director refused to respond to Mr Jones. He wanted to question the staff concerned. In view of the reprisals the Director has exacted against other staff who have disagreed with him previously, it is not surprising that Mr Jones was not prepared to let the Director interview staff. However, he took the proper course of making him aware of any specific allegations and seeking a response. It needs to be understood that reprisals against staff who have taken the courageous stand of speaking up to Mr Jones are a serious matter, and I have an equal obligation to look after the staff at the Memorial as I have to protect the interests of Air Vice-Marshal Flemming.

Staff contacted my office this morning to express their fears about retribution. Let me say to Senator Lewis and to any other senator that in no way have any of my personal staff been involved in any of these negotiations without my express approval. Bear in mind that these matters took place during the most difficult six months period any Minister could have had in getting the Veterans' Entitlements Bill passed by the Senate. Senator Lewis would be aware of how many hours and hours were spent by him, myself and the Australian Democrats to reach a resolution on those issues. Certainly I delegated some responsibilities in the matter and I make no adverse response about what my staff have done at my request. I ask honourable senators to look at the findings of Mr Jones. He concludes:

. . . there are serious weaknesses in the management performance of the present Director. This represents a value judgment by me and is a considered view, arrived at in accordance with the Terms of Reference as discussed at the beginning of this chapter.

I acknowledge that some of the less than full and frank provision of information to the Minister, and to a degree to the Council also, may well be due to carelessness by officers or loose administrative practice in the Memorial.

If practices are loose or information is less than frank, whose responsibility is that? Under the War Memorial Act the responsibility for the day to day affairs of the War Memorial rests entirely with the Director. So if they are less than full and frank it is pretty clear that in those circumstances the Director has to accept responsibility. Mr Jones also states:
. . . in some situations I have concluded that the Director has displayed a less than satisfactory level of competence and a carelessness in expression where the circumstances demanded truthfulness.

I demand truthfulness from the officers in my Department. It has been given to me by every person in the Department of Veterans' Affairs over the last 3 1/2 years. I am entitled to demand it from the Director of the Australian War Memorial and I will insist upon that sort of approach being adopted by everybody who comes within my jurisdiction. Unfortunately, with the way the Act is currently written, there is very little chance that either the Government or the Council can resolve this matter in the best interests of the Australian War Memorial. The Government and the Council have faith and confidence in the Australian War Memorial, and we do not believe that in the current circumstances the situation can be allowed to continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion brought forward by the Opposition in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: `That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs either to accept the finding of the Jones inquiry that there was no `misbehaviour' by the Director of the Australian War Memorial or to institute a full and open inquiry to be conducted in accordance with the principles of natural justice as recommended to the Council by its solicitors.

Two matters arise from that. The first, which is of some importance, is that this is a matter of urgency. Unlike a matter of public importance, it is a matter on which the Senate must express an opinion and vote. The second point of elucidation is, I think, the reference to misbehaviour. I imagine that refers to section 24a of the Australian War Memorial Act, which sets out the reasons for termination of the Director's appointment. It reads:
(1) The Governor-General may terminate the appointment of the Director by reason of the misbehaviour or physical or mental incapacity of the Director.
(2) If the Director-
becomes bankrupt, applies to take the benefit of any law for the relief of bankrupt or insolvent debtors . . .
is absent from duty . . . engages in paid employment outside the duties of his office . . .
the Governor-General shall terminate the appointment of the Director.

I think that is the crux of the situation. In the minds of some people it is a reason for the Director to stay there because that provision was put there to give the War Memorial a degree of independence from the Government. In the minds of other people it may be something that should be changed, because without its being changed there is no way that anybody who wished to do so could get rid of Air Vice-Marshal Flemming from the position of Director.

This matter needs to be seen in proper proportion. Firstly, the Australian Democrats hold that it is of basic importance that any inquiry into the affairs of a citizen should be made in the most full and open way and in accordance with the principles of natural justice and that an appeal by a citizen for such an inquiry should be treated seriously. It is for that reason that we will be supporting this motion of urgency. However, we do not wish this to be construed in any way as meaning that we are taking sides in the current Australian War Memorial controversy, which the Australian Democrats believe is something which is deeply to be regretted. When I hear, as I do, some of the minutiae on the small matters that have been raised-they are small matters-in the debate so far, it gives me increasing cause for debate that a memorial which is a repository of honour in the opinion of millions of people in this country should become embroiled in this kind of controversy. The Democrats view is that that controversy ought to be ended as quickly as possible and in the most proper way possible.

We believe that the inquiry that has been mentioned in this motion has now become inevitable as a result of the behaviour of all concerned in this matter. It ought to have been foreseen that the Flemming matter when it first arose would turn out to be one of very considerable controversy. This is due, in no small measure, to Air Vice-Marshal Flemming's position and his high profile in the community. It is perfectly natural for him to feel that his reputation is involved and that there should not even be the appearance of a smear on him unless he can be given the fullest possible inquiry. That is understandable. Air Vice-Marshal Flemming has claimed with some reason that the Jones inquiry was not that fullest possible inquiry. That is not to imply that the Jones inquiry was anything less than fair-far from it. It was a lengthy inquiry and I think Mr Jones went to a great deal of trouble over it. That also is not a matter which I think need be canvassed in this debate. However, it is necessary to look briefly at some of Mr Jones's conclusions. He states-I think this covers most of the serious points that have been raised-on page 3 of his summary in the report:

I conclude that there are serious weaknesses in the management performance of the present Director. This represents a value judgment by me and is a considered view, arrived at in accordance with the Terms of Reference . . .

Nevertheless, the Director is entitled to respect from the Memorial staff at all levels for his authority and responsibilities. This has not always been forthcoming to the extent that it should have been, even in the face of differences or difficulties.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an interesting observation, isn't it?
—Yes, it is an interesting observation and something obviously must be drawn from it. Mr Jones goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude that in a number of cases, insufficient or misleading information has been given to the present Minister, but not so as to cause him serious embarrassment in the public arena.
Then-and I think this is final point of importance-he says:
I cannot conclude from this inquiry that there exists misbehaviour by the Director in terms of Section 24 (1) of the AWM Act as I understand that provision.
I quoted from that provision in the Act when I began my speech. It concerns the termination of employment. Mr Jones goes on:

I do not find a deliberate intention by the Director to transgress in carrying out his duties. Rather in some situations I have concluded that the Director has displayed a less than satisfactory level of competence and a carelessness in expression where the circumstances demanded truthfulness.

While that in itself is a fairly serious statement it is not a statement which, to my mind, is something on which one ought to damn any officer in any position. It is not a statement by Mr Jones which would indicate that he felt that the Director, in the exercise of his powers, was beyond smartening up his act-let us put it that way-if he felt that were necessary. I would have thought that those statements were virtually an admonition to the Director to smarten up his act. The Director-if one can believe what the Director said on the media today-said the he is back at his job and that he wants to do everything he possible can to reinstate his position where the Minister is concerned. The Minister's view of that is something which, of course, rests with himself. My own view is that it is always wise and normally charitable in this world to give people a second chance. Whether or not that is justifiable is purely a matter of speculation on my part. I do not believe that I know enough about the situation-and I am pretty sure that nobody in the Senate knows enough about the situation as it exists in that place with all the personality problems and conflicts that it obviously has-to make that basic conclusion.

I believe that it is totally unreasonable that all the affairs of the War Memorial should be dragged into a debate and that we should have a long series of personal attacks on individuals. One might argue perhaps that there is a need for those kinds of attacks and that they should be made, but if they are to be made, surely it is better that they be raised in a full and open judicial inquiry where I think they are much more likely to be presented in a more circumspect way than they would be in this place. With respect to this place-it is not a criticism of this place-it is a fact that utterances here are privileged and from time to time statements are made which could not be made in an inquiry of the type I suggest.

I notice reported in this morning's Press a letter from Air Vice-Marshal Flemming to Dame Beryl Beaurepaire, who chairs the Council of the Australian War Memorial. In the letter Air Vice-Marshal Flemming says that his early retirement would `result in the very controversy you are trying to avoid'. I must say that I share that sentiment. He said that he had grave misgivings about the manner in which the recently completed report by Mr Ken Jones had been conducted, and he claimed that he had been denied natural justice. In the letter he said:
I am convinced that the whole series of inquiries was initiated by the Minister's Office primarily on unreliable information supplied by a very small section of disgruntled memorial staff . . .

That, at the very least, is a challenging statement, the truth of which can only be justified in an inquiry which is very open and public and in which all issues are brought to bear. It is important to note that the Director has made that statement. If he has made that statement, and we take it at face value, he feels that he has nothing to fear from such an inquiry whatever the situation may be. It is, of course, an argument for such an inquiry to be conducted and I believe an argument for it virtually to be inevitable at this stage. It is interesting to note that the Sydney Morning Herald today also states:
The Government, by way of the council, was understood to have offered the Director $60,000 in compensation.

The Director, I understand, has refused that, saying that it is not regarded as a price for his self-respect. That, again, is a challenging statement, and one which, to my mind, makes it necessary for it to be taken further.

Important though this matter is in principle-and I think this is the next important point in assessing our attitude towards this matter-it is of small substantive content when considered in the framework of the enormous amount of important legislation this Parliament must get through before the end of the session. This includes legislation concerning the Australia Card, the merger of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation with the Special Broadcasting Service, taxation and the Human Rights Commission. Many of these are matters which affect the welfare and future of millions of people. All of them represent quite considerable changes in the legal framework, and it is important that they should be fully debated. Honourable senators know as well as I do that bringing on this motion of urgency today will probably reduce the time for consideration of that legislation. While I am not necessarily disputing the Opposition's right to bring this motion on, I would hate in future to see debates continued on this matter, where it was brought back again and again to the attention of the Senate as matters of this kind have in the past. Neither do we have the time now or in the future to do justice to any inquiry into this matter before us and, again, that-if there is strong feeling that the present situation is unsatisfactory-is a good reason for an open inquiry. The debate so far on this urgency motion tends to confirm that view.

We have had rather painful experiences in the past when this House has attempted to act as a kind of court. If one takes the trouble to look back through the centuries at the appalling records of other houses of parliament which have arrogated this function to themselves, one would find that they almost always ended in pain and hardship for the person thus judged and considerable trouble for the house of parliament that instigated it. One has only to consider the classic example of the trial in the House of Commons of Warren Hastings which dragged on for four years and which ended in the financial ruin and the destruction of the health of Hastings himself. That trial has rightly been condemned by history. It has been condemned because of the virtual inability of the parliamentary House at that time to conduct such an inquiry in a reasonable way-because of the nature of the House of Parliament.

Since any attempt to make this motion a debate on whether or not Air Vice-Marshal Flemming ought to resign, or on any of the matters concerned, is very much to be regretted in my opinion and I will not canvass them here. I say merely that I am aware that judicial inquiries are expensive. However, this one ought not to take too long, and it appears to us to have been made inevitable by the conduct of all concerned. The Democrats advise the Government to accept the necessity for such an open inquiry with a good grace, and to proceed with it as soon as possible. If it does not, the matter is likely to become a political football to be kicked around right up until the next election and beyond.

I know that the War Memorial Council is due to meet at 5 o'clock and that various statements on what it will do have been kicked around. I do not propose to canvass any of those and it is certainly not proper to anticipate its decisions-if any. But I cannot see that any decisions made by the Council at this stage can influence, or have any bearing on, the matter that is now before the Senate.

However, I repeat that to Air Vice-Marshal Flemming his own reputation is naturally a matter of importance, and in no way do I criticise him in that. My own view is that there is little point in carrying this matter any further in this Parliament. It is a matter for the Government to sort out. A mess has been created. It is an untidy and unsavoury mess as it stands, and it certainly needs tidying up. I hope that ensuing speakers in this debate can restrain themselves from entering into a publicly broadcast witch hunt under privilege. But since this matter has been brought forward we will vote for the motion and hope that the Government agrees to a full and open inquiry as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating, as a matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs either to accept the finding of the Jones inquiry that there was no `misbehaviour' by the Director of the Australian War Memorial or to institute a full and open inquiry to be conducted in accordance with the principles of natural justice as recommended to the Council by its solicitors.

The reason we have this motion of urgency before us is that a man's reputation has been destroyed in public. There is no evidence at all to justify the destruction of that man's character. Not only has his character been destroyed but also he has been asked repeatedly by the Australian War Memorial Council and by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) in public to resign. All of these moves have been made after four inquiries and when there has been no evidence at all to justify them. The latest inquiry into the Australian War Memorial was led by someone who was hand-picked by the Minister. The terms of reference for that inquiry were broad-ranging into all matters of the management and operation of the Australian War Memorial as they related to the Director. What was the finding? The finding can be summarised by page 3 of the report on which the inquirer said:
I cannot conclude from this Inquiry that there exists misbehaviour by the Director in the terms of section 24 (1) of the Australian War Memorial Act as I understand that provision.

Senator Gietzelt, in his speech in his own defence, made a whole lot of nitpicking allegations against the Director. They principally related to where he claimed he had been misinformed. The paragraph before the one in which the inquirer, Mr Jones, says that he cannot conclude that there exists misbehaviour by the Director reads:
I conclude that in a number of cases insufficient or misleading information has been given to the present Minister . . .
The important qualification, which Senator Gietzelt has never referred to, is that Mr Jones then says:
. . . but not so as to cause him serious embarrassment in the public arena.

Yet we have had this persistent, sustained and vicious character assassination of a great Australian. We in the Senate want the Minister to accept the findings of his hand-picked inquirer, Mr Jones, and live by the umpire's decision or let us have a full and open inquiry into the actions of Air Vice-Marshal Flemming. The Parliament, and above all the Senate, is the last repository of justice in this country. It is the last court of appeal. If Senator Gietzelt does not move to set up that full and open inquiry, we may well do so in the Senate.

Not only has Air Vice-Marshal Flemming lost his reputation but also he has been asked to resign, both by the Minister and by the Council. He has been publicly instructed by both of them to resign, yet he has broken no laws at all. There is no authority to demand his resignation. This man has not had a fair go. Justice has not been done, let alone been seen to be done. We have had a whole lot of highly irregular actions by the Minister, reminiscent of the summary trial and execution mentality of a Third World country. Before I get on to those matters I want to talk a little about the history of the Australian War Memorial. It is our national memorial to those who died in war and it is a repository of Australian military history. Kenneth Clark, or Lord Clark as he was when he died, an expert on museums and culture, said that the Australian War Memorial was the finest of its type in the world. The Australian War Memorial attracts the biggest crowds in Australia of any public institution. It has an international reputation. It is an institution of which all Australians are proud. It exists for the benefit of all of us. It is set up under a special Act to be independent and non-political. It is governed by a Council which has wide and almost total powers. Its chief executive is a director. I quote from the Australian War Memorial Act regarding the powers of the Director. Section 20 (2) states:
The Director is the chief executive officer of the Australian War Memorial and shall, subject to and in accordance with the general conditions of the Council, manage the affairs of the Memorial.

Section 24 states that the Governor-General may terminate the appointment of the Director if he becomes bankrupt, is absent from duty without leave of absence for 14 consecutive days or 28 days in any 12 months or engages in paid employment outside the duties of his office. Air Vice-Marshal Flemming fills none of the conditions in section 24 for his resignation to be asked for in public.

The War Memorial was always administered by whichever portfolio dealt with museums in general. In the previous Parliament Mr Cohen, as Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, was the Minister responsible for the Australian War Memorial. Senator Gietzelt wanted the Australian War Memorial in his portfolio and had it transferred to the Department of Veterans' Affairs. When the museum was set up it was never intended that it should be under the Department of Veterans' Affairs. But this Government has no respect for the feelings of the old diggers. For the first time ever it cut Defence Force retirement benefits. The Government is talking about including veterans, now the responsibility of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, with the age pensioners under the Department of Social Security, so one could not expect it to be concerned about the niceties of the preservation of the independence of the Australian War Memorial.

Let us consider some of Senator Gietzelt's actions. They are not the actions of a fair and reasonable man. There was the failure to re- appoint a great Australian, Admiral Sir Anthony Synnot, who was the first Chairman of the Board not to get a second term. There was the way Senator Gietzelt stacked the Council with his left wing mates and the way he fired Des Corcoran, as Senator Lewis instanced. There is the way the cronies in his office talk to their cronies in the War Memorial. There is the way he politicised the Australian War Memorial by giving the first account of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill there. It has been the first time any Bill relating to veterans has been presented in the Australian War Memorial. Senator Gietzelt politicised the War Memorial that way.

We have had all these attacks on the Director, Air Vice-Marshal Flemming, in public and in advance of any inquiries. The Minister's attacks after the inquiry are one thing, but his attacks before the findings were released is inexcusable. These are not the actions of a fair and reason- able man. Whom are we talking about? We are talking about Air Vice-Marshal Flemming-Officer of the Order of Australia, member of the Order of Australia, Distinguished Flying Cross, United States Air Medal, Mentioned in Despatches-a man who for 40 years has served his country as a fighter pilot and as a senior officer in the Royal Australian Air Force, in the Pacific and in Korea. He flew in the first strike against the communists in Korea. He ended up as chief of the Air Force development section. For 40 years this man put his life on the line for the people of Australia. He was ready to die on orders for his political and military masters. He came through 40 years with an absolutely unblemished record-until he met with Senator Gietzelt.

What have been his actions since he has been Director of the War Memorial? He has had a brilliant record. It is over 30 years since I first visited the Australian War Memorial and I have kept a constant interest in it. At present the Australian War Memorial is functioning at its highest ever level. Air Vice-Marshal Flemming is a man of quick intelligence. He is someone who wants quick results. That is a great crime in a town like this where nothing happens, or happens at a glacial pace. Let us consider the growth in the budget of the War Memorial, the number of its staff, which has gone from 156 to over 200 since he became Director, the new galleries, the revitalisation of the whole place. This man is a visionary, hard-working, intelligent achiever. But he has the personality of a typical fighter pilot. He wants things quickly and he wants them now. He wants results. He does not want red tape. That is anathema to the bureaucracy. Yet we have the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) telling us that he is going to reform the Australian Public Service. Why? To get rid of red tape. We have the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) telling us that the Opposition will reform the Public Service in a couple of months time when we get into government. Why? To get rid of red tape so that the bureaucracy can do things for the people of Australia.

This man is not getting a fair go. He was attacked repeatedly by Senator Gietzelt. He was the subject of a cowardly attack when he was sick in bed for three days. At a hearing of the Estimates Committee Senator Gietzelt tore him apart under parliamentary privilege. He went through the business of putting in an acting director from his Department. The Deputy Director of the War Memorial was not asked to relieve for the three days; the Acting Director was appointed from Senator Gietzelt's Department. In this town that is tantamount to saying that a gross scandal is going on, that we have a Watergate at the War Memorial. Senator Gietzelt knew that when he appointed that man as Acting Director. So much for the actions of the Minister, but what of the Council?

The Council is the governing body of the War Memorial. When one runs anything a responsibility goes with that command. One has a responsibility to look after the welfare of people beneath one. If serious allegations are made they must be inquired into. If there is no substance to them the person against whom the allegations were made must be supported. What did the Council of the War Memorial do? Its members did not make any inquiries until they were forced to. Having found after inquiry that the person in question was clear, they failed to support him and even worse they asked him to resign-without reason. The Council has written twice to Air Vice-Marshal Flemming saying that it wants him to leave for the good of the Australian War Memorial.

Members of the Council lack moral fibre. Their actions are as contemptible as those of the Minister. How must people lying in their graves feel when they know that at the War Memorial, their memorial, they have custodians such as the present Council members looking after their interests? An article from the Age, which was drawn to my attention before lunch, alleges:

The council now is expected to look at ways of abolishing the director's position. Sources said last night that Dame Beryl was likely to write to the leaders of all political parties asking that the Australian War Memorial Act be amended.

She can save her time in writing to me. One could almost be excused for wondering why we need to change the legislation when the Council at present is just a puppet of Senator Gietzelt. Furthermore, this action flies in the face of the findings of the Minister's inquiry. The Jones Inquiry into the Australian War Memorial specifically found that there was no need to alter the legislation.

Coming back to the Jones Inquiry, justice was not done there. Unsubstantiated allegations and rumours were put to the inquiry and the accused was denied any opportunity of having legal representation before that body, despite the fact that his solicitor asked for it and that a former head of the Attorney-General's Department, Sir Clarrie Harders, another very great Australian who, after a lifetime in the Public Service, knows the bureaucracy backwards and how inquiries are conducted and who has a position of eminence in the legal profession, said: `Your client has the right, under the terms of reference as they stand, to be present in the circumstances mentioned and to question witnesses'. On top of those two opinions, the War Memorial's own legal adviser said: `Air Vice-Marshal Flemming should be present when his accusers are slandering him and he should have the right to legal representation'.

This is why we are very concerned. If this matter is to be decided by slander and innuendo, we want to know whether there is a personal element to this attack. Is there a political element? Are some people in the War Memorial feeling guilty after the Arthur Young audit report into their actions in the research and publications section? We on this side of the chamber are quite prepared to accept the findings of any open inquiry. We will obey the umpire's decisions. Those opposite should set up that inquiry if they will not live by the findings of the first one. The reputation of a very great Australian has been taken away. While reputations might not mean much to the Australian Labor Party, that is the gravest of all charges. I was taught as a school boy, and as Shakespeare said:
Who steals my purse, steals trash . . . But he that filches from me my good name, Robs me of that which not enriches him, And makes me poor indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I often do not agree with Senator Mason but when he called for a reasonable and sensible level of debate on this issue I hoped that this would happen. Of course, it has not happened. I suppose that one would not expect it to happen with Senator MacGibbon. I accept everything Senator MacGibbon has said about the fine war record of Air Vice-Marshal Flemming. I accept the fact that he was willing to fight and die for his country, and I respect him for it. I point out that so was the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt willing to do that. I point out also that both those gentlemen have a much more distinguished war record than does the previous speaker.
—And yourself.

—I make no claim for mine. I ask Senator MacGibbon to tell us at some time for whom and where he served overseas and whom he serves now. I will deal with some of the points put forward by Senator MacGibbon because it is essential to do so. The first thing he said was that the Australian War Memorial was transferred to Senator Gietzelt and his Department because Senator Gietzelt wanted it. All I can say is that anyone who was here at that time who believes that will believe anything. The repeated request that the War Memorial be transferred to the Department of Veterans' Affairs was made by the representatives of the veterans, the Returned Services League. That request had been made year after year. Anyone who believes that Senator Gietzelt wanted the job does not know the history and record of what happened.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, as well as condemning the Minister-we on this side cop that and usually do not ask for it to be withdrawn as do those on the other side-Senator MacGibbon condemned the whole Council of the War Memorial, including Dame Beryl Beaurepaire. I know that Senator Walters believes that Dame Beryl is a socialist and that in the past Senator Walters has said that Dame Beryl is a socialist, but no one else believes that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I know that Senator Grimes has said in the past that he likes saying things off the top of his head, but I deny that I have ever said that. He knows that I have never said that Dame Beryl Beaurepaire is a socialist. In his typical way, he is telling fibs.
—Order! That is not a point of order, Senator Walters. You may make a personal explanation later.

—Senator Walters may make a personal explanation later, but I just remind her of a meeting that was held in Hobart some years ago. Many people present will remember the things that Senator Walters said about Dame Beryl Beaurepaire. However, I accept that that is irrelevant. Let us not fool about that. Senator MacGibbon condemned both the Minister and, to a considerable extent, the Council. He talked about Mr Jones being the choice of the Minister to conduct the Inquiry when he was the choice of the Council. The honourable senator said that what was needed was justice, then, of all things, he threatened that unless he and his colleagues get what they want they will have an inquiry here in which the Senate will be judge, jury and sentencer and everything else.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some calmer words written about this matter, which I notice that no one on the other side has quoted. The words in the editorial of the Canberra Times this morning are not bad words. It points out, very correctly:

. . . the memorial is not and should not be a party-political thing, it is quite obvious that government has an interest in its proper management, in the efficiency and effectiveness of its operations and its meeting, and being seen to meet, minimum accounting and accountability requirements. Any government which ignored signs that all was not well, or that public funds were not . . . effectively spent, would be derelict in its duty and betraying ideals that the memorial itself stands for.

As has been pointed out, this Parliament attempted to have the administration of the War Memorial put at arm's length from politics by setting up a council of distinguished people to run it. As so often happens, and I have been critical in the past of this sort of procedure, in attempting to push away from the Parliament and the Government responsibility for an organisation such as the War Memorial, the legislation makes it very difficult to get rid of someone even if the Council wants to get rid of that person-whether or not the Government wants to get rid of that person-if the proper standards of efficiency and effectiveness of operations and the proper standards of accounting and accountability are not being met.

As Senator Gietzelt has said and as the newspapers have said, we have had considerable disquiet about what has been happening at the War Memorial in recent times. We have had the O'Connor report, the Auditor-General's report-considerably critical-the Arthur Young report and the Jones report. No one here could suggest that these reports have come up with the most satisfactory findings for the War Memorial. The Jones report finds that Air Vice-Marshal Flemming `has displayed a less than satisfactory level of competence and a carelessness in expression where the circumstances demanded truthfulness'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are selectively quoting, like Senator Gietzelt.
—I ask Senator Lewis to wait a minute. Mr Jones stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not find a deliberate intention by the Director to transgress in carrying out his duties.

I accept that. Whose job is it then, given by this Parliament, to make decisions about the efficient operating of the War Memorial arising out of that report? Surely it is the job of the War Memorial Council. The Council wants to do that job. It has written to the leaders of all the political parties suggesting that it wants to get on with that job in an atmosphere without the political nonsense, political rhetoric and personal attacks which have been going on here this afternoon. The Opposition has deliberately chosen-it is its choice-to ignore the Council's reasonable request to be able to make its decision this afternoon having considered the report and its requests to Air Vice-Marshal Flemming and any facts that may further arise.

What has happened in this place? Quite clearly for party political reasons-one need hear only the speech of Senator MacGibbon to realise that-the Opposition has ignored the operations of the Council and its requests and has decided that it is urgent on Monday to influence and subvert the actions of the Council. It cannot wait until tonight. Maybe it is fair enough for the Opposition to want to do that but I do not believe it is a sensible thing to do. The Council knows what is going on at the Memorial. It has reports of members of the staff and the reports of previous inquiries. I am the last to get up here and to say that I know all the details on this matter. I hope Senator MacGibbon does not think he does. I hope Senator Lewis does not think he does either, although I suspect that Senator Lewis knows a little more than Senator MacGibbon. That is why he relied a little more on facts and a little less on rhetoric. The Council has to meet further to consider its difficult decision in the light of all the facts. Yet we conduct a debate this afternoon asking for yet another judicial inquiry, for heaven's sake.

TALK.START.PARA: —Allowing justice.

—In view of the things that Senator Walters and some of her colleagues have said about a person who is recently deceased in this country, for her to talk about justice, for her even to mention the word `justice', is the greatest example of hypocrisy I have ever heard. What she wants is what she sees as justice for her friends and she will quite happily kick people to death and bury them. She ought to be ashamed of herself. She is a disgrace to the human race. I do not want that spy in front of her getting up and saying anything different.

SPEECH.PARA: What are the Opposition's motives in seeking another inquiry? It is trying to prevent the Australian War Memorial Council from doing its job and performing its statutory functions as given by this Parliament, statutory functions which are very difficult to perform in view of the way in which the legislation is written. I suppose the Opposition is trying to create further political fuss, to continue to have the War Memorial made a political football, when, as the Canberra Times in its very sensible editorial said, that is the last thing it ought to do. It is trying to keep pushing this issue as a political issue because all the other issues it has pushed have failed. All I can say is that people outside this city have very little interest in what is happening and certainly do not consider this to be the greatest political issue of the day. I think they will be extremely surprised to find that the Opposition in the Senate on this day, with all the hoo-ha it is making about other issues outside, should pick this issue to debate as a matter of urgency on Monday, 17 November, when this afternoon the Council this Parliament has charged with looking after the War Memorial is meeting to consider the same issue. The Chairperson of the Council is not by any means a Labor Party appointee or sympathiser. The majority of members of the Council certainly are not.

I suppose I could do what has been done this afternoon and go through the reports, particularly the claims by the Director that he had been denied natural justice, the claims that he could not answer his accusations even though page 39 of the report states that he was offered the opportunity to respond to specific allegations made by the staff and he actually refused to do so. He refused to do so despite the fact that the inquirer wanted him to do so and asked him to do so. We know that there is considerable concern by the very large staff of the War Memorial-not only Air Vice-Marshal Flemming-for their future if they question in any way the actions of the Air Vice-Marshal. I suggest that has been one of the problems. That is another side of the can do mentality that Senator MacGibbon finds so attractive-if one cannot do it one kicks whoever gets in one's way. A series of inquiries have looked at the situation. The Council does not deserve the abuse it received from Senator MacGibbon this afternoon. It deserves the right to have its meeting and to sort out what should happen in this case. Instead of that, it will have to do so following the debating of an urgency motion, of all things, brought up in this place this afternoon asking for yet another judicial inquiry.

The question is not the great war record of Air Vice-Marshal Flemming; no one questions that. The question is not his willingness to serve this country. No one questions that, any more than one questions Senator Gietzelt's willingness to do that. The question is Air Vice-Marshal Flemming's capacity as the managing director, if you like, of the War Memorial, what has happened since he became Director of the War Memorial, the competence he has shown, and the effectiveness of his operations there. That is a matter that certainly should still be judged by the Council and which later can be judged by this Parliament; but to suggest that it should be subject to yet another judicial inquiry, and if that does not happen, of all things, a politically motivated Senate select committee, I think is the height of lunacy. I am amazed that it should be suggested in view of the recent history of such witch hunts in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I have tried to keep this debate on a fair level and I shall continue to do so but I must respond to Senator Grimes's reference to another Senate committee of inquiry in relation to a person recently deceased. I point out to Senator Grimes that in that case this Senate established a second hearing just so that the particular person concerned could have the same principles of natural justice as Air Vice-Marshal Flemming is seeking in this case. That is exactly what Air Vice-Marshal Flemming is seeking. If the Minister does not want to accept the advice of Mr Jones, it behoves him to ensure that Air Vice-Marshal Flemming is given access to the same principle of natural justice as this Senate gave to the particular deceased person whom Senator Grimes referred to.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition parties are not calling for a judicial inquiry; we are simply pointing out that the Minister has created an impasse-a terrible situation for the Australian War Memorial Council-because he does not accept the findings of Mr Jones. Those findings certainly do not put Air Vice-Marshal Flemming in any sort of blameless position. I openly acknowledge that the findings make it clear that Air Vice-Marshal Flemming is responsible for some misleading information which has been given to the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't that serious?

—I agree with Senator Gietzelt that, yes, it is serious. If I were the Minister I would be concerned about it, but I must say that I would have taken action about this matter a lot earlier than he took action. The report of Mr Jones goes on to say that although that information may have been misleading, it was not so as to cause the Minister serious embarrassment in the public arena. I draw Senator Gietzelt's attention to the fact that he has not been subject to any action in this chamber in relation to what he tells us was misleading information. I think that is what Mr Jones is talking about. The very important thing which Senator Gietzelt refuses to face up to is that, even if he does not accept this report, Mr Jones says:

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot conclude from this Inquiry--
and I will be fair, I will not be selective in what I read out from this paragraph--

that there exists misbehaviour by the Director in the terms of Section 24 (1) of the AWM Act as I understand that provision. I do not find a deliberate intention by the Director to transgress in carrying out his duties. Rather in some situations I have concluded that the Director has displayed a less than satisfactory level of competence and a carelessness in expression where the circumstances demanded truthfulness.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does that mean?
—What it means is `a carelessness in expression'. He is not a trained public servant who responds to your questions in the way that a trained public servant might be prepared to respond.
—By not responding.

—As Senator Withers says, more often than not by not responding, or by having two bob each way. What he did was tell the Minister what he thought the situation was at the time. As has been pointed out, on one occasion when there was not legal ownership of an aircraft but equitable ownership of the aircraft, he said: `We own the aircraft'. He misled the Minister by not pointing out that it was only equitable ownership of the aircraft. As has been indicated, it really is nitpicking by the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: That result of this very extensive and thorough investigation was that Mr Jones not only made these findings but also went on to point out to the Council how the problem could be resolved. He pointed out the legislative changes that had been suggested to him, whether he supported them or not, and he pointed out the steps the Council could take to resolve its dilemma. But the Minister has refused to accept the report. The Minister has said that he must win. The Minister has said to the Council: `Get the Director to resign. Offer him $60,000 and get him to resign.' If the Minister had adopted a reasonable approach to this matter it may well have been that Air Vice-Marshal Flemming, for the sake of harmony, would have resigned a year before his contract expired. I do not know whether he would have or not. But how could the Minister possibly expect him to do so when, in the security of this chamber, he keeps bucketing him at every opportunity.
