That is what has made the negotiations absolutely impossible-the Minister's behaviour. The Minister is trying to have it every way. He set up the inquiry and he required the Council to conduct the inquiry. He told the Council what its terms of reference were. He has had his report and now he says--

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not true; the Council drew up the terms of reference.

—The Minister wrote the Council a letter in which he told it, at great length and in great detail, precisely what he wanted inquired into. So that fixes that. The Minister wanted the inquiry and he has had the inquiry, but he is now not prepared to accept the report. He now wants Air Vice-Marshal Flemming to resign, but at the same time he continues to bucket him under the privilege of this Parliament. The Minister wants it all ways. He has left everyone in a hopeless dilemma and as I said in the motion of urgency, as a result he is leading everyone to a situation where the only possible result will be to have some sort of full and open inquiry, to be conducted in accordance with the principles of natural justice, which will cost everyone many, many thousands of dollars and which would have been unnecessary if the Minister had adopted a reasonable approach to the report of Mr Jones. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the question be now put.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President-
—There will be no debate on that motion.
—I do not want to debate that; I just want to table some documents.
—You may table those documents before the question is put.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Gietzelt

TALK.START.PARA: —I table five letters relating to negotiations on the early retirement of Air Vice-Marshal Flemming.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the motion (Senator Lewis's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I commend the report to the Senate. It is particularly strong in excellent sentiments about the development of Australian industry. It has an admirable layout and its content is very good, if one reads it in isolation from what the Government is actually doing. The information about the aims of the Department, its structure and programs is very well set out. In fact, within the Government's operations, I would say that it is a bastion of virtue in a den of iniquity.

Australia has been in the midst of a trade crisis for the last 18 months. This Department must be at the cutting edge in getting us out of that crisis. The Government was rather slow to acknowledge and react to the problems of our large trade deficit. But the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, and his Department have been implementing policies which offer us some hope of being able to pull out of the problems. The introduction to the report states:

Australia needs to shift economic resources into the traded goods and services sectors. The substantial depreciation of the Australian dollar in response to our current account weakness provides an important opportunity.

I believe that the Department has been trying to take advantage of this situation through operations such as the 150 per cent tax allowance, the grants for industrial research and development and training schemes such as the national industry extension service-the NIES scheme-which it is carrying out in conjunction with the States. The Department, at page 15 of the report, states that its main resource is its staff, and that it is developing an industrial democracy plan, embracing the equal employment opportunity program. This, of course, is what all departments are expected to do. But the Department states that it is well advanced in this area, and I congratulate it.

However, the main crunch of the report comes at page 52, which mentions the type of environment in which the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce is operating. We are operating in an area in which business taxation is being increased. I note with some amusement that the tax measures which are mentioned at page 52 of the report do not include the fringe benefits tax. They do include the capital gains and the non-pecuniary benefits tax. The reduction of personal income tax and the accelerated depreciation provisions are mentioned. If one is to believe the report, everything in industry is completely rosy and the Government is offering a stable business environment. I do not believe that that is the case. The Department is obviously trying to provide it, but I do not think it is being helped by government.

I commend the report as excellent reading. The graphs and the material are very informative about what is happening to Australian industry. In fact, it is not a happy picture when one looks at the graphs at the back of the document. Despite the efforts of the Department, which are laudable, the end result for our business is not very vast investments in new developments. In the main, investment of foreign money seems to be going into takeover activities, and I deplore this development.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the covering letter with the annual report of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, the Secretary to the Department said to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button):

SPEECH.PARA: This year's report has been written around the theme `managing change'. The theme reflects the significant changes this year in Australia's economic circumstances and the corresponding need for urgency in the Department's efforts to encourage the international competitiveness, export orientation and innovativeness of Australian manufacturing and service industries.

It is now trite to say that Australia must export more and more manufacturing and technology products. Exports of mining and agricultural goods have served Australia well, and still do so, but clearly they are no longer sufficient to establish the balance of trade in this country's favour. Claims are made that exports of services, manufactured goods and technology will blossom if they are produced cheaply enough. Again and again the theme is taken up in this chamber that government should ensure that wages are low, that hours are long and that taxation on industry is at a minimum. Such claims-they may be made later in this debate-are simply wrong and quite simplistic. The Minister for Science, Mr Barry Jones, has demonstrated this again and again in the most lucid of fashions. If low wages and long hours were all that were needed for successful manufacture and technology, countries such as Bangladesh and other Third World countries ought to be exporting myriad manufactured goods and services, but they are not. If high wages and short hours prohibited the export of goods and made them too dear, Sweden, which has a 32-hour working week and much higher wages than Australia, would not be successful, yet it is one of the most successful exporting countries in the world. The reason for that is that its traditions, culture and practices over many years have been oriented towards the export of the sorts of goods that presently find favour in world markets.

I make the point at this stage that the sort of analysis often made in this chamber and elsewhere is that the good times will come if government simply reduces taxes on business and as a consequence throws the tax burden on to the workers of this community. To take the burden of taxes properly paid by business and place it on workers is not only unfair but also simply the wrong analysis of the sorts of problems we face.

Solving Australia's problems depends more upon turning around the world's perception of what Australia produces and the quality of those products than it does upon attempts to reduce the cost of producing the sorts of goods on which the world relies. It is not as though Australia has a poor reputation for manufactured goods. The problem is that Australia has no reputation, by and large, for manufactured goods. The solution is to look to the area where we can establish a reputation, to increase the sorts of things that will lead to the production of good quality goods, goods that people want to buy, and that does not necessarily mean the cheapest of goods. To equate cheapness of goods with the solution to our problems is short-sighted. Fortunately, this report goes into the sorts of questions I have raised. Hopefully, honourable senators will cease crying out for lower wages, shorter hours and increased burdens upon the people who work and will look more to finding real solutions to the problems in terms of improving the quality of goods that we manufacture.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to say a couple of things on the annual report of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce which I have not yet had a chance to read in full. If one were to look at the work of the departments of the Commonwealth it would have to be said that the work of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce has probably brought forth the least criticism from the Opposition in that it thinks that a number of the initiatives being taken by the Department and a number of the policies-indeed, the general direction of policy which is being pursued under the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button)-is correct. In other words, we think that the Government is more correct in its actions in this area than it is in most others. Our fundamental criticism of the Government's approach to industry policy relates not to the work of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce but rather to the failure of the Government to bring in other policies which would make the policies of this Department work better. In particular, we have been critical of the Government's failure to come to grips with what we see as the failures of the taxation system and the labour market to adapt in a way which is necessary if we are to have a modern manufacturing economy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition would agree with the comment in the introduction to the report that achieving substantial and sustainable progress will depend on increasing business investment. To get that increased investment we believe that it is necessary for the Government to change some of its policies in other areas. It cannot persist with macroeconomic policies which maintain interest rates in Australia at such extraordinarily high levels and expect, at the same time, that there will be substantial investment in industry. We see an odd imbalance between what the Government is seeking to do through this Department and what it is seeking to do through other departments, including the Department of the Treasury. We are very critical of the fact that the logic which should be applied to the policies which are being promoted by Senator Button is not being applied by the Government.

To the extent that we have qualms about the approach of the Department, it would be in the suggestion that the Government is there as an agent for managing change. I think that expression was used by the head of the Department in his letter to Senator Button accompanying this report. The question the Opposition would raise is the extent to which the Department should be managing change as against facilitating the changes which are certainly necessary. To become a bit specific, if we look at the approach which the Minister adopted and which the Department, on behalf of the Minister, facilitated in the development of the heavy engineering package we see an example of some of the concerns which the Opposition feels. There is no doubt that the Department, and indeed the Minister, can play a very important role in educating a particular industry sector to the need for change. The sorts of discussions which were facilitated by the Minister and in which the Department participated, and which led to the acceptance by the industry of the need to make changes, is a very constructive process. The fact that there needed to be discussions about improving productivity, growth through investment and new capital equipment and technologies does make one wonder what in the world management in these industries and the labour unions involved were thinking about if that was not apparent to them. However, it seems to have been necessary to engage in this process of discussion to develop thinking in this area. Our concern is not that process; our concern is that, at the end of the day when the package is announced, we find there are some quite bureaucratic elements to the package.

We are told in this report that access to the program of assistance will be conditional on participating heavy engineering establishments demonstrating that they and relevant unions have agreed to significant positive changes in work practices. In other words, government assistance, taxpayer assistance, will be provided as long as the employers and the unions have agreed to changes in work practices. The point that concerns us is that this is a very long route to the point which has to be reached where employers and employees directly involved in an enterprise devote themselves to removing any restrictive work practices which are impeding the efficiency of that business. The intrusion of committees, and sets of rules which will be drawn up by committees, into this process shows a lack of understanding about the urgency of the task facing Australia if we are to meet the very heavy international competition we face in this and other areas. I believe that the Department is making a very useful contribution to the development of industry in Australia. There is no more vital or difficult task. My quarrel would be that it needs to be done in a way which acknowledges more the urgency of the problems that we face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the annual report of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. Senator Button, who is the Minister in charge of this Department, is a very energetic and effective Minister. I have congratulated him in this place previously on his initiative in the steel industry in particular and, to a lesser degree, his initiative in respect of the car plan. Having said that, I point out that Australia faces a critical problem. Australia is essentially a Third World country in that only something like 30 per cent of our exports are manufactured goods whereas, by contrast, the manufactured goods of most Western countries make up something like 80 per cent of their exports. We have an enormous gap to make up, and we are not going to lift our performance, we are not going to get out of the Third World status, unless we dramatically, quickly and urgently reform our manufacturing industries.

SPEECH.PARA: My criticism of this report is that it does not contain any real strategy to get industries across the broad spectrum of manufacturing in this country internationally competitive. There is no real Government initiative which says: `We have to have our industries export orientated, we have to get them to a stage where they can be as efficient as any industries in the world and look on the whole world as their market'. The Government could adopt some initiatives simply and readily and at very little expense. For instance, employees could be involved in industry, and there is no doubt that employee share ownership is a very important part of that initiative. If we can give employees a slice of the action, if they can be part of and have an equity in an organisation, of course they will be more involved.

The Government is paying out money to various industries in the form of bounties. Why could not the Government make those bounty payments to specific industries conditional upon these companies offering, say, 8 per cent of their capital for purchase by their employees? That would not cost the Government anything. It would just be a condition of the Government paying a bounty to specific industries. If this were done, we would be able to get a very important initiative off the ground without any cost to the Government.

Something has to be done as a matter of urgency in industry. It is not that this requires greater effort by Senator Button, but I am afraid that we have to see more action in critical areas. A fundamental criticism I make relates to the great imbalance in what the Government is paying to industries in the form of bounty. I notice that the heavy engineering industry is going to receive $269,000 whereas the bounty for ships is something like $38m. One should look at these various payments-I could give other examples-to see whether we are getting value for money on the basis of one criterion only, and that is the export potential of those industries. If the Government assesses its financial assistance to industry on the basis of whether the assistance will increase the export ability of those industries, the money the Government is spending will be well invested.

Briefly, a lot has been done by Senator Button, and I do not criticise him. However, an enormous amount still has to be done. We have to have a rifle shot approach. We have to select carefully the industries the Government assists on the basis of their export earning potential. As I say, we have to direct the assistance to those areas with rifle shot accuracy. We will not get our industries efficient until we involve employees. Let the Government do something about employee share ownership now. It could tie such a scheme to grants to industries and such an initiative would cost it nothing at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the sectorial objectives stated in the annual report of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce might be very admirable and laudable, there is really nothing in the report that relates to the performance of the Department of how effectively the objectives that have been set for the Department are being met. The report is strong on policy issues and it is critical of the performance of industry. Yet there is no self-analysis in this document as to how well the Department is performing in relation to achieving its own objectives. So what is good for the goose should also be good for the gander. I think it is about time that a little self-analysis was undertaken by government departments and instrumentalities so that we can see how well they are performing. What are the yardsticks? There is none. What are the performance measurements? There is none.

SPEECH.PARA: The report is great on platitudes-there are plenty of them. The report says that we must export more. I remind the Senate that there is fear and anger in the community about a lack of Government action to get confidence back into the country. We will not get confidence back into the country by taking away jobs in the textile industry. We have to offer carrots. We have to offer some sort of incentives and not just take jobs away from people in decentralised areas. Anti-business activity permeates everything the Government does nowadays. We are seeing more regulation, more fringe benefits taxes and more attacks on small business, but the Government is not doing enough to get business overheads down. If business overheads are being increased, how can industry prosper and expand? With an inflation rate higher than that of our domestic trading partners, how can we continue to export in the long term, bearing in mind that the effects of devaluation will be very short?

I remind the Senate that business in Australia is really very small in a world of large businesses. Business does not mind what the rules are, so long as everybody abides by them and so long as they are clear. It does not mind so long as there are long term objectives and we do not have the U-turns on which the Australian Labor Party has been so strong. One of the features of the Labor Party Administration has been the corruption of public standards. This has been one of the worst features of its reign.

I remind honourable senators that an Austrade exhibition is being shown today in King's Hall. The exhibition is quite good and it urges Australians to be more conscious of the need to export. In fact, appropriately displayed on one side of the exhibition is a list of the achievements of Austrade-what it is trying to achieve and what it is doing to help export industries. I acknowledge that Austrade has made a significant contribution in this respect. At the head of one list is railway equipment. I remind the Senate of the sad story of the involvement of Australian National Industries Ltd in a Hong Kong contract. That contract worth $70m, in which Austrade says it has played a significant part, is at risk because of union thuggery. The Government is not prepared to tackle head on this major problem-a problem which will escalate into the loss of 500 jobs in Victoria. The Government plays the platitudes but it avoids the hard issues involved in trying to overcome one or two unions which are threatening this valuable contract and the jobs of Australians. What has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) had to say? He has stated that Australia can no longer afford strikes if it is to be a successful manufacturing exporter. What is the Minister doing in relation to his own State, the threat of the loss of jobs and the loss of this important contract? This matter is more important than just putting up platitudes in King's Hall. I believe that this country can no longer afford this sort of luxury if it is going to be a successful manufacturing exporter. We just cannot afford the luxury of sitting here and doing nothing about the thuggery that is going on in respect of ANI.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sheil) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS GENERAL ASSEMBLY: FORTIETH SESSION 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Australian Delegation to the United Nations is to be complimented on the arduous task it undertakes of dotting i's and crossing t's on numerous resolutions and debates in the United Nations forum, particularly when those votes reflect a growing sense of independence and a realisation that Australian interests need to be served, in concert with the interests of our neighbours in this region, rather than merely following the interests of others.

I would like to comment briefly on the nuclear and disarmament issues mentioned in the 1985 report, particularly in relation to resolutions calling for a comprehensive test ban. The Australia-New Zealand resolution was accepted in the 1985 report, but I question Australia's abstention from the first of two Mexican resolutions which called for the comprehensive test ban and a moratorium in the meantime while that test ban is put in place. Australians who understand the urgency for a comprehensive test ban and who support the Government's hard work toward that end cannot understand the Government's negative attitude towards a moratorium. The Soviet moratorium has now been in place since 6 August 1985 and at the time this resolution was made in October last year it had been in place for a couple of months. I think the Soviets' good intentions had already been proved to some extent. That moratorium has now been extended three times. I believe Australia should be using its influence on the United States in whatever way possible to ensure that the United States joins in the moratorium that has been put in place by the Soviets. Unfortunately the United States seems to be not the least bit interested in a comprehensive test ban because of its adherence to the strategic defence initiative, which will require an unprecedented number of nuclear tests. The SDI, which has also been dubbed `a stupid damned idea' or `Self-destruction Incorporated', will require an enormous number of nuclear tests, the like of which we have not yet seen in this nuclear age.

The Australian delegation has changed its position very slightly in the current session of the United Nations by one jot. Last week it supported the Mexican resolution as far as the comprehensive test ban part was concerned, but recorded a reservation calling for all States to join in the Soviet moratorium. In this respect I find the Australian delegation's performance wanting. An immediate moratorium on nuclear testing would be a clear demonstration of good intentions. This is sadly lacking on the part of the United States and, of course, on the part of France, which is as intransigent as ever where nuclear testing is concerned. Is Australia happy to be seen to be acquiescing to those countries who continue nuclear testing programs? That is how our behaviour is being interpreted. We are not using every opportunity that we might in putting a stop to the wasteful and immoral programs of nuclear testing. This lack of political guts is extremely disappointing.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time allotted under Sessional Orders for the consideration of Govern- ment Papers has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts I present a progress report on the Committee's inquiry into the education of gifted and talented children. I seek leave to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Honourable senators will recall that this matter was referred to the Standing Committee on 17 October last year. The Committee advertised for submissions in the national Press at the end of October 1985. It also wrote to selected organisations involved in the education of the gifted and asked for submissions. To date, 166 submissions and 33 Committee documents have been received. These include submissions from all State governments and the Commonwealth Government. Public hearings have now been held in all mainland State capital cities. The Committee intends to conclude its program of public hearings in Hobart on 16 December. The Committee is grateful to all those who have made submissions or given oral evidence. On behalf of the Committee I should also thank the teachers and students of the six schools the Committee has visited in the course of the inquiry.

Although the Committee has now almost completed its program of hearings and visits, work on this reference has not proceeded as quickly as I might have wished. There are two main reasons for this. Firstly, the Committee has had a heavy work load during the past twelve months. It has tabled five reports since last October. This has necessarily limited the amount of time available for hearings and other work on the inquiry into the education of gifted and talented children. The titles of these five reports are listed in the report I have tabled today. Secondly, not all members of the Committee have been able to attend hearings despite our best efforts to schedule these at convenient times. This factor delayed the start of the public hearing program. In the Committee's progress report, mention is made of difficulties sometimes experienced in obtaining a quorum for hearings. In the report, I indicate that I regard the committee system to be one of the strengths of the Australian Senate. If committees begin to suffer, however, because senators cannot make the time available to attend public and private hearings, that strength to which I have referred will soon wane. The Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts has, in effect, operated for the major part of this year with only five active members, three from the Opposition and two from the Government. This is clearly unsatisfactory and is a matter which should be of concern to all honourable senators and to the Government. The Committee appreciates that a final report should be made as soon as possible. It expects to table the final report on this important subject in the 1987 autumn sittings of the Parliament. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Bill received from the House of Representatives.

Bill (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

I bring before the Parliament today a Bill to enact an integral part of this Labor Government's tax reform package-a long overdue reform to provide fairness and equity for all Australians. The Australia Card program will play a significant role in this Government's fight against tax avoidance and evasion, and social security fraud. It will help ensure that every Australian pays their fair share of tax while ensuring that benefits from the welfare system go properly to those in need. By helping to restore fairness and equity to the Australian taxation system, and to the social welfare system, we will help restore public confidence in the integrity of those systems. The Australia Card is essential to the achievement of that integrity.

At the same time, this Government wishes to ensure that we maintain a proper balance between the need to protect the interests of the community, and the need to preserve the rights to privacy and civil liberties of the individual. Therefore this Bill establishes a data protection agency-DPA-an independent watchdog body which will review, establish, and maintain guidelines for the operation of the Australia Card program and provide individuals with a fast and efficient appeals mechanism in the event of complaints of a breach of those guidelines. The Data Protection Agency will also administer privacy safeguards in relation to the protection of personal information contained in government computer data banks. Those safeguards will be the most broad ranging and effective ever seen in this country.

The Bill provides for penalties in the event of the misuse or abuse of the Australia Card, the Australia Card Register, and the national births, deaths, and marriages register. Honourable senators should in particular note that severe penalties will apply to those individuals or organisations who, unauthorised by legislation, demand the production of an Australia Card. Such demands will be illegal.

Privacy legislation will also be introduced into Parliament this session to support and underwrite the privacy protections provided in this Bill. But privacy is not a one way street. Irrefutably, citizens need to be protected against abuse of their privacy by Government. But equally citizens need to be protected against others who cynically hide behind the mantle of privacy to create false identities, and thus defraud the community. We need to achieve a realistic balance to protect the interests of both citizens and community.

The Bill further provides for a national register of births, deaths and marriages. Not only will this facilitate identity checks to ensure the integrity of the Australia Card, but it will end one of the chief means of creating false identities in this society. Just as, in the past, different State railway gauges hampered national communications in Australian society, so today the State births, deaths and marriage registers, neither computerised nor linked with each other, hamper the national fight against crime, corruption and fraud. By the creation of a national BDM register we will plug this major gap in our defences.

The Government believes in the basic principle that people should contribute to the tax system according to their ability to pay, and take from the social security system only their just entitlement. By providing a fair system-whether in tax or social welfare-we underwrite equality. The Australia Card Bill provides for the detailed operation of the program in respect of the Australia Card register and the Australia Card itself.

Parts I and II of the Bill establish the Health Insurance Commission as the administering authority of the Australia Card, and deal with the issue of the card. The legislation enshrines the principle that no one will be required to carry his or her Australia Card at all times, and that he or she will only be required to produce it for the uses explicitly authorised in the Bill. This, along with the prohibitions contained in the Bill, will ensure that the Australia Card does not develop into an internal passport, as some critics have claimed. However, if a person wants to voluntarily use the Australia Card as proof of identity then that person is free to do so.

Much of the detail of Part II of the Bill derives from the Government's desire to make the administration of the Australia Card as flexible as possible and to cater as much as possible for individual needs. A provision for prescribed representatives is included so that a person may act on behalf of another who because of age, infirmity, or other condition cannot easily comply with Australia Card requirements. It will also allow parents to hold cards on behalf of their children.

Special provision has been made in the Bill to cater for persons who are unable to attend an interview for an Australia Card, for example the bedridden. In such cases field officers will be employed to visit these people in their homes. Similar provision will be made for those in remote areas. Further, where the taking of a photograph would cause extreme distress, either to the person or to the person's family, the Bill provides in rare cases for an exemption of that requirement.

Part III and the attached schedule one deal with the Australia Card Register, and I will address the issues raised by this part when dealing further with privacy and civil liberty matters. A key aim of the Australia Card Bill is to provide a major weapon to counter tax evasion, as set out in Part IV. The most conservative estimate put forward by the Australian Taxation Office of revenue gains under the Australia Card program is in the vicinity of $724m a year once the program is fully operational-over $700m, and that does not take account of additional taxes and penalties which would arise where omissions of income have been detected, nor does it take account of amendments to prior returns.

Even the Joint Select Committee of an Australia Card considered that those two factors, together with an acknowledgment that the estimates of evasion and therefore the estimates of benefits were extremely low, could more than double the revenue gains to the Government from this important piece of legislation. That tax evasion exists is an indisputable fact. Explicit and quite specific information on tax evasion is contained in the 1984-85 annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation. In the financial year ending June 1984, 57,000 taxpayers were found to have understated their income by a total of over $470m. In the following year nearly 66,000 taxpayers understated their income by $472m. If these amounts can be detected through the efforts of the Tax Office without the assistance which will undoubtedly be provided by the Australia Card, is it any wonder that estimates of tax savings under the Australia Card program of $4.1 billion over the first ten-year period are considered conservative? With total costs over the same period of $759m it is clearly ludicrous to assert that the program would not be cost effective.

The people of Australia have a right to expect that the taxation system in this country reflects one of the principles held so dearly by them-that is, the right of everyone to a `fair go'. This was an approach fully endorsed by leading members of the Opposition, just over a year ago, before a cynical opportunism overcame their commitments to principle and rationality.
The Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Hunt, put it bluntly:

``The use of plastic cards for an effective means of identification would streamline the collection of tax revenue, imposing a greater accountability on that small minority of taxpayers who sought to evade their responsibilities to the community''.
The honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) was equally enthusiastic. He stated:
``With the Government's white paper on tax reform recommending the introduction of I.D. Cards, there is now broad bi-partisan support for this measure. It should therefore be implemented.''

Another Opposition front bencher, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), put it more succinctly: ``We need a policeman to safeguard the public purse. A plastic policeman would be the most effective in preventing this abuse.''

The Australian people will no doubt want some explanation reconciling these strong statements of support by the National Party elite and their vote on this Bill. The Government has no such hypocrisies.
In order to combat tax evasion the Bill before the House proposes that an Australia Card be produced to identify persons associated with the following transactions:
Deposits and accounts with financial institutions;
Investments;
Income from certain trusts;
Primary production income and rental income;
Foreign remittances;
Real estate transactions;
Use of safety deposit boxes;
Shares in public companies;
Dealing in futures contracts;
Employment; and
Prescribed payments.

By requiring production of an Australia Card for these purposes the Taxation Officer has an immediate means of linking all sources of income to the one number. Such a link is essential to the success of the Australia Card program.

One spin-off of this enhanced pursuit of the money trail will be an improved assault on corporate and organised crime. Although former Royal Commissioner Frank Costigan has asserted that an identity card would not have assisted his enquiries into the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, I find this difficult to reconcile with his Royal Commission report. It stated that:

``Criminals seek to possess wealthy homes, land, expensive cars, yachts, and incur high living expenses . . . they may pay for much by cash; but ultimately . . . they find the normal financial institutions far more convenient and seemingly no less safe to use . . .
``. . . this leads to the creation of large accounts with many taxation vouchers. Once located, those vouchers provide a fertile source of intelligence to the investigator.''

Mr Costigan was so alarmed by the extent of abuse of the banking system that he recommended that each person applying to open a bank account should provide a statement of full name, name under which the person was born, date and place of birth, any other name used between the date of birth and the date of the statement, whether the person is, or has been, a taxpayer, and if appropriate the name under which he lodged his last return, the place of lodgment and his tax file number. The Australia Card will provide precisely such an identity link. Mr Justice Stewart, when conducting the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, also recommended that banks require greater proof of identity. The bottom line is that two royal commissioners recommended for one reason or another, and in one way or another, that identity procedures should be tightened, indeed must be tightened, to assist in the fight against organised crime.

The second major purpose of the Australia Card is to provide a weapon to combat fraud in the social welfare area. During its term of office the Government has already taken steps to attack various opportunities for welfare abuse. The recent budget initiatives are an example. The results of the measures taken since March 1983 can be seen in the frequency with which cases of social security fraud are being brought before the courts.

It is difficult to establish the extent of welfare fraud, but a number of specific cases are notorious. To take one recent example, an individual was convicted of operating a scheme whereby he collected over 50 separate unemployment benefit cheques each fortnight. In just over two years this man robbed the social security system and thus the taxpayer of nearly $400,000. The Joint Select Committee recognised this problem. It stated:

``While the Committee accepts the Department's difficulty in establishing the amount of social security fraud due to false identities, it believes that there is still significant fraud within this area.''

There is no doubt that as we continue to uncover the cheats and bring them to justice, new ways of defrauding the system will be tried by a new generation of cheats and we have to protect ourselves against that.

However difficult it is to measure accurately, we do have a problem with fraud in the social security area, and Opposition front benchers have seen the Australia Card as a valuable response. As the honourable member for Richmond and shadow Minister for Social Security, put it:
``Another major benefit (from the Australia Card) would be a reduction of fraud affecting government outlays, especially social welfare payments . . .''
The Australia Card is a major step in further enhancing the integrity of the social security system-a process this Government has been committed to since taking office.

A further but indirect impact of the Australia Card would be its deterrent effect on illegal immigration. It is estimated that there are some 60,000 illegal immigrants in this country-people who have entered this country contrary to our laws, an affront to all those who patiently wait to enter Australia through the proper procedures. Because these immigrants are here illegally they are often exploited by unscrupulous employers, they often escape the tax system, and they often make demands on the social security and Medicare systems. By making employment more difficult, by placing firmer controls on financial transactions, and by protecting the welfare and Medicare systems from abuse, the Australia Card program will act as a major deterrent to illegal immigration.

No one now doubts that the Australia Card will check tax evasion; no one doubts that it will contribute to the integrity of our social security system; no one doubts that it will be a useful weapon in deterring illegal immigration; no one doubts that by facilitating the pursuit of the money trail it will provide an invaluable instrument against corporate and organised crime. Any doubts that people do have about the Australia Card relate primarily to whether the cost will be too high in terms of privacy and civil liberties. I wish now to turn to this part of the legislation and that concern. All controversies over civil liberties involves questions of striking a balance: a balance between the benefits to the community of some proposed course of action-usually governmental-and the possible threat to civil liberties posed by that course of action. I would point out that Australians are already living with a range of identity systems. As we grow up most of us acquire a driving licence. As time goes on each Australian acquires a range of identity cards and papers: Student identity cards, credit cards, Medicare card, membership cards, security clearance cards, passport.

Those who rail against the Australia Card proposal as an attack on civil liberties overlook these fundamental facts of modern life. Nor do they note that practically every democracy in continental Europe requires identity cards or unique identity numbers of its citizens. Such blurred thinking represents a failure to distinguish between identity papers per se, and the uses to which they are put.

Let me make a few more pertinent observations. Already the tax office has comprehensive powers under the Income Tax Assessment Act to seek details of individuals, in some cases without these individuals being aware of an investigation. Many commercial enterprises keep detailed records of an individual's credit worthiness. Sharing of information between retailers and credit worthiness companies has been a long standing practice. Information obtained by some companies is sold to other companies interested in sending out unsolicited material.

Banks appearing before the Joint Select Committee indicated that they routinely double checked information given on loan applications with other banks-without the customer's approval. Most people do not know what information is kept on them by private companies, and certainly do not have an opportunity to correct that information. Absolute privacy does not then exist. The Australia Card program recognises this, but also begins the task of protecting privacy from abuse.

Let us be clear about what information is and is not displayed on the Australia Card, and more importantly is or is not recorded on the Australia Card Register. The Australia Card itself will have on it only the given names and surname of the person; and Australia Card number; the expiry date of the card; a photograph of the person; and a signature. No other identifying information will be contained on the card. Slightly different information will be shown on the cards of persons under the age of 18 years, adults who have someone else managing their affairs, and visitors staying more than six weeks. Children's cards will for example show date of birth, while visitors cards will show ineligibility or otherwise for employment and or medicare benefits.

However, while accepting that the information on the card itself may be innocuous enough, there has been much conjecture-much of it ill-informed-about precisely what details will be held on the Register. Indeed the outlandish allegations made on this point have fluctuated wildly from keeping information on everything from religious beliefs to political allegiance. It has never been suggested that employers will be able to check on the medical history of prospective employees through the Australia Card. This is totally wrong.

Let me remind the Senate that no private agency has access to the Register, no government agency has access except for a narrow range of specified uses, and that no cross-matching is possible other than that which already occurs. The Australia Card Register will contain nothing other than identifying data such as surname and given names, date of birth, sex, residential and postal addresses, changes of address, any other name by which the person is entitled to be known and wishes to use, and other basic identifying information as listed in schedule one of the Bill. The Register will also contain administrative details necessary to assist the authority in its management of the program, such as where and when cards were issued, details of any replacement cards, details of amendments made to information held on the Register, where and when the changes were made, and by whom. The Register will not, I stress not contain information about such things as medical history, credit history, marital status, religious beliefs, edu- cation, employment history, income or voting intentions.

To give further personal re-assurance, all individuals will have access to the information about them which is held on the register, as provided for in Part V of the Bill. Access to the Australia Card register will be limited to the user agencies-the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Social Security, and the Health Insurance Commission-and that access will be limited to the validation of identity for the purpose of carrying out their departmental or agency role. Again, this is set out in Part V of the Bill. Furthermore, every access and every attempted access by each department, agency, and individual will be logged. That means every single access, Mr President. In conjunction with the establishment of the Australia Card Register we will establish a national births, deaths and marriages register, to be kept quite separate from the Australia Card Register. The co-operation of the States is vital to the establishment of the births, deaths, and marriages register.

The purposes of the national BDM is to combine information held by State and Territory registries of births, deaths and marriages which is vitally important in establishing identity for the Australia Card. The most important function of such a streamlined system is the linking of records or events such as births and deaths, so that birth certificates for people who have died cannot be obtained for fraudulent purposes.

Access to the births, deaths and marriages register will be tightly restricted, and information from it will be used for the following purposes only: By the Health Insurance Commission to check the validity of information on the Australia Card register; by the Department of Foreign Affairs to check the validity of passport information; by the Australian Bureau of Statistics for the extraction of aggregated statistical data and the classification of causes of death; and by the Australian Institute of Health for particular epidemiological studies. Information held on the BDM will remain the property of the State or Territory concerned, and no State will have access to another State's information without prior agreement.

Apart from the sanctions provided in the Bill for breaches of the legislation, a special body-the Data Protection Agency-is created to ensure that individual privacy is not abused. As set out in Part VII of the Bill, the role of the DPA will be to: Review decisions by the Health Insurance Commission in its role as the Australia Card Authority; issue guidelines to ensure that information kept on the register is accurate and confidential; enquire into complaints that the guidelines have been breached; supervise the way in which the Authority keeps the register created from births, deaths and marriages registers; publish a record of all Commonwealth databases containing personal information; research and monitor developments in computer technology and its effects on privacy; undertake educational programs to promote the protection of individual privacy; and perform functions to be conferred upon it by the privacy Bill.

The DPA will consist of a president and two commissioners who will be appointed by the Governor-General on a full time basis. There will be power to appoint associate commissioners on a part time basis and there will be an advisory committee drawn from the community to advise the agency on which consumer interests will be represented.

With these protections, I believe the Australia Card achieves the necessary balance between the protection of individual privacy, and the protection of the community from exploitation through false identities. I can only echo the comment of Professor Whalan of the Australian National University: ``Perhaps one irony would be that if we do have an Australia Card with all those protections . . . our privacy may be better protected than it is now.''

Let me finally rebut the tax file identification system, a kind of soft and fuzzy alternative identification system to the Australia Card, advanced by the majority of the Joint Select Committee. In its bid to fudge its response to the Australia Card, the opposition has toyed with this notion. But let us look at the crux of the tax evasion and social welfare problem. Tax evasion is caused to a large extent by the Tax Office's inability to link all sources of income-that is, to identify persons in receipt of income from more than one source. Likewise welfare fraud is caused to a large extent by the Department of Social Security's inability to fully verify identify to ensure that the identity of a person in receipt of welfare benefits is in fact the true and only identity under which that person operates. In other words, the problem is created by those agencies not having the means of establishing correct identity.

The tax file number option does not solve that problem because it is not based on a secure document system. Under the tax file identification system it was suggested that, to allocate numbers, those who had paid tax continuously for five years should be considered genuine identities, while all other taxpayers and persons who did not possess a tax file number should verify their identity to the same level of integrity as that of the Australia Card program.

Two glaring problems immediately become apparent. First, the Australian Taxation Office itself readily admits that the tax file number was never intended as a unique identification number and is flawed by numerous false identities in the system. Second, the lack of an effective identity document removes from the users the ability to ensure that the number presented is in fact the rightful number of the bearer.

Let us not be fooled by the proposition that tax file numbers could be upgraded to the same level of integrity as that of the Australia Card, and that it could in some way achieve a system of equal integrity. If the system is to commence with false identities-as is the current opposition suggestion-and if it is to be based purely on a number without any secure documentation, it cannot be equated with the Australia Card program and it cannot achieve the same level of integrity. To verify a person's tax file number it would be necessary to undertake precisely the same identity verification procedures as are proposed for the Australia Card, which in turn would mean employing the same number of people to administer the same system for the same purposes. To take the logical further step of issuing a tax file number card would simply be to create an Australia Card by another name.

Let there be no mistake, whether an identification system is called an Australia Card program or a tax file number, its purpose, use and need for integrity is identical. However, because the integrity and security of the proposed tax file system would erode significantly over time due to lack of a secure card-or any secure document to tie a person with a number-the benefits would most definitely not be the same. On a comparative basis, the Australia Card program will return $5.37 for every dollar spent-using the extremely conservative estimates as discussed previously-while the tax file system would return $3.69 for every dollar spent.

Over the first ten years the Australia Card program will provide net total benefits of $4.7 billion, after costs of $759 million. The benefit figure includes gross benefits of $4.1 billion in taxation revenue, and $1.4 billion in savings by the Health Insurance Commission and by the Departments of Social Security and Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

The cost figure includes $544m in establishment and operation costs of the Australia Card Authority, $27m for establishment of the Data Protection Agency, $49m for the establishment of the National births, deaths and marriages register, and a total of $137m in establishment and operation costs over the first ten years for the Australian Taxation Office, the Health Insurance Commission-for Medicare purposes-the Department of Social Security and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

Detailed discussions have been held with the private sector. While it has been difficult to estimate precisely the costs to that sector, it is generally agreed that such costs will not be as significant as some critics originally predicated and that those costs arise as much for new tax requirements by the Australian Taxation Office for wider reporting as from the Australia Card itself. Indeed it is generally expected that there would be some longer term gains in streamlining procedures. In conclusion, I believe this Bill has achieved the necessary balance between the needs of the private individual and the needs of the community. The savings to revenue in taxation and social welfare are too significant to be denied; the spin-off benefits in deterring illegal immigration and providing, through a surer money trail, a further weapon against corporate and organised crime, are unarguable. The measures to limit the use of the card and prevent bureaucratic abuse of privacy are comprehensive, pioneering, and respond to the real concerns of civil libertarians.

I would urge senators to read the Bill with care, and not to reject it on the basis of a luddite distrust of technology, or on the basis of unexamined assumptions about the threat to privacy. For those who might be tempted by a facile opportunism let me say only this: It is inevitable that this country will establish an identification system before the century is out. If we are to secure the full advantages of the system for our people, and if we are to avoid it sneaking in the back door without proper privacy protection, we should seize the opportunity now. In the words of the present leader of the opposition I ask the Senate to give the Australia Card ``Favourable Consideration.''
Debate (on motion by Senator Sheil) adjourned.
