SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
PRIVACY BILL 1986

Mr President, the purpose of the Privacy Bill, and the associated Privacy (Consequential Amendments) Bill, is to regulate the collection, handling and use by Commonwealth departments and agencies of information about individuals so as to provide them with a level of privacy protection that is consistent with efficient government administration. The Privacy Bill will establish a comprehensive set of rules regulating such dealings with personal information and provide an effective means for monitoring compliance with the rules. The rules will, however, mesh with and avoid overlapping existing legislation which coincidentally protects privacy, such as the Freedom of Information (FOI) Act.

At common law there is no enforceable right to privacy as such. There are, however, various existing legal rights that protect aspects of what are generally regarded as individual privacy. Thus the existing law on defamation, breach of confidence, copyright and passing off can be used to prevent unauthorised circulation of personal information or comment in various circumstances. In recent times there have been enormous developments in technology for processing information, providing immense opportunities for building up and using information on individuals. This has focused attention on the need to provide more comprehensive measures for protecting privacy against the threat posed by misuse of this technology. This has been recognised during the development of the Australia Card by the decision to establish the Data Protection Agency.

With the greater range of services being provided by Government, the greater is the accumulation of personal information about individuals. More than anything else, the capacity of modern computers to search and process information offers the greatest potential for invasion of personal privacy by misuse. The greater the accumulations of personal information, the greater are the possibilities of inaccurate material being included amongst such information. Decisions based on wrong information are oppressive to the individual concerned and hinder efficient administration.

Internationally, guidelines for the enactment of legislation protecting personal privacy in the processing of information have been developed by the Council of Europe and by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development of which Australia is a member. Most European countries, the USA and Canada have enacted privacy protection legislation. In December 1984, Australia formally signified its intention to introduce legislation along the lines of the OECD Guidelines on the Protection of Privacy and Transborder Flows of Personal Data.

The Government has been giving detailed consideration for some time to comprehensive information privacy protection legislation. In December 1983 a very detailed report and recommendations were received from the Law Reform Commission following a reference to the Commission in 1976. The recommendations included draft legislation which drew on the OECD Guidelines.

The scheme of the Bill is to enunciate a series of rules, called Information Privacy Principles, which are based on the Principles recommended by the Law Reform Commission in its draft legislation. They will apply to Commonwealth Departments and agencies to the same extent that the FOI Act applies to them. Privacy complaints against security and intelligence agencies, which are not subject to the FOI Act and thus are exempt from this Bill, will be able to be dealt with by the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security.

Under the Principles, Commonwealth agencies must have a lawful purpose for collecting personal information, and the purpose must be related to the functions or activities of the collector. An agency collecting personal information from the information-subject must see that the latter is generally aware of such things as the purpose for which the information is being collected and, if such is the case, the fact that collection is authorised or required by law. The Principles require agencies, when both collecting and retaining information, to see that it is relevant to the purpose of collection, is up to date and is complete. Before using any information, they must also check its accuracy.

`Personal information' is widely defined to include anything-fact, true or false, or opinion-that reasonably identifies the information-subject. However all the Principles are concerned only with personal information in a record or collected for inclusion in a record or a publication, so unrecorded conversation, for example, is not covered.

The Principles require agencies to store information records securely against loss or misuse. If asked, they are to provide information about the types of personal information they hold. Subject to FOI Act exemptions they are to provide access to them if sought by the information-subject and to make corrections for accuracy, relevance and completeness. Subject to certain specific exceptions, notably to law enforcement and preservation of life, information that was sought from the information-subject may not be used for a purpose or disclosed to a person other than with the agreement of the information-subject.

Commonwealth agencies will be required to comply with these Principles. A breach of the Principles will be deemed by the Bill to be an `interference with privacy'. Under the Bill the Data Protection Agency to be established by the Australia Card Bill will undertake the functions of investigating alleged interferences with privacy, attempting to resolve the allegations by conciliation and, failing that, reporting to the Minister where it finds that there has been such an interference. The DPA's powers in conducting investigations will be those prescribed in the Australia Card Bill. The DPAs investigation and reporting functions will be exercisable not only on complaint but also of its own motion.

Remedies such as injunction and declaration, will be able to be sought against interferences with privacy to the extent that they are available under existing law. However the Government has decided that, at this initial stage, it should not be possible to recover damages for interferences with privacy by agencies. Nevertheless, when reporting a finding that an interference with privacy has occurred, the DPA will be able to make a recommendation for compensation to an individual affected by the interference.

To help agencies achieve compliance with the Principles, the DPA will be able to give advisory opinions, issue guidelines and examine proposed enactments for privacy implications. Where an agency believes that a current or proposed practice that may breach the Principles is nevertheless important to its operations, it will be able to seek from the DPA a determination allowing the practice to continue or go ahead without risk of its being found to be an interference with privacy. Such a determination may be granted only if the DPA is satisfied that the public interest in permitting the practice substantially outweighs the public interest in adherence to the Principles.

I mentioned earlier that the law of confidence is an important existing means of protecting privacy in some circumstances. The Bill includes some limited extensions of the law of confidence recommended by the Law Reform Commission which will further enhance privacy protection. The companion Privacy (Consequential Amendments) Bill includes amendments of the FOI Act to extend the opportunities for access to personal affairs records by record-subjects and establish the requirement for record-subjects to be alerted to requests for access to those records by others.
The proposals contained in the Privacy Bill and the Privacy (Consequential Amendments) Bill are expected to have a direct cost to the Government of $800,000 in a full-year operation.

International instruments to which I have referred, overseas legislation and the Law Reform Commission's report recognise that there are important interests that compete with the right to privacy, including effective Government administration, law enforcement and free flow of information. The Government considers that the Privacy Bill, applying as it does to Commonwealth agencies, strikes a fair balance between the right of the individual to privacy against the equally important concern of the individual, as a taxpayer, that the Commonwealth administration is not overburdened.

What will be achieved by the Privacy Bill is a comprehensive code of information privacy protection standards. It will be the first such legislation anywhere in Australia. It will also provide a practical means for persons who have been adversely affected by a failure to comply with those standards to seek redress. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
PRIVACY (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986
Mr President, this Bill is a companion measure to the Privacy Bill which I have just introduced.

The main amendment made by this Bill is to the Freedom of Information (FOI) Act to introduce `reverse FOI' for personal affairs documents. That is, where documents requested under FOI include a record of personal affairs of a person other than the requestor, the record-subject must, if possible, be consulted and given an opportunity to seek exemption from disclosure to the requestor of that record. Another amendment to the FOI Act will slightly restrict the circumstances in which a ground of exemption from access can be used to prevent access to a record of personal affairs by the record-subject.

Otherwise this Bill makes essentially machinery amendments to ensure that privacy complaints wrongly directed to other agencies are transferred to the Data Protection Agency for investigation under the Privacy Bill without inconvenience to the complaint. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sheil) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1986OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Walsh) agreed to:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the questions with regard to the several stages for the passage through the Senate of the Bills being put in one motion at each stage and the consideration of such Bills together in the Committee of the Whole.
Ordered that the Bills may be taken through all their stages without delay.
Bills (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a first time.
Second Readings

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1986

The purpose of the Bill is to amend section 4 of the Overseas Students Charge Act 1979, to extend the charge liability to overseas students who enrol in government and private secondary schools, and courses at TAFE level institutions for which Commonwealth funding is received. The intention is to recoup a proportion of the cost to the Commonwealth of supporting places for overseas students at Australian education institutions. Charge liability is also extended to include diplomatic and consular representatives, their staff and dependants, who undertake tertiary courses.
The further purpose of the Bill is to amend section 6 of the principal Act to fix the charge rates for the 1987 academic year. The new levels of charge are indicated in the Bill.

As foreshadowed in 1985, the increase in the overseas students charge proposed in the Bill, for university and advanced education level courses, raises the contribution of a new student or one who commenced the course after 1 January 1986 to 45 per cent of the full average cost of a place. In respect of a student who commenced the course before 1 January 1986, the charge represents 32 per cent of the full average cost, or an increase of 15 per cent over the 1986 level.

The amount of the overseas students charge will be reduced by $250, the amount of the higher education administration charge to be payable by all higher education students in respect of the enrolment.

TAFE overseas students who commenced their courses prior to 1 January 1987 will pay 32 per cent of the average Commonwealth contribution to TAFE costs, and new TAFE students will pay 45 per cent. All secondary school overseas students will pay a flat rate of $300.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present an explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

The purpose of this Bill is to vary the categories of students exempt from the overseas students charge. This is effected by including in the Overseas Students Charge Collection Act 1979, through inserting section 4a, those categories of students who are exempt from the charge. The current exemption provision relating to a postgraduate student who is the holder of a scholarship to the value of at least $3,500 per annum awarded by an Australian institution is now limited to a person who has been granted such a scholarship and commenced study before 1 January 1987.
It is also proposed to withdraw the charge exemption provision for a postgraduate student who is the holder of a scholarship awarded by the Australian-American Educational Foundation.

The proposed extension of the charge, as from 1 January 1987, to postgraduate students who are awarded a scholarship by an Australian institution on or after 1 January 1987, and to all Australian-American Educational Foundation scholarship holders, is expected to raise approximately $1.2m in 1986-87.

This Bill proposes to provide exemption from the secondary level charge to those overseas students entering Australian secondary schools under reciprocal exchange agreements between Australian and overseas secondary schools and organisations. This will facilitate the continued participation of Australian students in these important exchange schemes. This proposed exemption from the charge will amount to a reduction in revenue, which would otherwise have been collected, of approximately $300,000 per annum.

The further purpose of the Bill is to amend section 7 of the principal Act to restrict the capacity of a department or authority of the Commonwealth to discharge the liability of a student to whom that department or authority has granted a scholarship or like award, to postgraduate scholarship holders who commenced study before 1 January 1987.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the revised explanatory memoranda to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sheil) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BOUNTY AND SUBSIDY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill continues the practice begun last sittings of combining amendments required to bounty and subsidy Acts in one omnibus Bill.
In brief this Bill contains amendments to current bounty and subsidy Acts to-
(1) amend the Bounty (Ships) Act 1980 to provide for a single cash limited bounty for all eligible vessels regardless of market destination;
(2) give effect to the Budget announcement to reduce most bounty and subsidy rates in existing schemes by 20 per cent; and

(3) make a number of technical amendments to the Bounty (Steel Mill Products) Act 1983 and the Bounty (Metal Working Machines and Robots) Act 1985 and to all bounty Acts in respect of the appointment of authorised officers.

In this speech I will outline the amendments to the Bounty (Ships) Act 1980 and the amendments required as a consequence of the 20 per cent Budget cut in bounty rates. Details of the technical amendments to the various Acts are set out in the explanatory memorandum to this Bill which has been circulated.
Part 2 of the Bill contains the proposed amendments to the Bounty (Ships) Act to provide for a single cash limited bounty for all vessels.
Currently this industry's assistance arrangements involve a non-cash limited bounty for vessels built for the domestic market and a cash limited bounty for vessels built for export.

The amendments proposed to those arrangements by this Bill are essential if the shipbuilding industry is to maintain and increase the significant gains in efficiency and competitiveness it has achieved over the last decade.

The Government's 1984 decision to extend bounty payments to vessels built for export and to tighten registration requirements for bounty purposes hastened the pace of rationalisation in the industry begun in 1976. Australian shipbuilders have developed market niches for their products at home and abroad. Throughput has generally improved and some economies of scale have been achieved. Devaluation has also worked to the industry's advantage.

These factors are reflected in burgeoning exports. Growth in exports, I am happy to report, has been remarkable since 1984-85 when only one vessel was built for export. More than 20 were being built for export last financial year. Contracts for further exports, worth over $120m, have either been finalised or are nearing finalisation.

This success has created significant new demands for the export bounty which under the current annual cash limited approach would not allow many of these contracts to proceed. If this was to occur, the scale advantages accruing to the industry from increased throughput would be lost with resultant declines in competitiveness, investment and employment.

The Government believes that the revised arrangements in this Bill will not only allow these contracts to proceed but will provide the industry with the stable and predictable environment it needs to further expand its export activity.

Confidence in the future rate and availability of bounty is very important for this industry because of the long lead times in tendering and construction. Contract negotiations normally take between three and 12 months. Construction normally takes between nine and 24 months.

The imposition of limits on expenditure at clause 7 is necessary to enable the Government to exercise appropriate budgetary restraints while at the same time continuing its commitment to the industry.

Adoption of a reservation system for all vessels also proposed by clause 7 means that builders of domestic vessels, like builders of export vessels, will be required to reserve bounty funds from within the total allocation of $144m. All shipbuilders will be required to nominate a completion date, within this or the next two financial years, to be able to reserve funds. Failure to complete a vessel within six months of the nominated financial year will result in forfeiture of bounty eligibility.

A roll-over provision is proposed if in any one of the financial periods the amount reserved exceeds the amount of bounty available for payment. This will allow the acceptance of reservation applications to be `rolled over' into the next period, if sufficient funds are available within the $144m.

Another proposed change, reflecting the improved competitiveness of the industry, is that the rate of bounty for certain classes of vessels will be reduced from 20 per cent to 15 per cent on 1 January 1988.

Only modifications and those vessels whose construction costs have not been reduced as a result of the Australian dollar's depreciation will attract the higher rate after that date. Tugs, bulk carriers, rig servicing and fishing vessels fall into this category.
This change will require the Australian shipbuilders to further improve their efficiency.

Improvements in efficiency will be aided by extending the orderly development provisions introduced in 1985 on an annual basis to all shipbuilders seeking bounty assistance. Under those provisions new entrants or those shipbuilders who were not building a bountiable vessel on 11 October 1984 had to demonstrate that their registration would not disrupt the market and negate the Government's objective to increase industry throughput and hence efficiency.

As a result of those provisions the number of registered shipbuilders has reduced significantly, down from over 90 in 1984 to less than 30 today and throughput has increased significantly. The Government considers that the orderly development extension will lead to further efficiency gains and a reduction, in the longer term, in the level of support required by this industry.

The other important amendments in the Bill are contained in Part 3 and Schedule 1. Schedule 1 contains the amendments to most current bounty and subsidy Acts reducing the rates in those Acts by 20 per cent as announced by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech on 19 August 1986.

Omitting from Schedule 1 is the Bounty (Ships) Act, which is dealt with separately in Part 2 of this Bill. The rate for that bounty has been the subject of a phased reduction from 25 per cent. The rate payable from 1 July 1986 is now 20 per cent. I mentioned earlier that the bounty rate for certain classes of vessels will be reduced from 20 per cent to 15 per cent on 1 January 1988.

This bounty was not subjected to the 20 per cent cut in the rate. Long lead times are the norm in this industry. To enable firms to quote with certainty it was determined in pre-Budget deliberations to make the reduction to the cash limit rather than the actual rate to be paid.

Also omitted from the Schedule is the Bounty (Metal Working Machines and Robots) Act and the Nitrogenous and Phosphate Fertilizers Subsidy Act. This is for the reason that the reduction in the metal working machines bounty rate has already been effected by a Gazette notification made under that Act, a provision unique to that Act which does not appear in other bounty legislation. It is proposed that the fertilisers legislation which is not effected by the Budget rate cut be dealt with separately later in this sittings.
I should make it clear that the reduction in bounty rates is a fiscal measure made to reduce Government expenditure and for no other reason.

In framing the 1986-87 Budget the Government considered a wide range of options for reducing outlays and exercising expenditure restraint. It is the Government's view that such restraint should be borne by the community as a whole and a cut in the bounty and subsidy rates is just one of the measures needed to achieve the Government's expenditure objectives.
Financial Impact Statement

In relation to the revised shipbuilding bounty, clause 7 of the Bill sets an absolute limit of $144m on funds available for reservation purposes for bountiable ships in the period to 30 June 1989. Within this limit clause 7, restricts outlays to a maximum of $42m in the current financial year, and to $45m in the succeeding two years. Reserved but unexpended funds as at 30 June 1989 will be available as required up to 30 June 1991.

The Budget cut of 20 per cent in bounty and subsidy rates is expected to save about $43m in bounty and subsidy payments in 1986-87 and is estimated to maintain total payments at about the same level in money terms as in the previous two financial years.
Other measures is the bill have no direct financial impact.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the revised explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sheil) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STATUTORY COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Haines, requesting a change in the membership of the Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority.

INTERJECT.PARA: That Senator Haines be discharged from further attendance on the Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority and that Senator Macklin be appointed a member of the Joint Committee.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 17 November.
GROUP A
Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce
Proposed expenditure, $353,853,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is continuing the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 in Committee and is considering the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. Unfortunately, the excessive roles of monetary policy are having a damaging effect on investment, although the large depreciation in the value of the Australian dollar has provided some change in relative prices. I wish to draw the Committee's attention to some interesting questions raised by an eminent economist, Professor Herman Black of the University of Sydney, when he asked: Is manufacturing investment being innovative or have overseas surveys been made as to market tendencies? Do we have on hand or within the plant local products available or acceptable to foreign investors and, if so, where? In other words, do we have the products that overseas customers want? Does the J-curve cause the Australian Council of Trade Unions ever to have second thoughts about wage claims, indexation and superannuation? Perhaps the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) should ponder the questions of a man who has been around for a long time. Unfortunately, so many of the sunrise industries that the Minister and the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) were saying a short time ago were going to be the saviour of the Australian economy, all too soon became sunset industries. They failed to ensure that existing firms adopted the appropriate new technology. They did not put enough emphasis on the uniqueness of design and on building quality products.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, this Budget is a manifestation of the Government's policies, not of wealth creation, but of wealth distribution-the distribution of a reduction in living standards across the community. Therefore, this Budget is a Budget not of promise, but of disillusionment, of broken promises, from a government that fails to come to grips with many of the problems faced by our nation, particularly on the industry front. In fact, one of the big problems which we face as a potential exporter and which could seriously damage our standard of living is the high rate of domestic inflation, which is a major problem for--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. We put up with a great gaggle of bores and egomaniacs during the second reading debate--
—Order! The point of order should not start with those comments. State your point of order, Senator Walsh.
—The point of order is that this is a second reading stage speech and not a Committee stage speech.

—Yes, I am watching that. Senator Watson, you have to relate your remarks to some part of the estimates of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. I can understand how your remarks might be so related but you should do so directly.

—I draw the Minister's attention to this question: Why have so few firms registered for participation in the tax incentive research and development area? This is an area which should hold great potential. Is it a concern that the business community has towards this Government's approach to research and development? I remind the Committee that perhaps part of the problem is a crowding-out effect that bodies such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the universities have. While they have some good results to their credit, they are very slow to bring on stream some productive processes to earn money. It is all very well to have the ideas, but for research and development incentives to have any effect we have to ensure that these ideas are put into practice very quickly rather than slowly. It is no good just lumbering the Australian taxpayers with higher taxes. The Minister himself has been very strong on telling his Labor Party audiences that the community will not tolerate increased taxes. What has he done? He has actually presided over the highest taxing government in the history of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this segment of the Budget has the potential to lift our living standards, has the potential to get Australia out of this so-called problem, but the reliance is on a J-curve. Surely the J-curve has been discredited by now. Surveys by the Australian National University have shown that the long-awaited J-curve has failed to emerge. The tightening of monetary policy, which the Minister was so sensitive about in my remarks, is keeping business under the thumb. The growth figures are not emerging. The Government has a policy of high interest rates to protect the dollar, which has now been underwritten by the Reserve Bank of Australia. Under this sort of regime industry has no alternative but to stagnate. Lack of growth is one of the features of this Budget. It is a reflection on the failure of the previous Budget to take the hard decisions. In failing to take those hard decisions, the Government is now left with a Budget that is getting it into difficulties. It now has nowhere to go for industry policy. This is a sad reflection on a socialist government adopting socialist philosophies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to canvass three matters associated with the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. The first matter is the need for us to get into certain new areas of technology, such as material science and electronic communications. We particularly need to encourage the development of our own high technology industry so that in the long term we will not have to import such goods. A particular industry I have in mind and which has been fairly well canvassed is the space industry. The Technical Director of Hawker de Havilland Australia Pty Ltd has estimated that Australia will be paying between $450m and $500m for space services by 1995, especially as our communications are dependent on this area. Our present actions will determine just how much of that money flows abroad. Current indications are that it will be virtually the whole lot.

SPEECH.PARA: The Madigan report of the working party on the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences recommended that $14m be spent this year to get a space industry off the ground over the next 10 years. It recommended that $100m be spent over the next five years. The Government has come up with a niggardly $5.25m for this year and no guarantees for the future, which makes it very difficult for such industries. One of its advisers has been quoted as applying the label `emotive and nationalistic' to aspects of this excellent report and saying that there are limits to how much vision governments are allowed to have. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard-I have sought leave from the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who was previously at the table, and the shadow Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Chaney-an article dealing with this area.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
Why our space industry may be left on the launching pad
By Rod Frail in Canberra
By 1995, Australia will be spending $350 to $500 million a year on space technology, mainly information from satellites vital for communications, agriculture, mineral exploration and weather.
How much of this technology will be made in Australia and how much will come from technologically more advanced countries depends on what initiatives are taken now to foster a local space industry.
A committee headed by the deputy chairman of CRA Ltd, Sir Russel Madigan, reported last year on how Australia could become involved in space technology.
The Federal Government released its policy response two weeks ago, but it has taken a very different view from that of Sir Russel and his colleagues.

They fear Paul Keating's banana republic warning will be borne out and Australia will become dependent not only financially but technologically on others unless a considerable amount of money is spent now to enter the space race with its accompanying advantages for revitalising industry.
The Government take the pragmatic political view that money does not necessarily buy results.
It says that in stringent economic conditions, it is more prudent to probe carefully the options before launching into unknown galaxies where there may be nothing but a black hole devouring dollars.
Entering the space industry involves a Catch 22. You can't win international contracts without a track record in the industry. You can't get experience without contracts.
The Madigan committee recommended that the Government spend $100 million over five years to assist Australian companies to fill Australian contracts and gain experience.
The report said Australia had to find itself a market niche based on its areas of particular technological expertise.

It identified one such area as remote sensing-collecting and interpreting information from satellites such as Landsat which circles the earth sending back information on land use and geography for agricultural and mineral exploration.
Australia's vast distances and scattered population will make it increasingly dependent on this type of information.
Aussat 1 and Aussat 2 are already providing radio and television to remote areas and supplying other data. Aussat 3 will be launched late next year.
The total cost will be about $405 million of which $120 million will have been for Australian-made content in the form of direct content or offsets.
The question is how much of Aussat's second generation in the 1990s will be Australian-made?

The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, and the Science Minister, Mr Jones, did not accept two of Sir Russel's key recommendations-to commit the Government to $100m over five years and to a NASA-style independent statutory authority to be called ASTRA, Australian Space Technology Research Authority, to formulate policy.
The Government has given a $5.25 million commitment for one year only.
It is setting up an interim advisory committee, the Australian Space Board, located within the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, headed by the chairman of OTC, Mr Robert Somervaille.
When Sir Russel was asked what his reaction to the initiatives was it was found that the Government had not even given him a copy.
After reading them, Sir Russel said: ``I would not like to knock the whole thing because I think there are some positive aspects, but I just worry it is too little too late.''
He singled out three causes for worry:
The small amount of money for 1986-87-his committee recommended $14 million-and not commitment beyond.
Most of the $5.25 million is already committed to existing projects.
The Space Board stays within the bureaucracy rather than being made a more independent body with large, free-enterprise representation.
``If the board is not independent, then the department will do a Sir Humphrey [the interfering department head of television's Yes Minister] on it,'' he said.
Referring to the economic climate, he said: ``I would have thought it was the very thing needed. This is one thing that would generate money, not spend it.
``I don't think any business can spend capital setting up a factory to make something which the Government is only committed to support for one year.''
Another member of his committee, the technical director of Hawker de Havilland, Mr Stan Schaetzel, agreed.
He said: ``If we don't spend this money, by 1995 the whole of Australia will be paying $450 to $500 million for space services and if we don't have a space industry, that will be going overseas.''

A third committee member, the chairman of the Physics Department at La Trobe University, Professor Keith Cole, had a dire warning for Australia: ``It either wants to get into the 21st century or degenerate.
``Space on its own is only part of the business. It has enormous spin-offs for industry-automation, remote sensing, transmission and processing of data.''
Mr Jones rejected Sir Russel's fears about the bureaucracy.

He said: ``The board is independent and, while subject to ministerial riding instructions, people like Bob Somervaille and Dr Ken McCracken [director of the CSIRO's Office of Space Science and Applications, COSSA] are not bureaucratic stool pigeons.''
Senator Button's policy adviser on aerospace and technology matters, Ms Denise North, described aspects of the Madigan report as ``emotive and nationalistic.''
``There are limits to how much vision Governments are allowed to have,'' she said.
The US now spends between $25 and $30 per head of population on space research; Canada, Japan and West Germany $4 to $5; Australia about 33 cents.
Ms North said space technology was not profitable without large government contributions.
Nor should the spin-offs from the technology be overestimated.

``The spin-offs are important but not enough to justify the spending on their own. You don't fund the Apollo program just to get a Teflon fry pan. If you decide to produce space communications and space remote sensing, you don't do it on economic grounds, you do it on public policy grounds, like electricity supply.''
It will be the economic conditions of the next few years which determine whether Australia's plans for a space industry actually leave the launching pad.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. No wonder Sir Russel Madigan was worried by the prospect of the Australian Public Service remaining in charge of an enterprise with such great potential. We have a real problem in this area. I ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) exactly what he intends to do about it and particularly about the Madigan report. The Minister knows of the article.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to canvass the subject of the tobacco industry. I raise the question of the excise on cigarettes and manufactured tobacco and the way in which the tobacco industry is currently creaming off money from government revenue by pumping tobacco leaf with gas. I believe that this matter should be investigated by the Department. I would like to know whether the Minister knows about it. It is put forward in the name of reducing tar content. However, the way tobacco interests are going about it is the only way in which they can skim off the profits by paying less excise and still charging their victims the same. Tar levels can be reduced by improving filters and by promoting the growth of different types of leaf. But in neither of these cases does all the profit go to the tobacco companies in the first instance. A source, which must remain confidential, has made available to me some figures on the comparative weight of 1,000 cigarettes over the past 11 years. In 1975-76 the weight of 1,000 cigarettes was 947 grams. By 1984-85 the weight of the same number of cigarettes was 788 grams. The weight for 1985-86, when averaged out, is estimated to have been only about 645 grams.

TALK.START.PARA: —That makes them healthier.
—I will get on to that. I seek leave to incorporate the table provided to me in Hansard.

This means that every time companies reduce the weight without reducing the price they pay less excise and pocket the profits. Perhaps this disreputable behaviour could be stopped by charging the excise on a per packet basis and discriminating on the basis of average tar and nicotine levels. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. The table deals with the rates of excise duty on cigarettes and manufactured tobacco between 1965 and 1985. The Fraser Government raised the excise only twice in its seven and a bit years, the first time by around 27 1/2 per cent in 1978 and the second time by 20 per cent in 1982. The Minister will probably recall that the Australian Medical Association called for a 50 per cent increase during the first major government inquiry into the industry, which happened just recently, after about 40 years. This would have the effect of reducing consumption among the young because they are influenced by the price of such commodities. We have a national drug offensive in place to discourage the use of poisonous or other harmful products. The Better Health Commission has pointed out that we need vastly increased excise levels. That would make a sound contribution to national health. I wonder whether the Minister has considered co-ordinating his Department's activities regarding excise levels with the Government's health strategy. I would also like to know whether he will have his Department examine industry returns on average cigarette weights so that the admitted practice of pumping tobacco leaf with more gas does not constitute a siphoning of the revenue into tobacco coffers.

SPEECH.PARA: The last matter I want to raise under this Department is also tobacco-related. It arose from questions asked in Estimates committee hearings. Just last week the National Health and Medical Research Council announced its strong opposition to all forms of `smokeless tobacco'. The Press release said:
Evidence has come forward of a high incidence of mouth and lip cancer from `smokeless tobacco'.

In June the Council had recommended that steps be taken to control the import and advertising of chewing tobacco. Now it has gone further by recommending that State and Territory health authorities restrict the availability and advertising of these products. Although the Department of Health has taken up this issue and everybody in the States has taken it up and recommended that Customs duty levels be raised, the Customs section of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce does not seem to have done anything to stop this product entering the country. I would like to know from the Minister whether anything is happening in this area, in which his Department and its activities impinge so strongly on the health of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are in the Committee stage of the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) relating to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. I will not go over all the details of either the matters raised in the second reading debate or, more particularly, the questions and issues raised in the very interesting and, I think, rewarding Estimates committee debates on this matter. I thank the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is in the chamber today, for his co-operation in the Estimates committee debate. It is a pity the outside public and the listening audience cannot hear what goes on in the Estimates committee debates because they are a very important part of the parliamentary process in the Senate and lead to a greater understanding by all sides of politics about some of the issues involved.

SPEECH.PARA: In the few minutes available I will raise a couple of issues from the Estimates committee debates and from what I assert to be the considerable inconsistency between the Government's approach to macroeconomic policy over recent years and the approach adopted particularly through the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce in terms of specific industry policies. We would all agree that there is a need for considerable consistency between the Government's industry policies and its broader or macroeconomic policies, by which I mean monetary, fiscal, wages and exchange rate policies. There is also a need in particular industry policies for stability and predictability. There is a growing acceptance of the need for a revitalisation of Australian industry. Enormous issues must be tackled if this revitalisation is to occur. The bottom line is increased productivity and, therefore, increased export competitiveness and the ability to compete in our market against imported products.

Those things will not occur unless we have considerably increased investment in industry. Increased investment will not occur unless the investors can see the prospect of a reasonable return on their investment. It is quite pointless attempting to encourage investment and productivity growth without providing the necessary environment, stability and predictability in government policies. We need an environment in which wealth generation, individual enterprise and business investment are actively encouraged and rewarded and in which our primary concern is how to create wealth and income rather than how to distribute it. The reason we have so many deep-seated and seemingly intractable problems in Australian industry today is, very importantly, that the community attitude has been built up over decades that we need to be more concerned with wealth and income distribution than with wealth creation. That is a very negative and backward attitude and one which has led us progressively over the years to a declining relative standard of living compared with those of many other countries.

Where the Hawke Government is falling down so badly is that the macroenvironment the Government has painted with its policies has caused investment to lag and further cuts to investment plans are being forecast. I will go into some of those details in a moment. The latest quarterly survey of business conditions from the Australian Chamber of Commerce and the National Australia Bank, which was released over the weekend, makes very disturbing reading. The survey found planned capital expenditure over the year ahead to be at its lowest level since the 1982-83 recession. The survey also highlighted the cost problem facing industry at all levels. The survey has simply confirmed what many of us have been saying to the Government for a considerable time-that if we cannot restrain our domestic costs the potential benefits to be derived from the quite massive devaluation of the Australian dollar over the past two years simply will not be realised.

The effect of the devaluation in those circumstances may well be negative, with an increased likelihood that the economy will slide into further recession. I say to the Government and to the Minister at the table that so far as industry policy is concerned they have had very considerable support to date from the Opposition. Senator Chaney, the shadow Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, has said that there is a high degree of common ground between the Government and the Opposition on specific industry policies. That is an accurate assessment; but time is running out on this support because of the Government's failure and inability to take seriously the need to provide the complementary supporting macroeconomic environment and its failure to provide stability and predictability in those macropolicies and in industry policies. Let us look at a few examples of what I mean. The Government talks about stimulating investment and then it promptly goes ahead and raises corporate tax levels to the highest level in the Western world.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is rubbish and you know it.

—I understand that the company tax rate of 49 per cent recently imposed by the Minister's Government is the highest company tax rate of any government in any country in the Western world. There is much worse to come. The Government has imposed a whole raft of new taxes on the business sector. It has done so because it does not have the ability or courage or what have you to take the necessary measures to restrain its spending. As a result we have the fringe benefits tax, which has placed a double burden on industry by increasing costs to industry and the tax on industry. As a result, thousands of jobs throughout industry have been destroyed, particularly in the automotive industry. This goes across a very wide range of industry.
—Which section of the automotive industry has had thousands of jobs destroyed? Don't talk bunkum. Come on, tell me.

—The effects are still working their way through. They will be very considerable in the next couple of months. This will happen not just in the manufacturing sector but particularly in the sales and distribution area. That is a very major part of the industry. The Minister does not need me to tell him that. He knows that better than I. On top of that is the capital gains tax, which is a major disincentive to increased and, importantly, more flexible investment. That is by no means the end of the list, but those examples on the tax side illustrate what damage the Government is doing to the productive private sector with its increasing tax policies. On top of that comes the Government's support of union wage and wage-related demands, which will push costs still further and make it more difficult for us to improve our productivity.

SPEECH.PARA: Other decisions have greatly eroded the confidence in this Government of the manufacturing sector and other sectors of industry. I mention in particular-it is just an example because there are many cases to support it-the totally arbitrary decision announced in the Budget to cut all bounty payments by 20 per cent overnight. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, has admitted that the decision was taken purely on budgetary grounds. No account whatsoever was taken of the situation facing particular companies or industries. No advice was sought from industry and no advice was sought from the Industries Assistance Commission, which is the body responsible for advising the Government on industry assistance matters. In one instance, that of the book bounty, the Government reduced the bounty by 20 per cent on Budget day and the very next day announced a further 20 per cent reduction to apply from 1 January as a result of an IAC inquiry.

When I questioned Senator Button on this at an Estimates committee hearing he admitted that he was aware of the very significant impact on the book printing and publishing industry of what amounts in fact to a 36 per cent reduction in assistance in 4 1/2 months, more than half of that reduction in assistance coming with a decision that had nothing at all to do with industry policy. Yet the Minister is not prepared to give any further consideration to those most affected, including those-but not exclusively-in regional areas which depend very importantly on some of the companies in the industry. Nor has the Minister been prepared to give consideration to those other companies and industries adversely affected by this quite arbitrary decision. Many of them have already been disadvantaged by significant cost reductions flowing particularly as a result of the devaluation of the Australian dollar.

The fringe benefits tax, the Budget bounty decision and other instances display a conflict between economic policy and industry policy which has led to a considerable inconsistency in the Government's whole approach to industry. It is unsettling to industry, it causes nervousness and lack of confidence. No wonder industry is not investing at the rate which is required if we are really serious about revitalising Australian industry. I am not sure that the extent of investment which will be required in Australia to get industry going again is fully realised, nor am I confident that the extent to which that will have to rely on imported capital equipment for investment purposes is fully realised. That leads one to a whole range of other areas of great concern, particularly in relation to what it means for the balance of payments, the exchange rate and all those other things that go together to make up a macroeconomic policy environment, which the Government has a mandatory obligation to try to get right if it is really to be serious about what it is trying to do with its industry policy.

We certainly should be serious about this because in its outcome lies the future of Australia's living standards. There are various other issues that are relevant and pertinent to this Committee stage of the debate. Time does not permit me to go into them. If I had time I would refer to the whole question of our offsets policy and the problems smaller companies are having in getting a worthwhile involvement in the offsets program. I would certainly wish to talk about the role of the Australian Industry Development Corporation in taking its 10 per cent equity in the Portland smelter-an absolutely disastrous development politically motivated by the Cain Government in Victoria. I would refer also to the staggering lack of follow up on the very valuable work that has been done by the Business Regulation Review Unit, the problems facing the management and investment companies which were reported in the Press over the weekend, the lack of capital and the expansion that seems to be taking place in the bureaucracy involved with industry councils and the like. As I said, time does not permit me to deal with these matters but perhaps the Minister, in responding to the comments of honourable senators on this side of the chamber, will cover some of those matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to intervene at great length at this stage. I feel that in order that Senator Vigor might go and have the evening away from the chamber I should comment on some of the things that he said at this stage and get some of these matters out of the way. However, I really cannot say much by way of response to Senator Vigor, particularly about the tobacco industry. I honestly do not know much about it and I have not read the articles about pumping up tobacco leaves with gas. I will try to read them as early as possible. All I really know about the tobacco industry is that I smoke and I regret that fact very much. I regard it as silly but I cannot help myself. I will probably go on smoking. Senator Vigor asked me half a dozen times whether I recall that the excise duty was raised in 1973 and again in 1978. I do not recall many of those things. He asked me to take on board a number of other things and I will take on board everything else he said and see whether I can catch up with my reading in that particular area.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say a few things about what Senator Short had to say. His speech reveals the great dilemma of the Opposition at the moment. It starts with the proposition of saying: `There is a conflict between macroeconomic policy which we do not like and industry policy which we do like and that conflict has to be resolved'. There is always an inherent conflict between those two things and the sort of balance--

TALK.START.PARA: —There does not have to be.

—I think there does in the current context in Australia and the greater the extent to which one resolves those conflicts the better one will do. Having made that sort of general allegation, the rest of Senator Short's speech was just a grab-bag of everything that the Liberal Party in opposition has been throwing together in the past six months.
—You can do better than that.

—I am going to do better than that. There were certain statements-such as the effects of the fringe benefits tax-which, when I challenged Senator Short about it, he retreated very rapidly because what he was saying in respect of those matters was incorrect. Let me turn to one or two of the major issues which arise from Senator Short's speech. The promise from the Opposition inherent in Senator Short's speech was that in order to bring macroeconomic policy and industry policy together a Liberal government if elected in this country would abolish the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax, would reduce taxation and would do all the things designed to make the industry environment-indeed, the human environment-much more comfortable. One really has to address very hard thinking to those things. It is only three months since the last Budget was brought down. Senator Short well knows that one cannot do all the things which were inherent in what he was saying. One cannot have a sort of floating promise that somehow all of these things will be rectified if the Liberal Party ever gains office and money will be expended on other things. Indeed, it could not maintain anything like existing levels of expenditure if it funded all sorts of other things on which it has said it will expend money.
—No, we have not. That is not true.

—It depends which week of Liberal Party promises one is looking at. Senator Short went on to give a very potted view of comparative company taxation levels by simply asserting that Australia had the highest company tax regime in the world-49 per cent. He asserted that as a bland piece of information based on the fact that the nominal rate of company taxation will be 49 per cent. If Senator Short likes, I will get him that information. If he wants to substantiate these arguments in debate, I suggest that he try.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite recently I looked at comparative figures for the United States of America, Japan, Canada and Australia in respect of company tax rates. If one takes into account that in the United States a whole range of allowances and incentives will be abolished when the new nominal tax rate for companies comes into existence, plus State taxes and charges, if one takes into account in a similar way the existing regime in Japan and Canada, and if one takes into account the effects of imputation in Australia-the effects of the 5/3 depreciation and so on-Australia comparatively comes second out of those four countries. When Canada changes its tax regime, Australia will have the most favourable tax regime for companies out of those four countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to see the figures.

—Of course Senator Short would like to see the figures, and he will. If it has any effect in terms of advancing arguments around the place that one looks at the actual nominal rate and determines an argument on that basis, I think it will be very beneficial for him to look at the figures. I will see that he can do that.

SPEECH.PARA: There were a number of other fairly wild allegations about investment levels. The increase in investment levels in manufacturing last year was reasonably satisfactory on an historical basis. It is not satisfactory in terms of the enormous changes which have to be brought about. I do not pretend that for one moment. But let me make it quite clear that on an historical basis it was a satisfactory level of investment. He kept referring to all those other things which go together in statements like that. It is not possible at this stage in this debate, when looking at these issues, to put them all together. He said that he could not go into all of those things which go together. Some of the things he mentioned were a lack of capital for the management investment company licensing scheme. Is his Party going to increase capital for that scheme? I do not know. That is another thing which would have to be added to the expenditure side of a Howard Budget if that were done. He talked about bureaucracy in the industry councils. I do not think that has been a major problem in those councils. They have made enormous advances in the last two or three years-advances which would be largely lost if that process was not continued or if there was a party in power which was not capable, which it would not be, of continuing that process.

We can go on talking about these things ad infinitum, but what concerns me most is that in terms of matching macroeconomic policy with industry policy it is not sufficient to just take all those taxes which appear to have caused a little bit of pain to particular segments of the community and say `We will get rid of all those and the macro issues will then accord with industry policy much better than they have under this Government'. I do not think anybody out there in industry, if confronted with a serious argument on this issue, would agree with that view.

It is not sufficient to float the argument about comparative taxes, and the issue of investment, of course, is not as superficial as he suggested in the course of his contribution to this debate. Above all, I think it indicates the total unawareness of the substantial changes to the taxation system which have been brought in by this Government, both in respect of marginal rates and imputation-the sort of changes which led the Australian Financial Review to comment at the time on the tax package, for example, that these changes brought about essentially the best regime for investment and the future of productive industry, as distinct from the industries nurtured for years by Liberal governments with the absence of a capital gains tax, and brought about the best environment for productive industry in Australia that we have seen for decades. That is the sort of argument that has to be confronted here and not these sloppy allegations about the fringe benefits tax, for example, being greatly to the detriment, in the medium to long term, of productive activity in the Australian economy.

I intervened at this stage only for the purpose of correcting what seemed to be ideological errors in Senator Short's own argument and also to accommodate Senator Vigor's points that he made at an earlier stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before dealing with the alleged ideological errors that Senator Button, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, referred to in Senator Short's excellent speech-I hope to be able to demonstrate some of the elements of nonsense that Senator Button went on with-I would like to raise some specific matters which emerged from the Senate Estimate Committee questioning of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce which I believe call for some action by this Government. That questioning raised some general questions which apply to many other departments, but I would like to use the responses made by this Department as a general indication of matters of serious concern that this Government has not acted on and must act on. In particular, I draw attention to the additional costs involved in the management of government arising from the much higher level of sick leave required by permanent employees as against the rate of sick leave of temporary staff. I do not know whether the fact that a person is a permanent employee renders that person more prone to illness than a temporary employee, but it is interesting to note that throughout the Commonwealth Public Service there seems to be the strange propensity for permanent staff to be more afflicted by illness, and therefore obliged to take sick leave, than those who are temporary staff. Maybe it is because temporary staff do not have the same feeling of security in their jobs as do the permanent staff.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out, for example, that in the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, when I asked for the percentage of time lost by permanent as against temporary staff on sick leave, this was the answer: For permanent staff 2.41 per cent of their time is lost on sick leave. For temporary staff, as a percentage of total time, sick leave is 1.43 per cent. For those with a mathematical bent, this means that sick leave for permanent staff is 70 per cent worse than for temporary staff. That situation exists also in the Industries Assistance Commission, which comes within this general head. There, when one special case is excluded, the percentage of time lost by casual and contract staff is 1.9 per cent and for permanent staff the figure is 2.5 per cent-a similar disadvantage in cost terms to the Government between permanent and temporary employees. It would seem to me that, following some concerns stated in New South Wales about sick leave in the police force, it is worth the Government examining why there is such an extraordinary 70 per cent difference between the rate of sick leave taken by temporary staff and that taken by permanent staff.

This leads to another problem relating to illness. I asked all sections of the Public Service during Estimates committee hearings what were the reasons for the extraordinarily high level of invalidity retirement from the Commonwealth Public Service. I acknowledge that the Government has quite recently agreed to take some measures aimed at limiting the extraordinary situation that exists in the Commonwealth Public Service relating to retirement through invalidity. Of course, the measures being taken are of a token nature and are subject to the approval, as is almost everything that this Government does, of the trade union movement. I do not expect that approval to be given to those draft proposals. The only significant one is that those people who have retired through invalidity from the Commonwealth Public Service should be obliged to report to the Government what subsequent income they receive in any employment that takes place subsequent to their retirement through invalidity.

I looked at specific sections of the bureaucracy, such as the Australian Customs Service. It is extraordinary that in this Service, as is the case throughout the Public Service, a very large proportion of the retirements through invalidity appear to be related to problems which are difficult to diagnose. This relates, of course, to the whole Public Service. We have seen already that in the Victorian branches of the Commonwealth Public Service the retirement rate through invalidity is double the number of people who retire through reaching retirement age. This is an absolute nonsense. There can be no justification for twice as many people in Victoria retiring through invalidity as do through reaching retirement age. In New South Wales the ratio is exactly the other way around. Twice as many people in New South Wales retire through reaching retirement age as do through invalidity. Is it because of the different code of football that is played in Victoria? Maybe it affects people in some curious way. Maybe it is because of the appalling weather. Who knows what is the cause? But the reality is that some kind of ramp has been going on within the Public Service which is indefensible and inexcusable, which, as I said, involves twice as many people in Victoria retiring through invalidity as those who retire through reaching retirement age. In New South Wales it is the other way around.

In that situation-it is the case in the Australian Customs Service-an unacceptable proportion of people appear to be retiring for reasons that are, as I said, very difficult to diagnose. They involve mental illnesses or bad backs. Once again, when one looks at the difference between, say, Victoria and New South Wales, one establishes that three times as many people retire from the Commonwealth Public Service in Victoria as a result of mental disturbances-neuroses in particular-than retire in New South Wales through neuroses. Yet there are more Commonwealth public servants in New South Wales than there are in Victoria. Once again, is it the football that they play, or is there a clear ramp going on in Victoria relating specifically to falsification of reasons for retirement, particularly in the case of those people aged over 55 who can retire on full benefits, as I understand it, if they can be invalided out? Frankly, the Commonwealth Government must do something to clean up its Victorian operations because they are simply unsupportable.

From the information I have received relating to this Department, I do not know what proportion of retirements through invalidity in the Australian Customs Service, for example, relate to Victoria. But I presume the pattern would be the same. I think it is important to draw to the attention of the Committee the fact that the number and cause of retirements from the Australian Customs Service in 1985-86 are given in a table I have received from the Department, and they total 47. But 23 of them relate to problems of a mental state, bad backs or, of course, repetition strain injury. I will not question whether RSI is more appropriately a psychological or a physical problem. I am unaware of the answer to that. All I know is that it is hard to diagnose and apparently hard to treat.

If we look at the list of 47 people who retired from the Australian Customs Service last year, we find that eight retired through RSI and nine through anxiety depression. It may well be that the Customs Service is operating under a serious amount of tension, but it does seem extraordinary that last year nine people out of a total of 47 retirements should have retired because of anxiety depression. Two people retired because of chronic relapsing paranoid schizophrenia. I must say that I am glad they are not still in the Customs Service. Two retired through anxiety reaction and for other reasons. One person retired through alcoholism and depression, and one through back pain.

I have no comment about the genuineness or otherwise of those people. All I am saying is that it is extraordinary that a great bulk of the number of people who retired from the Australian Customs Service last year did so because of mental conditions. That seems to me to be a far higher proportion of people with neuroses than would exist in the work force. I cannot imagine that such an enormous proportion-22 out of 47 people who retired through ill health-are retiring through mental problems throughout the community. I am certain that that ratio would not exist. Is there something very serious about the conditions of work in the Customs Service? That may well be an issue that the Government should take up. There may be an urgent need to improve working conditions, or there may be a need to look into the matter on another ground.

The other point I want briefly to make is that, if the Government is serious about trying to cut costs-frankly, if it is serious about trying to cut costs it will do something about this invalidity retirement and sick leave matter-it could also look at the question of the unnecessary and self-indulgent expenditure of money on expensive stationery by the mandarins of the Public Service. We in the Senate have all agreed, because of the economic problems facing this nation, to do away with the special embossed letterhead we had. Our letterhead is now simply printed. I notice that Ministers have not shared the enthusiasm of senators to save costs in that way. In fact, in this Department there has been, in my view, a $6,000 waste of money in the current financial year on purchasing special ministerial stationery and envelopes. Such stationery costs about $40 a ream, as opposed to the normal cost of $25 a ream. In 1986-87, I am advised by the Department, in response to my request, the Department expects to spend $16,135 on ministerial stationery and envelopes-of which, by the way, $5,600 is met by the Australian Customs Service. The difference between plain stationery and ministerial stationery is that the ministerial stationery is vergo-typed-that is, with the printing raised-and it is printed on a higher quality paper.

If we are in serious economic trouble, why are we wasting money on expensive stationery? If it is good enough for the senators and members of this Parliament to use ordinary printed paper in order to save money, why do not the Ministers in this place and the departmental heads do likewise? This general question exists throughout the Public Service and throughout the ministerial offices. If the Government is fair dinkum about saving costs, Ministers could look to their own expenditure. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce alone is costing this nation $6,000 just so that he can have some pretty letterhead. I say to the Minister that he can do an awful lot better than that.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, could I have your indulgence for just a couple of moments to respond to something the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, said immediately before the dinner break, when he replied to some matters I raised. He questioned my statement about the inconsistency between the Government's fringe benefits tax and its policy towards the automotive industry. He claimed that there was no evidence that the fringe benefits tax had led to any reduction in employment or activity in the automotive industry.

SPEECH.PARA: For the record, I draw to the Committee's attention that the latest survey of the motor vehicle industry published as recently as last week indicated that the fringe benefits tax is the major cause of the 30.5 per cent drop-a drop of almost one-third-that has occurred in the sale of new commercial and fleet vehicles in recent months. According to the same survey, car dealers estimate that fringe benefits tax payments will add 6 to 8 per cent to the tax on most employers because the fringe benefits tax cannot be claimed as a tax deduction. The survey also pointed out that to date the fringe benefits tax has resulted in a decline of 4,000 workers in car retailing over the survey year and there is a prediction that a further 3,000 workers could be laid off. So, far from the statement made by the Minister before dinner that this tax is not having an effect on the industry being the case, it is patently obvious that it is having a major effect on the industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, encouraged us to put right some of the statements he has made regarding the Opposition's position on the economy and what it has promised it will do when it comes to power. SPEECH.PARA: It is no use Senator Button saying in this place that he does not know where the Opposition will get the money if it abolishes those three major tax gathering benefits to the Government. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we are dealing with the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet I wish to address myself to the question of the way in which legislation is dealt with in this Parliament and the way in which the Government is dealing with legislation at the moment, particularly the habit which is developing within this Government of passing legislation but not moving on to its proclamation. The vote to which one relates this to is that clearly under the provisions in Prime Minister and Cabinet there is responsibility for the funding of the Executive Council and the office of Governor-General.
—You have just anticipated the question I was about to ask you, Senator Puplick.

—Mr Chairman, I was aware that either of your own volition or as a result of prompting from those around you there was some question as to how this matter might be related to the appropriation before the Committee. Nevertheless, the Office of Governor-General, the Executive Council and the responsibility of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet for the establishment of the mechanism by which legislation comes into effect come under this appropriation. The attempt of the Government to make a mockery of the Governor-General's signature on a piece of legislation by putting it before His Excellency to sign into law and then not proceeding to its proclamation is a matter which has come before an Estimates committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Estimates Committee D has drawn the attention of the Parliament to the fact that there has been a development in which a considerable period has been allowed to elapse between the passage of Bills through the Parliament and their proclamation. It draws the attention of the Parliament to two Bills in particular. The Public Lending Rights Bill 1985 was introduced into the House of Representatives on 17 April 1985, passed by the House on 9 May 1985, introduced into the Senate on 9 May 1985, passed by the Senate on 6 December 1985, and assented to by His Excellency on 16 December 1985. That piece of legislation has still not been proclaimed. It affects individuals who have the right to receive payment for items which they have created and which are now within the public lending rights scheme throughout Australian libraries. We were told when the Bill was debated in this chamber that the amendments the Opposition sought to make to the legislation could not be made, that the Bill was an urgent Bill which could not be amended by the Senate in December 1985 because the House of Representatives had adjourned for the year and the Government was not prepared to recall it to deal with amendments which the Senate might have been persuaded to make. I moved those amendments on behalf of the Opposition.

The Australian Democrats were persuaded by the Government's objections that it was important to put this piece of legislation in place, that there was some urgency about it. In December 1985 the amendments we sought would have moved the payment schedule from being gazetted to being made by regulation so that the Parliament could have some scrutiny over those changes. We were told not to proceed with them because the Bill had to be got through the Parliament urgently. It is now November 1986, 11 months later, and it still has not been proclaimed.

A second example is given in the report of Estimates Committee D of the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill. That Bill was introduced in the House of Representatives in November 1985, passed on 18 February 1986, introduced in this chamber on 11 March 1986, passed on 1 May 1986, assented to on 13 May 1986 and is still not proclaimed. This is an Act which affects the rights of individuals who possess items which may or may not fall within the definition of movable cultural heritage property. They find themselves placed in a situation because an Act which was passed some six months ago is still not proclaimed into law. They do not know what their position is because although the Act has been passed, it has not been proclaimed into law. They do not know whether they have the right to export material which is in their control or not because although that may fall outside the ambit of the Act, the Act has not yet been passed. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a list which has been drawn up for me by the Clerk's office showing sections of Acts which have been passed but not yet proclaimed, Acts which have been passed but which have not yet been proclaimed and Acts which have been subject to significant delays from assent to commencement.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I give you examples, Mr Chairman? The Navigation Amendment Act was passed in 1980. Some sections of that Act have still not been proclaimed. The Australian Citizenship Amendment Act 1984, the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984 and the Shipping Registration Amendment Act 1984 were passed and substantial parts of them have still not been proclaimed. I can give the Committee some examples of Acts which have still not been proclaimed in toto. The first of these is the Patents Amendment Act 1984.
