In his second reading speech the Minister said that although the Act did not reflect dramatic changes in law it reflected changes in technology which were taking place and to which Australia had to be a party. In particular the Patents Amendment Act 1984 makes Australia a party to the Budapest Treaty which deals with biotechnology and the patenting of organisms created by biotechnological processes. We were told at the time how important this was for a part of Australia's industrial development.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vigor has a particular interest in these areas. Senator Childs is in the chamber this evening. The Standing Committee on Industry and Trade, of which he is the Chairman, is looking at the development of Australian manufacturing industry. We were told at the time that important sections of the Patents Amendment Act would allow Australia to participate in new biotechnology developments. That legislation was debated in March 1984 in the House of Representatives. It still has not been proclaimed.

There are significant issues involved in the way in which broadcasting is developing at the moment. One of the key areas is the definition of what actually comprises a point to point broadcast. There are very significant issues, not only of broadcasting law but of finance and property, involved in the definition of broadcasting. This matter was supposed to be taken up by amendments which were made in the Copyright Amendment Bill. But the sections of the Copyright Amendment Bill which deal with the definition of broadcasting have not yet been proclaimed. As a result, all of the new broadcasting technologies which involve private broadcasting to clubs, pubs and other organisations and which have a very profound effect upon the nature of broadcasting, are not yet covered because, although this Parliament has passed the necessary Act, this Government has not got around to proclaiming it.

I give only one other example contained in the list which has now been incorporated in Hansard, and that is the Interstate Road Transport Act which took hours and hours of debate in this place, was the subject of a large number of amendments, was passed in 1985, was assented to on 22 November 1985 and which still has not yet been proclaimed. There is nothing unusual about this procedure. The British Parliament has been doing it for a long time. An article in the Economist of December 1981 drew attention to the fact that the British Parliament's outstanding record was that the Children and Young Persons Act of 1969 still had not been proclaimed in that country. The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Children's Act 1975 and the Criminal Law Act 1977 were still unproclaimed in 1981.

One of the most distinguished previous members of this chamber, Senator Peter Rae, sought to draw the attention of the Parliament to this matter some years ago. In 1983 he gave notice of a motion which he proposed to move as an Address to be sent to His Excellency the Governor-General to request him to direct his attention to the habit which this and previous governments had been developing of passing but not proclaiming legislation. Normally under the Acts Interpretation Act, Acts of Parliament should come into operation within 28 days of receiving royal assent. But increasingly, Acts are being written in a way which says that they shall come into effect on a date to be fixed by proclamation. It is not just a matter of assent. It is in fact a matter of the Acts having to appear as having been proclaimed and that proclamation having to be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette.

I put it to the Committee that this is a very serious matter to which the Parliament should address itself. I do not regard this Government as being unusual in its behaviour. Previous governments of my persuasion have been equally at fault in this regard. The various Acts regarding the stand-down of Commonwealth employees-the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act and a number of others-were passed to be held in reserve, as it were, and to be proclaimed at some later date. I regard as very unsound the practice undertaken by governments of putting this Parliament through the process of passing legislation and then holding in pectore, as it were, some sort of secret deal whereby an Act of Parliament will be proclaimed. People in the community who believe that once an Act of Parliament is passed by the Parliament it has in fact become the law of the land are deceived in that it does not become the law of the land even once it is assented to by the Crown's representative because a government can hold, for whatever purposes, that Act in reserve and not proclaim it. I think that is a very unsound constitutional practice. I think it is a very unparliamentary practice. It is one which appears to be developing more and more.

Estimates Committee D looked just within the few portfolios for which it has responsibility and discovered two Acts, both of which are significant in terms of the way in which they impact upon the rights of individual citizens of Australia and both of which have economic consequences for people. I refer to the Public Lending Rights Act and the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act. We find that up to 11 months in one instance and six months in another have elapsed and still those Acts, which have been debated in this Parliament, have not been proclaimed into law. Of those two Acts, the former concerns me more because the Government deceived this Parliament by telling us that it was an urgent Bill which we could not amend because it was urgently required. Yet, 11 months later it has still not been proclaimed into law. I believe that the Parliament ought to take a little more seriously its responsibility in seeing that Acts which it passes actually end up having the force of law; that the law, as the Parliament passes it, is not left in the hands of the executive government to play ducks and drakes with and to proclaim and give effect to by executive fiat after the views of the Parliament have been made known. This is an issue to which I believe the Parliament should address a great deal more attention.

SPEECH.PARA: Another interesting answer that just turned up is the matter of public servants remaining on higher duties for periods of 12 months or more. I can understand this when a staff member goes on leave and will be coming back, but this was the reason given for about 700 of the 10,200 cases detected in the Public Service survey of 2 September 1985. Under 7 per cent of all cases were the result of people going on leave and being temporarily replaced. Nearly 4,400 instances arose because the positions had not yet been filled permanently and slightly more than 4,400 instances arose because someone else was on higher duties allowance. In other words, about one public servant position in every 40 was unfilled for over 12 months at that time. This means we are paying people at the senior level rate when they may only be acting in those positions. This had similar flow-on effects for essential people at lower levels. Again, this suggests that departments have not been in a desperate hurry to fill positions and have been quite prepared to make substantial proportions of their staff available for somebody else's job.

This is another problem that we have to look at in terms of effectiveness in the Public Service. Either it can do with less or there is a problem. Maybe it is padding it up with temporary staff. SPEECH.PARA: The main issue I want to raise tonight is expenditure on official hospitality at state occasions by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. In response to questions I asked in Senate Estimates committee hearings I have now received a note from the Department advising that the expected costs in the current financial year for the papal visit are $802,000 and for the America's Cup, $670,000. I have no problems at all with the $802,000 for the papal visit. It seems to fit in fairly appropriately with the cost of other recent tours. For example, I think the cost of the visit by the Prince and Princess of Wales was $864,000. The Queen's last visit cost about $675,000. The matter that concerns me is the $670,000 relating to the America's Cup. Why is the Government spending $675,000 of taxpayers' money providing hospitality in relation to the America's Cup? We are all aware of the fact that a few years ago, in the euphoria of champagne corks popping, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised $30m of Federal funds towards the America's Cup in the sort of self-indulgence which is totally inappropriate for a man who is supposed to represent the interests of the average Australian. Maybe he was a little light-headed because of the champagne bath he was having; but in the sober light of day it is disgraceful, coming from a government which claims falsely that it is showing restraint and that it has cut government spending. Government spending is going up this year, as everyone knows, in real terms as well as in nominal terms, by about 7 per cent.

We get this phoney nonsense about Government spending being cut, yet we have a classic example of the sort of self-indulgence this Prime Minister, in particular, and this Government practise when they plan to spent $670,000 on official entertainment relating to the America's Cup. I am certain that the people in the western suburbs of Sydney who are facing increasing unemployment and certainly the people in my area, the Illawarra region, where there is a very high unemployment rate, will be overjoyed to know that the Prime Minister is happily spending $670,000 on entertainment and hospitality relating to the America's Cup.

This is fairly typical of the Prime Minister, however, who has decided, as we found out during the Senate Estimates committee hearing when I asked these questions, that there is a special need to do up Kirribilli House. Kirribilli House has for many years been used chiefly for distinguished guests from overseas. That, at least, was the statement made by the previous Prime Minister on 24 September 1976. The final report in May 1979 of the Committee on Official Establishments said:
The Committee believes that Kirribilli House is admirably suited for use as an official guest facility and that such use should be continued in the future.

Instead of being used for that purpose, it is now the Prime Minister's official Sydney residence. He sold his home in Melbourne. He does not like Melbourne any more. He says that there is a much more pleasant view from the foreshores of Sydney Harbour. As a result Kirribilli House has been expropriated, if you like, as the Prime Minister's Sydney residence, at considerable expense to the people of Australia. What concerns me about this is that not only are the running expenses considerable but also major repairs are now required to be done on the building because the Prime Minister says that he needs them. There is no doubt that the building needs something done to it. The 1979 report of the Committee on Official Establishments said:

In many respects Kirribilli House is in poor condition. Almost every room of the building is faulty as a result of poor original foundation work; settling; damp penetration; and outmoded, faulty and inefficient plumbing. Hydraulic, electrical and mechanical services are mostly inadequate, overloaded, unserviceable and some need replacement.

For all of these reasons the Department of Construction, Sydney, was asked to carry out an architectural-engineering survey of the main residence which resulted in a detailed report entitled `Kirribilli House-Structural/Maintenance Report'.
The matters requiring correction were outlined in that report. The Committee-I support its conclusion-then said:
The Committee believes that the principal maintenance recommendations contained in the structural/maintenance report of the Department of Construction should be implemented as soon as possible.

That was said in May 1979. The previous Prime Minister clearly took the view that while it was important that this work be done it was not essential and in terms of priorities other, more important things, should be done with the money belonging to the taxpayer which is entrusted to the Government. As a result, apart from some repairs, guttering, roofing and so on the major structural things were not done because they were not considered to be of sufficiently high priority. That was when Mr Malcolm Fraser was Prime Minister. Now that Mr Hawke occupies Kirribilli House as his personal residence magically this has all become urgent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very urgent.

—As Senator Townley says, it is very urgent indeed. Is it urgent because the Department has provided some additional advice or information? Is it because the Department has pressed the matter? I will outline the response in the Senate Estimates Committee when I asked that question. I asked:

Perhaps the Minister has not noticed that yet. That is why when other arrangements have been made, for example, to pay the former Prime Minister, E. G. Whitlam, extraordinary amounts for matters including five trips to and from Geneva to take part in what could best be described as a talkfest on the Constitution, if the Minister wants to engage in that kind of stuff we will give it to him blow by blow. What I was seeking to do was on a slightly more elevated plane than that on which the Minister is used to debate. I was talking about a specific problem relating to our present crisis. This Prime Minister has chosen this time to spend $1m in a self-indulgent upgrading of his accommodation, plus everything else. Also, he has chosen to involve himself and his Government in entertainment expenses of $670,000 for the America's Cup races in Western Australia. All I have to say to the Minister is that if he cannot distinguish the fact that this kind of self-indulgence is dramatically inappropriate at this time, I can understand how enormously unsuccessful he was in bringing about any cuts in government expenditure this year because, as Minister for Finance, it was his responsibility to reduce spending. All he did was cut what some Ministers wanted to spend and what their projects would have involved spending had they proceeded uncut this year. These, of course, were the projects that were added to by this Government. For example, $2.5 billion of new expenditure programs were added in its first Budget and another $1.3 billion-odd was added in its second Budget.
—Up go the taxes.

—That is absolutely right; paid for by taxes. These were the increased spending items that this Government cut with a great flourish saying `we have cut spending' when in fact Government spending this year under this Minister, who is supposed to be in charge of cutting, is going up by 6.9 per cent and is also increasing in real terms to the highest level ever in Australia's history, after inflation is accounted for. And it is under this Minister. What an extraordinary hide he has to participate in this debate in this way. The reality is that this Government is a self-indulgent government and this Minister pretends to be careful, pretends to be the person who is enforcing restraint upon this Government when in fact he is not doing so. The style of his intervention tonight indicates the full extent of this recognition of his own failure.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a few very short questions concerning the Department of Trade. Firstly, I want to get some indication from the Department of Trade of what measures the Department is currently taking to try to curb our rising invisibles debt. We have been talking about this for some time; that is, trying to get an insurance market, trying to get local transport companies involved, and there does not appear to be any direct action currently in this area. We seem to be being treated as a type of big quarry in the south exporting minerals and possibly some primary produce when they are not completely priced out of the markets by dumping practices of other countries.

SPEECH.PARA: This brings me to the second question, which relates to the new round of General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks with the various developing countries. I would like to know the direct outcome of these talks, which are fairly costly in terms of the budgets of the Department of Trade. Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Peru embassy closure linked to Lima exit
By Ross Peake
The Government of Peru will close its embassy in Canberra, apparently in a direct response to the closure of the Australian Embassy in Lima.
The Peruvian Ambassador, Mr Bedoya Delboy, has told the Federal Government the post will be closed, but has offered to retain a charge d'affaires.
This would be a much lower level of representation than the present mission of an ambassador and two other diplomats.
Peru was a net food importer of meat, milk, grain and oil.
Australian exports to Peru have grown from $3.7 million in 1983 to $14.2 million in 1985, while imports in the same period have fallen from $5.2 million to $4.9 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vigor has raised three matters. As to invisibles, I see his point, so to speak. We are doing our best to increase--
—You can see the invisibles!

—Very good, Senator; you picked it up. We are doing our best to tackle that particular problem, not least in the transport area. It is not a function of the Department of Trade but certainly Mr Peter Morris, the Minister for Transport, has responded with a great deal of vigour to the concern of the Government and Australian traders that not enough is going into Australians bottoms as a result, no doubt, of the notorious difficulties of costs so far as Australian shipping is concerned. A lot of detailed attention is being given to that. Reports are being written and the trade union movement is displaying a lot of interest in adopting a more rational approach to this matter in the interests of expanding Australian shipping generally, which it is acknowledged can only be done in an environment where costs are more competitive than traditionally has been the case. If we can make an impact in transport, a lot else will follow from that.

SPEECH.PARA: There are difficulties on the insurance side because the local reinsurance market is necessarily quite small by international standards. The big risk takers will go on being Lloyds and the major insurance markets overseas; but we will do our best, because we acknowledge the problems in that area, to pick up more of that particular cake rather than seeing it go off-shore. The point also needs to be made about the increasing significance that services are playing in our trade account. That is the other side of the invisibles coin-the selling of Australian services overseas. There is also the obviously increasing role that tourism is playing in attracting funds of that kind. There are many points to be made about that but we acknowledge the force of Senator Vigor's argument.

As to his second concern, I accept gracefully on behalf of Mr Dawkins, the Minister for Trade, the congratulations that the Australian Democrats have offered him for what was a splendid performance on Australia's part and the third group of fair traders-the so-called Cairns group-at Punta del Este. The Uruguay round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is, of course, an extended process which is going to go on, on past precedents, for three or four years. We cannot expect to see any positive results showing up on the board at this early stage. A great deal of negotiation is going on at the moment on establishing the procedural regime within which these various substantive matters will be pursued. Whether at the end of the day we will have anything which could be remotely described as a new international economic order is a matter of some speculation, but it is everybody's hope that we will in fact work quite substantial improvements in the international trade environment as a result of this initiative.

As to the Peruvian Embassy, it is a matter of regret that budgetary priorities forced us to close that very small post. As I recall, it had only two Australian-based officers, both of whom were, I think, Foreign Affairs rather than Trade personnel. There was never an Australian-based trade officer in Peru. There was and will continue to be a locally engaged person on the ground there performing marketing functions. So to the extent that there are opportunities for further trade development there they will continue and have not been put at risk by the closure of that particular post.

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the Department of Trade, I want very briefly to refer to a similar matter to that I raised with other departments, and that relates to stationery. I noted earlier in respect of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce that there is a significant difference between the cost of stationery used by that Minister or the departmental head as against the ordinary letterhead used by the Department. I noted that senators and members of the House of Representatives have stopped using the expensively different vergo-type paper with a raised coat of arms and so on in the cause of economy. I am intrigued to note that this cause is not being pursued in the Department of Trade, as it is not being pursued by all the Ministers in this Government, who maintain the self-indulgence that is set by their Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his Kirribilli House activities.

SPEECH.PARA: I note in the written responses to questions on notice I received from the Department of Trade that the unit cost, based on a ream, for the bond and bank letterhead used in ministerial matters is approximately $44 and for departmental letterhead it is only $8. In other words, the paper that the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) uses is about 5 1/2 times as costly as the paper used by the Department. This kind of self-indulgence is just nonsense at a time when Australia is supposed to be tightening its belt and this Government is talking about restraint. Let us see some restraint from the Ministers who should know better.

Let us see what the difference is between ordinary letterhead and what the Minister insists on having, despite restraint. All the letterheads are in raised printing with black ink. The paper quality is superior to normal bond. Ministerial envelopes have the Minister's name vergo-typed on the front and the crest vergo-typed on the flap. The envelopes are white and the Minister has two different letterheads and `with compliments' slips. This means that in the current year something like $8,000 is going to be wasted on paper that is absolutely unnecessary. The ministerial paper is going to cost something like $10,000. It could be done on ordinary paper with ordinary printing for something like $2,000. That is just one department and one Minister and it spreads throughout the whole of this Government's administration and its bureaucracy.

It is interesting to note the different prices that some departments seem to be able to negotiate for their ordinary letterheads. This is a matter at which I think the Government could have a good look. For example, the Department of Trade says that is can get its ordinary departmental paper for $8 a ream. Austrade, which is another part of the Department-what used to be the Trade Commissioner Service-pays $13 a ream for its standard stationery. However, it pays something like $60 a ream for its ministerial stationery. But ordinary stationery which is used in enormous volumes by the departments of this Government, as those on the receiving end of material from them can testify, costs $8 a ream for the Department of Trade, $13 a ream for Austrade but $25 a ream for the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce-three times as much for ordinary letterhead. What is going on? Is there not an effective purchasing arrangement within this Government to ensure that the departments can get the best deal? Why does the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce pay three times as much for its standard letterhead paper as does the Department of Trade? It is just an extraordinary situation and I cannot see why that question should not be pursued by the Government if, once again, it is genuine in seeking to cut its expenditure. For heaven's sake, three times the price from one department to another is just untenable.

I hope that these activities of the Coalition Waste Watch Committee, of which I am Chairman, drawing attention to the sorts of things that the Government should have seen for itself will bring about some genuine action by the Government to cut unnecessary expenditure. This appears to be a small amount of money, $8 a ream, but, considering how many reams of paper are used by the ever expanding bureaucracy under this Government-it has appointed 12,000 extra public servants-what appears to be a small amount certainly ends up being a very substantial volume of money paid for by the Australian taxpayer.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise four short points in regard to the Department of Science. The first relates to the management of intellectual property within Australia. Despite considerable questioning of the Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office of the Department of Science during the Estimates committee hearing, I was unable to ascertain any type of policy position on the future plans for developing the handling of intellectual property. Currently there are very large backlogs in patents and design registration. The Department has closed down its information technology transfer unit, which described to various industrial people what patents were available.

SPEECH.PARA: It would be very useful if the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) could indicate to me what use a patent system is if we cannot have reasonable retrieval services on patents. Is this not a case of handing over the whole area to the patent attorneys, rather than using modern technology? It seemed to be a step in the right direction to have a unit which could answer general questions on intellectual property in an effective way. That was brought in with great fanfare in 1984, and closed down with little or no noise in this Budget. I am very interested in knowing what plans there are for providing that type of service to industry. I know that it does not come under the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. It remains with the Department of Science. That may be why it has been cut out.

The second item about which I would like to ask concerns Antarctica, which comes under the Department of Science. Maybe the Minister, with his knowledge of foreign affairs, can help me. I have had reported to me that the United States is planning to split its operations in Antarctica into civil and military operations. This seems very strange, considering the nature of the Antarctic Treaty, which forbids military activities. It would be quite useful to get some comment on what knowledge the Australian Government has of this and whether we are co-operating with that type of activity.

The third question relates to the cutting down of meteorological services. It seems to me to be wrong to cut down on meteorological services throughout Australia. We have enough problems predicting our weather over the whole continent without cutting down the number of stations we have. We do not seem to be replacing the services with adequate satellite services. Is the Minister convinced that the safety of aircraft and the long term development of our planning for weather are being properly managed by closing down various meteorological sites?

The fourth item I would like to raise concerns the very dramatic cuts in the marine sciences and technologies grants scheme. There have been cuts of approximately 25 per cent this year, which is the major slash to the Science budget. Considering that we have in the Great Barrier Reef some of the most important areas of reef in the world, this is having a devastating effect in those northern areas. I have been deluged with letters from as far north as James Cook University-I have received three or four letters from various people who have been affected by this grant-down to the Australian Museum's Division of Vertebrate Zoology in Sydney and the University of Tasmania, which have been affected by the cuts in this scheme. What has actually been done to supplement the marine sciences and technologies grants scheme? What is the rationale behind these cuts? In order to cut down on the time of debate, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard one letter, as an example, from Associate Professor J. S. Lucas, of James Cook University, who sets out the points of argument in this matter much more cogently than I could, without taking up a lot of the Committee's time.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
JAMES COOK UNIVERSITY OF NORTH QUEENSLAND
SCHOOL OF BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES
Department of Zoology
30 September 1986
Senator David Vigor,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Vigor,
Re: Marine Sciences and Technologies Grants Scheme

I write from a personal viewpoint as a tropical marine scientist, with several decades of research experience. This is to express my concern at the cut of approximately 25% in allocations to the Marine Sciences and Technologies Grants Scheme in 1987, and suggestion of abolition of the MSTGS.
To explain this concern, I will describe the changes that I have seen in marine science over the past decade.

I was appointed a Lecturer in Zoology at James Cook University, Townsville, in 1968. My first trip to the Great Barrier Reef was on a Hayles ferry chartered for the day by the Townsville Shell Club. It was only after a series of monthly Shell Club trips to the reef had been cancelled because of rough weather.

Under these conditions, there was no point in attempting to study animals on the Reef and I lowered my sights and worked on the local estuarine and mangrove fauna, which only required dinghies and modest field equipment.
The postgraduate student projects that I supervised during this era were in this inshore environment, for the same reason.

About this time, the Australian Conservation Foundation published a review of ``The Future of the Great Barrier Reef''. Professor Bill Stephenson (then Professor Zoology at University of Queensland) wrote the chapter on Marine Biology and referred to the Royal Society Expedition to the Great Barrier Reef (ca. 1929!) as the most comprehensive study of reef organisms. In other words, the most comprehensive study of the Great Barrier Reef had been made by a group of English men and women forty years before.

This situation has totally changed, as you are aware. It would not be presumptuous to say that Australia is now at the forefront of marine research on coral reefs. This was evident at the interdisciplinary fifth International Coral Reef Congress in Tahiti last year. It has been recognised by awarding the Sixth International Coral Reef Congress to Australia, specifically to James Cook University, in 1988.

The change in Australia's status in coral reef research has come about partly through the Australian Institute of Marine Sciences and Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority; through the establishment of further marine stations on the GBR and research vessels. However, Australia's eminence in coral reef research is also based on University research and the training of top-class graduates in this field. Australia's eminence will only continue as the Universities produce top-class graduates.

The provision of MSTGS funding has been the major factor in lifting the quality and quantity of marine research in Australian Universities and coral reef research in particular. Reef research is necessarily expensive due to logistical factors and first class research requires appropriate equipment. However, in terms of the money put in versus the research output and status for Australia that have resulted, it has been money very well spent.

My own research programs reflect the changes that have occurred in the past decade. They are now directed to animals that are characteristic of coral reefs: Crown-of-thorns starfish and giant clams. I supervise five Ph.D. students and one M.Sc. student who are working on coral reef animals. Both research programs that I am involved with, population dynamics of Crown-of-thorns starfish and giant clam mariculture, are multidisciplinary and involve international collaboration. The former is funded by MSTGS, the latter by the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. The giant clam mariculture study could equally well be funded by MSTGS, as mariculture is one of the nominated research areas for support by MSTGS.

If the MSTGS funding is taken away and we go back to university research budgets of a few thousand dollars a year, we go back to working on the shore again. One can still do quite interesting research on shores. However, coral reef science is where the action is and Australia has the greatest coral reef complex in the world. It would be a tragedy for Australia to lose its recently-gained pre-eminent position in this field. This will not happen immediately, if MSTGS funding is withdrawn; but as University research and graduate training is weakened, this will in time be reflected in the whole research enterprise.
Yours sincerely,
J. S. LUCAS
Associate Professor in Zoology

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. I seek some information from the Minister on what is being done to keep up our excellent reputation in marine science, in the light of these 25 per cent cuts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vigor has raised four points. As to the first point in regard to intellectual property and the operations of the Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office, particularly with regard to getting information of a retrieval kind, all I can say is that increased resources are being applied to the backlog which exists in this area. It is acknowledged that it is a difficult problem and will take time to resolve; but people are not indifferent to, or ignorant of, it. Senator Vigor's views will no doubt be taken, as always, closely into account. As to Antarctica and the suggestion that the United States is planning to split its civil and military operations, I do not have any information on that, either wearing my Minister Assisting the Minister for Foreign Affairs hat or in my current task of conveying the views of the Department of Science. I will endeavour to find out about it, but that may be a question Senator Vigor might care to pursue in other ways. As to the winding back, allegedly, of meteorological stations and meteorological activity, there has been a rationalisation, I am told, which has proceeded in this area but it is not one that will reduce in any way the meteorological services that are provided. It is a matter of doing things in a different and more cost efficient way.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the final point about marine science, there has been a cutback, again as part of the general budgetary discipline with which we are all familiar, by way of direct grants of various kinds in that area. But I am told and, indeed, can assert from my own departmental experience, that there has been a steady increase over the years, and again this year, in the funding that is by all means made available to marine science. I refer in particular to such avenues for expenditure on marine science as the Bureau of Mineral Resources and the Rig Seismic continental margins program. I am not in a position to give any specific information about what precisely is happening so far as marine and environmental science is concerned, about which Senator Vigor demonstrates, in common with his Party, a particular passion. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a different matter with regard to the Department of Science. It relates to the Department's liability to fringe benefits tax. The Department was asked whether it had allocated funds to cover this new tax when the Estimates committee hearings were held, I think in September. At that stage the Department advised the Committee that total liability to pay fringe benefits tax was estimated at $823,500 for the current financial year. That figure excluded the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, for which there is another $352,000. So between those two alone, about $1.2m in fringe benefits tax was to be paid. We asked for details of this. The Department responded that the amount of $1.2m would be reduced following what it called technical amendments to the FBT legislation announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Some technical amendments! They will reduce that amount on average, I think, by something like 10 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: As I read the legislation it seems that total collections will go down by only 10 per cent. I presume that that is the sort of incidence that will take place with this Department; so the Government will still be paying well over $1m to itself at great administrative cost from its left hand pocket to its right hand pocket. As the Department of Science takes money voted to it by the Parliament but, of course, raised in taxes from the people of Australia, it puts it in its pocket and then takes it out and gives it to the Australian Taxation Office. It is simply another way of raising money from the taxpayers of Australia but it is doing it in this nonsensical and administratively very expensive way. As I have said, $1.2m is being taken from the Government's left hand pocket and put into its right hand pocket and clerks and forms and heaven knows what will be involved in performing this charade. The Department of Science is only one of many departments involved. I raised this matter because the figures I have here, at least, are of some substance.

When we asked why this money was being spent, the details of it and how many people were involved, the Department said that it found it difficult to answer those questions although it did say that fringe benefits provided to departmental officers fall within the following categories: Cars, expense payments-that is official phones-living away from home allowances, housing, entertainment and other fringe benefits such as reunion fares. The number of members of the Department who receive fringe benefits will vary annually and no specific details for the 1986-87 financial year are available. As an example, officers in remote locales are entitled to travel to their home stations while on annual recreation leave and this will attract fringe benefits tax. However, specific details on the number of officers utilising this entitlement will not be known until those officers apply for leave.

The reason I raise this matter is that the recipients of benefits which are subject to the fringe benefits tax in the Department are not tax cheats or all the unpleasant things that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has said in the past should relate to people who are in this category. He said that whenever the Opposition has sought to point out absurdities in the fringe benefits situation it is defending tax cheats. Is the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) seriously suggesting that employees of the Department of Science and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, with $1.2m involved in fringe benefits tax, are the sorts of tax cheats who the Minister quite improperly alleges are the only people who are now disadvantaged by this legislation which the Opposition has promised to get rid of lock, stock and barrel? This Government cannot pretend that there is anything sensible at all in applying this kind of tax to public servants who, for heaven's sake, are not ripping off the system.

The explanation in the Department of Science's documents about why this tax is paid seems to reflect exactly the sorts of considerations that apply right throughout the private sector. It seems only sensible that these amounts should be paid and why on earth Senator Walsh should suggest that anyone who speaks up on behalf of people who get allowances-for example, living away from home allowances, reunion fares and so on-should be regarded as a tax dodger and a tax cheat I do not know, except for one simple thing. The Minister has set out on a pattern of personal abuse of the Opposition. Whenever we point out anomalies or stupidities in the fringe benefits tax legislation, such as the administrative cost of pursuing the Department of Science for the tax, his sole response has been: `You are trying to protect tax cheats'. Producing evidence about the Department of Science having to pay this tax demonstrates how totally false the Minister for Finance's arguments are and how totally inappropriate and improper his attacks on the Opposition have been when we have simply sought to point out what these matters really are and what this tax is about. For example, in the CSIRO, where highly skilled people are employed, $352,000 relates to the fringe benefits tax in this way: Official cars garaged privately $205,000, employee housing $110,000, official telephones about $10,000, entertainment $2,800, reunion visits-that is, after away from home posting-$12,000 and education costs and overseas postings about $10,400. Good heavens, are the recipients of such benefits tax cheats?

I now deal very briefly with the matter I have raised in respect of other departments and that is the extraordinary proportion of invalidity retirements from the Public Service relating to conditions which are very difficult to diagnose. For example, in the Department of Science there were 24 invalidity retirements last year of which 14 related to difficult to diagnose matters or clearly diagnosable neurotic matters. Of the 24 retirements three were due to repetitive strain injury, four to anxiety, one to stress, three to back injuries, one was psychiatric and two were due to depression. That kind of proportion, as I mentioned in relation to some other departments, is totally unsustainable. Something like 14 out of the 24 retirements are in the categories I have outlined. In the CSIRO, of the 43 who retired through invalidity something like 25 had conditions that were fairly difficult to diagnose. For example, eight out of the 43 who retired from the CSIRO had psychiatric conditions, 13 had bone degeneration and four repetitive strain injury. What is going on with the Public Service? Is it becoming overwhelmingly neurotic? Why are we having this extraordinary number of retirements due to neuroses and other psychiatric problems? If it relates to the nature of the persons by whom such people are employed perhaps I could understand it but it seems that this has gone beyond the bounds of reason. The Government really has to start doing something positive to stop this incredible nonsense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise two matters under the appropriation from the Department of Science. I very strongly support the remarks Senator Michael Baume made. SPEECH.PARA: The two matters I want to raise are, firstly, the extent to which public money is improperly expended in the Department of Science in the promotion of the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones). Jones, Minister for Science, published by the Australian Government Publishing Service. It is a simple advertisement for Mr Jones. No other Minister in the Commonwealth Government has seen it necessary to produce a booklet of his own speeches at public expense.
