They told us that there had been an initial run of 1,531 copies at a sum of $2,778.31 followed by a reprint of 1,031 copies for an additional $1,814.98. What they could not tell us was how many had been sold.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many copies of your book Liberal Thinking were sold? How did the best seller go?

—Not only did it certainly outsell Living by our wits but also it did not involve the misuse of public expenditure. Nor, indeed, will the next one. I am sure that Senator Evans would be perfectly prepared to claim that none of his own publications, in attempting to advance the political cause and the political ideology which he espouses, was produced by the use of public moneys for that purpose. I am sure to that extent Senator Evans would have been outraged if somebody had suggested that Labor Essays should have been financed by Commonwealth expenditure. Nevertheless, the publication of Mr Jones, putting forward not a statement about Australian science policy but a series of ideological statements about the way in which government policies should be developed, was paid for by public funds. It is indicative, I suppose, of the way in which this Government operates that, when one then looks at the funding provided for the Australian Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office, which is provided for in these estimates-Senator Archer raised this by way of question today; I have previously raised exactly the same point with Senator Button-one sees that, despite all of the Government's protestations about the importance of the development of technological information throughout Australia, one of the decisions taken has been the closing down of the technology information function of the Australian Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office.

SPEECH.PARA: A report was produced by the Industrial Property Advisory Committee, the Government's primary advisory body on the question of patent legislation, in August 1986. The report was entitled `Patent Information for Smaller Australian Enterprises'. That report made the point very strongly that small business in Australia was very much dependent on access to information which it received in terms of patent information through the activities of the Australian Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office. If one looks at the 1984-85 report of that Office one will see the following under the heading `Technology Information Branch Activities':

The potential uses of patent information are many and varied. It was an awareness of this fact, together with the realisation that the information potential of the patent system is a sadly under-utilised resource, that led in 1984 to the creation of the Technology Information Branch . . . within the Patent Office.

That report goes into considerable detail about the amount of information provided, particularly to entrepreneurial small business in Australia which cannot afford its own resources in terms of patent information, which cannot afford the fairly high fees which are charged by specialist patent attorneys around the country and which previously had access to the technology information branch of the Patent Office. Yet that has been closed down.

We found when dealing with estimates on a previous occasion that trade mark applications, for instance, take up to two years to handle, that the pressures on the Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office is very considerable and that, instead of taking steps to improve access to information and the ability of small business in particular to get access to this information, the Government has acted to close down the technology information function of the Office, contrary to the reports which it has had from its own primary advisory group, the Industrial Property Advisory Committee, and contrary to the reports which it has previously had from the Australian Science and Technology Council and a number of others.

Senator Button gave me an answer on 23 September 1986 indicating that the reason this was done was really that, to all intents and purposes, the Government thought it could make some savings without engaging in any considerable analysis of the impact of making this decision. The Minister, in terms of responding to me on behalf of the Minister for Science, put it very much in these terms: In view of the necessity of reducing Commonwealth expenditure the Government decided that the technology information function of the Australian Patent Office would cease. Yet Senator Button, who gave me that lengthy answer on 23 September, dodged the question today. He told Senator Archer that he did not know anything about the subject and therefore was not prepared to answer Senator Archer's detailed question, despite having previously given me that information.
One can look at another Government publication. The publication `Overseas Trading' of October 1986 under the heading `Patent files offer key' states:
Patent files are one of the best sources for exporters and high-tech companies wanting to keep up with technological and market developments.

It goes on to say how they can keep up with these developments by plugging into the technology information branch of the Australian Patent Office. But, of course, by the time this publication, which I think is an official publication of the Department of Trade, was out the Government had sabotaged that undertaking or that particular piece of advice given by the Department of Trade itself.

I simply draw attention to the fact that here we have the opportunity to balance the Government's priorities in these matters. The technology information service provided by the Patent Office is cut out and eliminated as a cost saving measure in the Department of Science. But at the same time money has been expended to put the Minister's speeches in booklet form for propaganda purposes. If people want to weight up what are the priorities of the Hawke Labor Government in terms of the Department of Science, they should well consider the closing down of the technology information branch of the Patent Office at the same time as public funds have been expended to put out runs of the Minister's speeches. This is a clear indication to the Australian scientific community of where this Government's priorities in science actually lie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of issues have been raised. I think the fringe benefits tax one raised by Senator Michael Baume is an old chestnut. The only quick point I would make there is that the requirement for departments to fund FBT payments out of their own departmental budgetary allocations without compensatory top-ups where discretionary payments are involved does amount to a discipline clearly on the department to haul back the area of perhaps such discretionary payments. Even if the revenue is not a net loser at the end of the day, even if the balance sheet comes out in the way that Senator Baume describes, the whole thing is not a complete nonsense; it does have an element of discipline about it.
—Are you suggesting that you are going to cash them in?

—I do not want to get into the endless discussion but there are forms of allowance that presumably would be taxable as fringe benefits that are of a discretionary character when people are out in the field doing various things. Some things, such as housing for officers in remote areas and so on, are clearly non-discretionary. The Budget allocation makes provision for that. But to the extent that payments that would be taxable in a private sector context are discretionary, it has to come out of departmental funding and, as such, there is an incentive on the department either not to make the payment at all or to find some other way of doing it, which is clearly difficult in a Public Service salary environment.

SPEECH.PARA: Beyond that, the arguments are the familiar ones about the difficulty of distinguishing between some categories of allowance or benefit that are necessary incidental to the course of one's employment, on the one hand, and those which are in the nature of a perk on the other. It is enormously difficult in practice to distinguish between those. That is why the categories of the fringe benefit application have tended to be fairly broad ranging. Of course it is the case that what have been described as unintended consequences, or perhaps the possible overreach of some of the initial formulae, have been cut back by the Government's recent decisions. That is not reflected in these figures now before honourable senators. They will be clarified by the time we get to the Supplementary Estimates, and I have no doubt that the amount here identified as a FBT payment will be much reduced as a result.

As to invalidity retirements, I think Senator Michael Baume has perhaps been a little sweeping in his demonstration of prejudices about anxiety, stress, depression, psychiatric disease, repetition strain injury and all the rest, which he sweepingly castigates, at least by inference, as try-ons and shonkiness of one form or another, ignoring the whole course of twentieth century medical science, which does acknowledge most of those conditions to be real and genuinely debilitating.

TALK.START.PARA: —In these proportions throughout the community?

—Well, in cases where they do exist. As to whether these proportions are excessive, I am advised that this is a matter for a Commonwealth medical officer's determination. It is not something done at a departmental level. If there happens to be a higher incidence of stress, anxiety, depression, psychiatric disease and RSI in the Department of Science than elsewhere, there may be various explanations for that. I do not believe, however, that they have to do with Senator Puplick's point about the excessively visible presence of the Minister. The rationale for that particular expenditure on a booklet is not, of course, anything so crude as vulgar self-promotion on the part of the Minister. If he should be tempted to engage in that, he can do it for free without the need to incur public funds expenditure in the process. The rationale for the booklet was simply to generate interest among as many sections of the Australian community as possible. Mr Barry Jones's speeches on national science issues clearly generate community interest with admirable force, vigour, clarity and perception and, as such, should be an occasion for congratulation that the Commonwealth is spending its money on such things rather than on publications which might not satisfy that description.

SPEECH.PARA: As to Senator Puplick's concern about patent information, these concerns are the subject of discussion at pages 801 and 802 of Estimates Committee A report and there is nothing much I can add to what was said there. There is a recognition of the need to have information services flowing in this area if the patent system is to work effectively. We believe that information is still flowing, notwithstanding some budgetary cutbacks, which are acknowledged. To the extent that there are problems, we are happy to try to do something about them.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
GROUP B
Department of Community Services
Proposed expenditure, $468,642,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services will know that I have given notice of a few questions. I do not expect those to be answered tonight. I was wondering whether the Minister could give me the answers in writing at a convenient time.

—(Tasmania-Minister for Community Services) (9.53)-Certainly. I have not had time to get all the answers tonight. I could probably give some of them but, as the honourable senator says, it is probably better that I do them properly in writing in the next couple of days.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Community Services has gone some of the way towards actually saving money along the lines I have been suggesting that other departments should do. To that extent I commend the Minister for Community Services for encouraging his departmental Secretary to stop the nonsense of having a specially embossed logo and so on on his letterhead. This is now differentiated from general departmental stationery only by the inclusion of the word `Secretary' as the top line of the address. If only the Minister himself would follow that lead given by his Secretary because his ministerial stationery has the departmental logo embossed and we have discovered from the other departments that this costs between four and five times as much as the other letterhead. It appears from this answer that the Minister will be spending this year $55,000 on his ministerial letterhead. If he were to adopt the same sort of restraint that other senators and members of parliament have adopted in moving away from embossed letterheads to ordinary printed letterheads, instead of costing $55,000 it would be something like $15,000 at the most. So we have $40,000 being spent on self-indulgence by this Minister. It is part of a general trend of all Ministers in this Government to preach restraint for everyone but themselves. While I commend the Secretary to the Department for his restraint, particularly in view of the large volume of paper being used by this Department, I recommend that the Minister follow the lead of his departmental head.

SPEECH.PARA: The number of invalidity retirements in this Department is increasing at a disturbing rate. I have dealt with other departments and complained about the high proportion of invalidity retirements as against age retirements. In the latest year, 1985-86, the Department had 11 age retirements but 12 invalidity retirements-one more than reached retirement age. Of those 12, something like seven related to ailments that are difficult to diagnose-in other words, more than half. Three were stress and anxiety, two were mental illness, one was RSI and one was depression.

The point I want to make is that in this financial year the proportion will be worse. There are expected to be 17 age retirements compared to 22 invalidity retirements in this Department. I wonder why this is so, and I will be interested if the Minister can advise us why it is so. It does seem to relate to the fact that the Department previously had many permanent temporaries working in it. For example, of the 1,455 people working in the Department last year about 1,086 were employed as short term temporaries under the Public Service Act. This short term temporary situation is to be reduced in the current year and the number of full time people will increase. I do not know whether, when we get full time people in these departmental situations, we end up with a far higher invalidity or, as we saw in some other departments, sickness ratio. It seems to me that this Department should examine the problem because in the coming year it will face more people retiring through invalidity than retiring through reaching retirement age. Whenever that situation exists, surely it should be a signal to the Minister in charge that at least something should be done. I am not accusing any of the people involved of anything. All I am saying is that that ratio does seem to be inappropriate. If the level of age retirements in the Public Service is so low that the number of invalidity retirements far exceeds it, something is wrong within the Public Service or within those individual departments. I urge the Government to do something to fix this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry Senator Michael Baume believes that I am self-indulgent because I have embossed paper used for correspondence in my office. I could not care less whether it is embossed or not, and I am sure he realises that. The fact that it is embossed means that I have no desire to throw out all the embossed stuff.
—Is this what you are spending this year?

—Hold your horses. The honourable senator gets up here and yaffles on, and does not want to listen to anybody's answer. I point out to him that in the Estimates Committee there were two Liberal senators who said that they believed that Ministers' correspondence should be embossed. I did not agree with them. I could not care less whether my correspondence is embossed or not. I am sorry that I, as a Minister, do not take notice of whether it will be embossed next year or not. To keep Senator Michael Baume happy I will ensure that any further correspondence paper I use is not embossed. I could not care less about it. If it will keep him happy and enable him to sleep better at nights I will not use that paper.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason that there are such a large number of short term temporaries in my Department is that it was a new department. In establishing it we did not get the full number of people from the pre-existing department. We have short term temporaries and in future years that will decrease. The fact that there are a large number of invalidity retirements in the Commonwealth Public Service is well known to this Government and is well known particularly to my colleague the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). We intend to do something about it. I merely make the point that it is nothing new. It has been going on far too long. It existed under previous governments and we will do something about it. The estimates for future invalidity retirements in my Department, in the strange way that this system operates, were provided by the Public Service Board. I will seek an explanation from it to get an answer for Senator Baume.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs
Proposed expenditure, $169,955,350.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have given the Minister for Community Services some questions which he could perhaps answer for me in writing. I take up one point regarding invalidity. The Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) will remember that the invalidity figures in the estimates for retirements, particularly for the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, were greater than those for his own Department of Community Services, and that we talked about the extraordinary number of cases of invalidity retirement that occurred in this particular Department. The Minister has just said that this is nothing new, that it was the case under previous governments, and that he and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) intended to do something about it. I refer the Minister to an answer I have just received which gives the ratios in the following order: In 1980-81 there were four retirements on invalidity grounds versus 17 on age; in 1981-82 there were 17 each; in 1982-83 there were 11 invalidity retirements versus 17 on age. This Government came to power in 1983. From then on there was a reversal. In 1983-84 there were 10 invalidity retirements and five on age; in 1984-85 there were 18 invalidity retirements and 12 on age; and in 1985-86 there were 22 invalidity retirements and eight on age. It seems as though that figure is increasing. I am not blaming the Government; I am just pointing out to the Minister that there is an increase. I am delighted to know that he will make some inquiries because, like him, I was very concerned about the numbers in this particular Department.

SPEECH.PARA: In the answers I got on repetition strain injuries, of 44 cases reported in 1985-86, six retired on invalidity grounds at a cost to the public of $93,480. The answer said that this reflected a 54 per cent decrease in cases over 1984-85 and a 37 per cent decrease in costs. Those six people were fairly young-27, 29, 33, 55 and 56 years of age. Can the Minister tell me what checks are made on, say, the 27, the 29 and the 33-year-olds? If these people retire on the ground of invalidity due to RSI, what checks are made to ensure that they do not take up other work? I would have thought that someone with RSI could perhaps be moved to another job within the Department. If this were unable to be done-as it obviously was-what check is made on these people and how often? What checks are made, say, on the 27-year old who retires for life on RSI grounds?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Walters pointed out from those figures, most of the changes in invalidity retirements, which she talked about, have been due in recent years to repetition strain injury. There has been a gradual increase in the number. One can make the sort of comment about RSI that I heard Senator Puplick make-I think it was his voice I recognised-and joke about kangaroo paw and other things and therefore imply that these people are malingering, or one can take the view that in fact something in the method of work causes such an increase in RSI. There may be inadequate treatment or, in fact, absolutely incorrect treatment. But whatever it is-and most people believe that a combination of physical and psychological factors is involved-I do not think it really helps for remarks to be made such as those made by Senator Puplick, but then it is a free country. Those people who are invalided out-and I must say, as I said before, that I share Senator Walters's concern that people are invalided out at such an early age in such a condition-are reviewed at least annually to see about their fitness for future work. That review is done on people by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, as it is done on all people who are invalided out under the Commonwealth employees compensation legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walters said that there has been considerable variation in the years from 1980 to 1986. There was a sudden and dramatic increase from 1980-81 to 1981-82. I certainly would not imply that that was due to the Government in power at the time, any more than the honourable senator would imply that any increase was due to another government at another time. RSI is a problem and no one is pretending that it is not. Certainly in some departments, including my own, there seems to be a greater success rate of treatment and rehabilitation than there has in the past. One wonders whether it is a similar sort of thing that occurred when the steel nib was introduced and when the typewriter was introduced. We will just have to see. I do not think it is very sensible to do as Senator Puplick did and imply that all people with RSI are suffering from some condition involving malingering.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of invalidity retirement to which the Minister has just referred and which Senator Walters raised prompted Estimates Committee B to express in its report to the Senate a little concern about information provided to it by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It noted in its report:

SPEECH.PARA: During its examination of proposed expenditure for the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Committee was informed that the ratio of invalidity to age retirements during 1985-86 was 1.7 to 1.
This is very high indeed. The report went on:
Information subsequently provided to the Committee by the Department indicates that this evidence was incorrect and that the ratio was in fact 2.75 to 1.
Almost 3 : 1. It is incredible that that ratio should exist. There are three times as many people retiring through invalidity than through reaching the retirement age. The report continued:
The Committee was further advised that the number of officers retiring on invalidity grounds has exceeded the number who retired--
as Senator Walters said-
on age grounds since 1983-84.
It noted that a similar situation also exists in the Department of Health, the Department of Community Services and the Department of Social Security. The report continued:

The Committee was also informed that under current arrangements there is a significant incentive for officers to be retired on invalidity grounds prior to their planned retirement age. The Committee wishes to express its concern about this matter and informs the Senate that it will continue to monitor the situation at future Estimates Committee hearings.

As Chairman of the Waste Watch Committee, I am overjoyed that the Committee's report to the Senate makes that statement because there is no doubt that the cost to the nation in invalidity retirement payments, which totals something like $350m a year, clearly has been boosted by extraordinarily large proportions of public servants retiring on invalidity grounds from individual departments and, as I mentioned earlier, in individual States, particularly Victoria. Unfortunately, we cannot tell in each of the departments where the bulk of these curious invalidity retirements take place. The point the Committee made that under current arrangements there is a significant incentive for officers to be retired on invalidity grounds prior to their planned retirement age needs to be stressed. That does not necessarily mean that the officers themselves seek to be retired on invalidity grounds. It may well be that managers within the bureaucracy find it a convenient way of getting rid of people they do not want. This concerns me. It may well be a very expensive way-expensive for the taxpayer-of getting rid of officers of the Public Service who are no longer required by management.

Part of the reason, for example, for the curiously high Victorian figures may well be a consistent trend towards moving officers of the Public Service from departments centred in Melbourne to Canberra. A lot of the neuroses we keep hearing about may arise from the fact that the thought of going to Canberra makes people sick. Perhaps they would rather stay in Melbourne and be invalided out than make the trip up here and have to live in this environment. The reality is that, whether it emerges from the officers initiative or whether it is a convenient method used by management to get rid of surplus people, it ends up being a massive additional cost burden on the taxpayers of Australia and it should be stopped. I am glad that the Minister has expressed some concern about the issue in a responsible way. I can assure him that my activities on behalf of the Waste Watch Committee in pointing out the facts are equally responsible.

Initially, the Department made a significant error about the ratio of invalidity to age retirements. This leads me to another question, which was raised in the report of Estimates Committee A but which is relevant to this matter nonetheless. The report said that during the hearings on the 1986-87 Estimates the Committee noted a wide discrepancy in the capacity of officials to provide an appropriate level of information in response to questions from honourable senators. It stated that this was observable both within the same Department and within different departments. I underline the merit of the point made in the Senate Estimates Committee A report that there are far too many instances where either the wrong information or no information is provided, with the result that one has to rely on questions on notice, which in many instances one cannot pursue, even though one would think that the public servants should be well briefed on the subjects concerned. We have to recognise that there are continuing problems across a whole range of Public Service departments relating to the question of invalidity and age retirements, brought up by the Estimates Committee B report. I assure the Minister that I will be encouraging him, or his successor after he goes on to greater things, to do what he can to improve the performance of his Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to follow up some fluctuations in staffing in the Department which were revealed by questions asked in the Estimates committee hearings regarding the number of temporary staff in each of the sub-programs on the last day of May, June and July this year. The program budgeting system has meant that it is rather difficult to get out costing figures. I noted, particularly in regard to this Department, that in one or two places the program budget did not balance. However, an explanation for this was given at the Estimates committee hearing. Numbers of temporary staff in the Department dropped markedly at the end of June, which is when the official statistics on the number of temporary staff are collected. I believe that that must have had some impact on the operations of the Department. Quite a few more people were taken on in July. Post-arrival services and temporary staff numbers were back to the May level by July. These statistics were incorporated at the time of the examination of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet estimates for the Public Service. I asked the question of Senator Walsh but did not receive an answer.

SPEECH.PARA: The areas of policy co-ordination and management and office support lost 28 temporary staff in June and then picked up six in July. It seems as though very large numbers of staff are completing specific tasks outlined in contracts. This may be an attempt to circumvent unrealistic staff limits. I would be very pleased to get some explanation from officers of the Department as to why this phenomenon is occurring. I would like an idea of why such large numbers of contract staff are needed, especially in the policy co-ordination, management and office support areas.

The additional information to the Committee indicated that the area offices of Albury-Wodonga, Rockhampton and Launceston were closed on 30 September this year. It also stated that operations at Newcastle, Wollongong and Geelong are under consideration for closure. I would like some information on where those deliberations currently stand and what offices can expect to remain open in regional areas. People in regional areas will be put to greater cost by these closures. Will the Government be taking any action on the Minister's suggestions to his ethnic communities that he will consider a study of extending the 008 telephone service to his Department, so that people in those areas can ring through, and will he provide an advertising campaign to advertise the service? Will the Government be taking any steps to ensure that sensitivity to local conditions is not lost within the bureaucracy which is sometimes fairly remote?

I would also like to follow up a question that was asked by Senator Peter Baume regarding statistics on international travellers. During the last financial year over a quarter of a million more travellers arrived in Australia than in the previous year. The number of travellers departing Australia was about 160,000 more than the number for the previous year. There are a variety of reasons why more travellers might have stayed in Australia but it is not at all clear how the excess of arrivals over departures would increase from 40,000 in 1984-85 to nearly 140,000 in 1985-86. I would be very pleased if the Minister or members of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs could give some indication as to how that has happened.

Just recently in Western Australia there was a long-running case of Majid Fardsavar, who was under threat of deportation to Iran even though he was linked with a general in the former Shah's army and was thought by some people to be in great personal danger as a result. An extraordinary run of departmental stonewalling and imperviousness came to an end when Mr Justice Toohey granted interlocutory relief against the Minister's deportation order. Appeals had come in from Amnesty International about the risks to this man if he were to go back to Iran but these apparently had no effect on the Minister or his advisers. A large prison bill had to be run up even though Fardsavar did nothing untoward when he was out for two weeks on bail during this ordeal.

It seems, as a result of this court action, that future deportation arrangements will have to satisfy a reasonableness criterion. In this case Fardsavar has been accepted by the Spanish Government and is already in Spain. It seems to be a reflection on our compassion and humanity that the Minister resisted such a sensible compromise for so long and that well over $40,000 of public money has been spent on proposing and defending the really indefensible case of sending him back to Iran. I would very much like the Minister and the Department to give some indication of how typical or atypical is the Fardsavar case. Because of my involvement in this case I am now receiving a number of letters from people who seem to be in similar situations, such as Dr Hempel and Mr Etheredge who are in custody at the C. W. Campbell Remand Centre in Perth awaiting a decision of Mr Justice Burchett, a justice of the Federal Court of Australia, on whether they should be extradited. The major problem is that we are spending vast amounts of money on these cases. What is the justification for keeping these people in prison when apparently there is no evidence of bad character, previous criminal record or desire to escape? It seems to me a real problem. Perhaps some of these moneys could be better spent in other services, such as keeping open regional offices.

Lastly, on 24 September I asked a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs relating to the dismemberment of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs. In that capacity, Senator Button undertook to refer factual matters to the Minister for an answer. No such answer has been forthcoming. It is now three months since the announcement that the Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs was to be established within the Department. I would like to know from the Minister how many officers will be involved? What will be the annual running cost of this operation? Can we also get some indication of the extra funding to be devoted to independent research in an area in which the Jupp Review of Migrant Multicultural Programs and Services believed that the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs still had a very important role to play? Or is the Government hoping to lessen the scrutiny and continue its fierce attack on multiculturalism through this means? Within the Department and by the Government there has been an attack on multiculturalism. This is highly disturbing in a country in which 45 per cent of the community is of non-Anglo-Celtic background.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that we continually have to put up with attacks such as we have just heard from the honourable senator as we consider the Estimates in Committee. I happen to be proud of our multicultural society. If Senator Vigor really believes that changing the Institute of Multicultural Affairs in the way the Government has done will make any difference to that, he is having himself on, quite frankly. I was very pleased to hear tonight on PM the editor of the biggest Italian newspaper in this country point out that 96 per cent of Italians never watch the Special Broadcasting Service programs and could not care less about a merger. If the honourable senator talks to communities, as I have, on the weekend-the Lebanese community and the Greek community in Melbourne-he will find the same response. He can chase his populist issues up hill and down dale but he will not get any response from me during debate on the appropriations when we are supposed to be looking at matters of detail. If the honourable senator wants to use this debate for the sort of rhetoric populist nonsense that we hear from him all the time, he may do so but he should not expect a reply from me.

SPEECH.PARA: I make a similar response about regional offices. This Government faced a budgetary situation in which we were urged by people throughout the community, particularly those opposite, to cut government expenditure. We did so in some places. The honourable senator has distinguished himself by opposing every cut of that type. He has made no suggestions about what alternatives could be made. He has just picked up every populist issue and run with it. He may do that as long as he can. He can always do that because he is in the absolute position of never having the opportunity to be in government. He will never have to carry out anything that he proposes and therefore he can act in that irresponsible way. Some of his colleagues, if they live long enough, might get close to that but he certainly will not from number three on the ticket in South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —He might be number two in the Australian Capital Territory.

—He might. We will see how he goes then. Answers to the specific questions that the honourable senator asked the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs about staffing levels and the employment of people on temporary and contract arrangements were given to him. We work on a system of average staffing levels. At times during the year that level is penetrated and at other times it goes down to get the average level up. I am sure that at every Senate Estimates committee hearing at which Senator Vigor has asked questions someone has painstakingly sat down and explained the ASL system. If he had been on Estimates Committee B he would have heard Senator Sheil use a rather rude term for the ASL system.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose that I could attempt to explain it again in words of one syllable, but frankly I will instead arrange for officers of this Department, of the Treasury, of the Public Service Board or of anywhere else to explain carefully to Senator Vigor, who I know has a scientific background, just what averages mean and how at some times of the year if we go above the level and at other times of the year we go below it the average works out to be roughly between those figures. That is a very simple way of putting what happens.

TALK.START.PARA: —But there is an enormous dip in June.

—For heaven's sake, we have an annual budgetary situation. The honourable senator might like to change that, as I would. If he picks another time of the year he will get dips and ups and downs in different departments. I cannot remember what else the honourable senator asked.

SPEECH.PARA: He says that we must not close any regional offices. Senator Michael Baume does not like regional offices being closed in Wollongong. The only place where nobody has minded very much is in Launceston, from where I come. In Launceston, Senator Newman's office, Senator Watson's office and my office do the work we were doing before. We look after the immigration inquiries. We did not need that regional office and we will not have it there in the future. No one complains very much.

TALK.START.PARA: —But Wollongong has an enormous ethnic population.

—Of course, but Senator Vigor opposes the closure of them anywhere. Wherever offices are closed he says that we must not do it. TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking on the adjournment tonight I wish to take a few minutes to draw the attention of the Senate to a report which has been tabled in the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory. It is the report of the Northern Territory Railway Executive Group on the Alice Springs to Darwin railway project. The Railway Executive Group was set up to examine the specific details of the feasibility of the railway line-to give an honest assessment of its cost, its earning capacity and the services which it could provide. The group was chaired by its Director, Neil R. Conn. The table of contents of the report lists the freight task and revenue projections, the transport task in 1984-85, the base year transport task, the base year freight rates and rail share, the base year railway task and revenue, the railway task and revenue beyond 1990. Part II deals with the route, engineering and construction costs. It lists the route, survey, investigations and design, engineering and construction cost estimates. Part III deals with services, equipment and operating costs. It lists standards and services, equipment requirements and operating and maintenance costs. Part IV includes funding requirements and options. In this report are included tables and information which make a very complete report. I seek leave to table the report.
