THE ALICE SPRINGS TO DARWIN RAILWAY
Further Statement to the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly
13 November
BY THE HON. STEVE HATTON
Chief Minister
STATEMENT BY THE CHIEF MINISTER ON TABLING REPORT OF RAILWAY EXECUTIVE GROUP IN THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY
THE ALICE SPRINGS TO DARWIN RAILWAY
Mr Speaker, I table a report by the Railway Executive Group on the Alice Springs to Darwin Railway.
Mr Speaker, last June I foreshadowed to Honourable Members that I would provide during the present Sittings a further progress report on the Alice Springs to Darwin Railway project.

The Railway Executive Group has now presented its report to Cabinet. It is, as I anticipated back in June, a careful and sober assessment of what the line will cost to build and equip, and what it may be expected to earn after meeting operating costs.
The work of the group has been aimed, quite deliberately, at two distinct but related targets.

The first has been the projection of a base-year transport task and earning capacity for the Railway, devoid of `blue sky' future developments and fully aware of the Railway's need to be competitive with other modes of transport in the Territory.
The second has been the determination of a set of least-cost, but nonetheless safe and acceptable, construction and operating standards for the line.

The Railway Executive Group has done its job well-almost too well, in the sense that it has set itself deliberately to ignore the Territory's demonstrated capacity since self-government to grow faster and do a number of things, not only better than expected, but often better than it's been done elsewhere in Australia.

Honourable Members will probably share with me the belief, after they have read the report, that the Railway will be carrying bigger tonnages and earning more than projected soon after its completion.
It would take, for example, just one new, railway-using Territory project to come on stream in the 1990s from amongst the list of possibilities to radically transform the commercial results.
Development of the Port of Darwin as one end of a land-bridge across Australia would have a similar result.
Such possibilities have been put firmly to one side in preparing the report I will table today.
This report establishes a basic bottom line for the project.
It shows that the Territory has a basic railway task that can be done in a realistic and economical way.
It makes a useful start on how the project's funding might be structured.

For those who share our confidence in the future of the Territory, however, it will do no more than provide reassurance that the `downside' risks of participation in this great developmental project are low.
For them, the rewards of participation from the outset will be greater than the report allows itself to anticipate.
Against that background, I present now to Honourable Members in some detail the major findings and recommendations of the Railway Executive Group.
FREIGHT TASK AND REVENUE PROJECTIONS
The report starts from the following facts regarding freight already moving within the Northern Territory and open to capture by the completed railway:
the central corridor (between Alice Springs and Darwin) is the dominant land freight route;
the majority of freight moving in that corridor already makes use of the existing railway south of Alice Springs;
northbound freight exceeds southbound freight by a factor of almost two-to-one; and
over two-thirds of the freight concerned is non-bulk and directly related to the needs of the Northern Territory population (described in the report as `General Freight' requirements).
The report also notes, after surveying existing rates for carrying goods by road and/or rail, that rail freight rates are generally lower than competing road rates.
The report consequently assumes for its base-year projections that:
(1) rail will generally be preferred to road for carriage of bulk cargoes over long distances;
(2) tariffs on the Alice Springs to Darwin Railway will be 20-25 per cent lower than present road rates for comparable freight tasks;
(3) intense competition is to be expected from road operators for backhaul (mainly southbound) cargoes, requiring even lower rail rates in that direction;
(4) rate differentials will be much less in evidence where dedicated rolling stock is used (for example, in carrying petroleum products); and

(5) the base-year Railway share of freight carried north of Alice Springs will be no less than the proportion already carried by rail as far as Alice Springs. Not only would transhipment to road at that point make no commercial sense with the Railway link to Darwin completed, but experience with the Tarcoola to Alice Springs standard gauge link since its opening in 1980 suggests that the proportion will in fact increase.
The report goes on to assume, in making its projections for future growth in traffic on the Railway, that:

(6) there will be no increase in General Freight requirements per head of population (estimated to average, northbound, about 3.5 tonnes per year), so that the rate of growth in this major component of the transport task will be limited to the rate of population growth;

(7) only projects which are presently operational or virtually certain to proceed over the next few years will generate freight for the line, and the total tonnage carried will increase at only 3% per year from the base-year level:

(8) no additional traffic will be generated by the presence of a rail line where none existed before-that is to say, the developmental consequences of the line itself have been ignored in the rail traffic projections; and

(9) there will be no shift of traffic away from the eastern and western road corridors into the central corridor, despite the greater appeal the central corridor should have upon completion of the line.

Together these assumptions imply that the Railway will carry 70% of total freight tonnage an average distance of 1,000 kilometres and earn an average of a little under 4 cents per net tonne kilometre for doing so.
It follows that Railway gross revenue in 1991 will total $31.5 million, measured in today's dollars. Within that total:
two-thirds will be earned from freight moving the entire distance between Alice Springs and Darwin;
80% will come from northbound traffic; and
well over 80% will be earned from the carriage of general freight (mainly northbound) and petroleum (mainly southbound from Darwin).

As a final comment on the projected freight task, five locations will account for most of the operations of the line, namely Darwin, Mataranka (principally for its limestone deposits), Katherine (boosted by the Tindal Air Base development), Tennant Creek (particularly as a staging point for traffic from Queensland and, to a lesser extent, New South Wales), and Alice Springs. Other points requiring service, according to the report's projections, will be Batchelor, Adelaide River, Pine Creek, Daly Waters, Renner Springs and Ti-Tree.

I stress to Honourable Members again that the freight projections are based upon particularly cautious assumptions. We can be confident that, in the report's own words, they are at the lower bound of any reasonable range of expectations. The projections ignore the enormous developmental potential of the line, and the very real prospect of new developments and hence rail traffic appearing once the line is in place. It would be difficult to devise a more severe test, on the revenue side, for the project.
ROUTE, ENGINEERING AND CONSTRUCTION COSTS

I turn now to the second part of the Railway Executive Group's report, which assesses the alignment alternatives, a range of design standards and the approach to construction of the line, all against the over-riding objective of containing capital costs to the lowest level consistent with safe and acceptable standards of operation.

In my June statement I indicated that a number of cost-saving options were under careful review by the group and its consultants. Some of those options, such as the use of timber sleepers and the building of timber trestle bridges, have not survived the further tests applied to them, at some loss I would guess to the Territory's cartoonists.
Others, such as the re-use of part of the old North Australia Railway (NAR) route and bridges, have survived and remaining significant cost-saving features of the group's proposals.

It is estimated that $23 million (in today's dollars) can be saved by re-using the NAR route over the 200 kilometres between Katherine and Adelaide River, the larger part arising from net savings on bridge and culvert costs. Cameron McNamara and Partners, a major firm of consulting engineers, have confirmed that it is both possible and economical to re-use, after strengthening, the existing NAR bridges. The majority of the bridges to be strengthened comprise wrought-iron superstructure beams which will require the addition by welding of supplementary steel palting. Laboratory testing commissioned from the University of Queensland has confirmed the feasibility of welding the wrought-iron and that satisfactory fatigue resistance can be achieved.

Mr Speaker, I mention this incidental technical aspect of the report simply as an example of the care the Railway Executive Group has taken at each step to ensure that its findings are both financially sensible and technically feasible.

With the exceptions of the section between Katherine and Adelaide River and some tighter curves and inceased gradients over the next 65 kilometeres north to Noonamah, the remainder of the preferred route sticks closely to that contemplated by the Australian National before it was obliged to cease planning for the line.

Planning had proceeded to the point were some 70% of the alignment is already pegged with the remaining 30% located precisely on the map. The bulk of necessary survey work has been finished, including a relatively short but crucial section commissioned at our expense by the Railway Executive Group. So far as the old NAR alignment is concerned, no survey is available but the old design drawings are, so that only limited calibration surveys will be required to give indicative quantities.

Potential ballast and groundwater supplies for earthworks construction purposes have been assessed for the entire route. Certain gaps have been identified and provision has been made, in estimating construction costs, for filling them.

No right-of-way or environmental impact problems are anticipated over the preferred route. The Land Councils have confirmed their backing for the project and the Sacred Sites Authority has confirmed that there are no issues of significance that affect the proposed alignment.
Overall, then, the Railway route has been checked out thoroughly and passed every test the Railway Executive Group has applied to it.
Nor does it appear that there will be any significant engineering problems associated with the line's construction.

A track formation width of 6.7 metres has been assessed as being adequate for initial construction, with provision for widening (on an as-required basis) built into future maintenance cost estimates. The effect of this narrower formation width, suggested originally by Canadian Pacific, is to reduce the initial volume of bulk earthworks and selected fill requirements by some 15 to 20%. It has the further effect of reducing the typical culvert length and hence of reducing construction costs in this area as well.

A review by the Railway Executive Group of alternative ballast depths, subgrade strengths, sleeper spacing and sleeper types established a preferred track structure and that, on the basis of present ballast and tracklaying estimates and current supply prices, steel sleepers would be the most economical. Whilst competitive tendering could, in the event, result in the chosen course becoming concrete sleepers, the construction cost estimates are based on the steel sleeper alternative. As noted earlier, the review of timber sleepers revealed price, durability and handling problems sufficient to discount that option.

The estimated cost of rails is based upon a B.H.P. quotation for new 50 kilogram rail, expected to be used for all mainline track. B.H.P. has confirmed at the same time that it could supply rail at the rate required for the preferred construction program.

All sidings and loops have been assumed to utilise lighter rail acquired from Australian National after recovery from the former NAR line, The possible use of short second-hand rails from North America has also been investigated, but higher estimated tracklaying costs, the depreciation of the Australian dollar and a very competitive price indicated by B.H.P. have combined to remove the cost advantage perceived earlier. The option should, notwithstanding, be kept under review in case any or all of these more favourable conditions should change.

The preferred construction program envisages a 4-year design and construction period commencing in 1987, with tracklaying fronts starting at both Alice Springs and Darwin. A detailed review by the international tracklaying experts, Barclay Bros. Limited, has confirmed that a tracklaying rate of 8 kilometres per week on each of these fronts would be sustainable, implying a total tracklaying time of well under 30 months. The report has assumed, for conservative estimating purposes, that the full 30 months will be taken.

The Group and its consultants are confident that the project can be completed within four years providing it is undertaken on a project management basis which allows design, supply and construction to proceed simultaneously.

As I stated back in June, the work done by the Railway Executive Group and its expert consultants will allow a flying start to be made, since so much of the preparatory work has already been done. The results of this work will be available, of course, to all who would seriously contemplate participating in the project once I table the group's report today.

In all, it is estimated that the line will cost $610 million, measured in today's dollars. That sum contains over $30 million in contingency allowances provided to meet the unforeseen expenditures that will crop up in the course of design and construction. The estimate also includes an appropriate provision for the site allowances that will be an inescapable part of labour costs for a project of this nature in the regions it will traverse. A notable cost saving has been identified in the use of available second-hand locomotives and rollingstock for construction purposes.

To keep the total sum in perspective, Honourable Members will recall that Canadian Pacific in their September 1985 report to the Northern Territory Government spoke of a ``lowest initial cost'' Railway costing in the region of $500 million over 3 years and a ``base case'' of roundly $550 million spent over 4 years. The infamous Hill Inquiry used a figure closer to $600 million.

It is important to note that all these estimates were based upon wage rates and materials prices prevailing in 1983. After allowing for inflation over the intervening 3 years, it is apparent that the Railway Executive Group has defined a project which is at least as economical as the ``lowest initial cost'' version sketched by Canadian Pacific, without the vulnerability of that version's condensed construction program to unexpected supply and other problems, and well inside the Canadian Pacific ``base case'' which in today's dollars would be approaching $700 million. The Hill version would long since have passed that mark. I note, simply for further perspective on national projects, that the new Parliament House in Canberra is set to exceed $1000 million in total cost.
SERVICES, EQUIPMENT AND OPERATING COSTS
I turn briefly now to the report's findings on likely services, equipment requirements and what the Railway will cost to run when it goes into operation.
The operating plan assumed by the Railway Executive Group for projection purposes provides for:

(1) the Railway to handle wagon-load freight business to and from a small number of centres (anything less than wagon-load will first need to be consolidated by customers, including freight wholesalers);
(2) no scheduled passenger services;
(3) the Railway to connect and co-operate closely with the Australian National system at Alice Springs and, through AN, with the rest of the Australian standard gauge network;
(4) minimum manning practices, with two-man crews on the trains and Railway staff employed only at Alice Springs, Tennant Creek, Katherine and Darwin; and
(5) initial rollingstock requirements, except for locomotives, to be met mainly from equipment used during construction and from surplus equipment available elsewhere.

After taking account of the projected volume and composition of the Railway freight task described earlier, and making certain technical assumptions regarding train sizes and operating characteristics, the report derives an initial Railway service comprising 5 double-locomotive trains per week between Alice Springs and Darwin and a further 3 single-locomotive trains per week between Mataranka and Darwin. Future freight expansion is projected to be met by a combination of more frequent and bigger trains requiring up to three locomotives each.

Initial equipment purchases for the line, comprising new locomotives, rollingstock, freight handling, track maintenance and other equipment are projected to cost $24 million (in 1986 dollars), after allowing for a substantial amount of rollingstock and track maintenance equipment transferred from construction at no additional cost to the project.
Total operating and maintenance costs for the line have been estimated at $23.6 million (in 1986 dollars) in the first year of operation.

Allowance is made within that figure for the marginally higher operating costs arising from the adoption of the NAR alignment north of Katherine, as well as provision for the cost of widening the track formation where operational experience shows this to be required.
The estimates have been checked with AN, particularly against their experience with the Tarcoola to Alice Springs line.
NET OPERATING SURPLUS
Honourable Members will have noted that projected operating and maintenance costs at $23.6 million fall well inside the projected revenue of $31.5 million in the first year of operation.

I have anticipated publicly that the Railway would generate an operating surplus from the outset-we now have an estimate of the size of that initial operating surplus, namely $8 million in today's dollars.

That is an encouraging start. I believe there is no real rail system in Australia, with the exception of the dedicated iron ore lines in Western Australia and the coal lines in Queensland, which can claim to make an operating surplus. It certainly cannot be claimed by the author of the Hill Report who, during his term as Chief Executive of the NSW Rail Authority, was widely applauded for containing his system's operating Loss to only one million dollars per day.

Another encouraging result is that the operating surplus on the Alice Springs to Darwin line is projected to grow in real terms at over 6% per year, or more than double the assumed rate of growth in tonnage carried, as overhead expenses are spread more widely and economies of scale in operations come into effect. At that rate of increase, the operating surplus (in 1986 dollars) doubles within the first twelve years of operation and reached almost $25 million (in 1986 dollars) after twenty years of operation.

The discouraging result, at first sight, is the finding that these accumulating operating surpluses do not appear to pay, within that 20 year period, for the cost of building and equipping the line. Measured in constant 1986-dollar terms there is no doubt about it-during the first 20 years of operation, accumulated operating surpluses are projected to contribute only $303 million towards the $610 million construction costs, the $24 million spent initially to equip the line and the further $55 million required in subsequent years to expand and replace equipment as use of the line grows.

I say do not appear to pay since, when allowance is made for the inflation that inevitably will occur and costs and outlays are inflated to future dollars rather than 1986 dollars, the project becomes substantially cash-positive. That is to say, over 20 years it generates more than enough cash after operating expenses have been met to recoup all construction and equipment costs and still have something left over. This happens essentially because future revenues are boosted by inflation but construction costs are not having been sunk into the project at the outset.

Mr Speaker, this is not done with mirrors or require any great financial sophistication to appreciate. It simply reflects what home buyers and project sponsors have always known in times of inflation-that building something with today's dollars and paying for it with tomorrow's dollars has generally been a good deal providing the cost of financing is kept to reasonable levels.

That final proviso is, of course, the key to the whole matter. If the ``something left over'' after meeting operating costs is not enough to service the debt and equity funds raised to finance the capital cost of the project, then the project will not proceed.
PROJECT FUNDING REQUIREMENTS

In the case of our project, the Railway Executive Group puts it quite brutally: The Railway will be totally unattractive as a strictly commercial venture over the period covering construction and the first twelve years of operation, since the net cashflow over that time will be negative.

This should come as no surprise to anyone. This is a long-term, infrastructure development project and it would be quite unreasonable to expect it to pay for itself within only twelve years (a limited time horizon set more by banks than by the project).
The real surprise should be that it takes only another 6 years to reach that position, on the generally cautious projections made in the report.

That is not, in itself enough. The Project must also have the capacity to service, at acceptable rates of interest or dividend payment, the funds raised to meet the projected cashflow deficiency over the early years. The Railway Executive Group is, again, quite blunt about what its cashflow projections indicate: The Railway will turn substantially cash-positive, but the internal rate of return (a nominal 2% per annum over 24 years) will be unattractive to potential equity investors.

Mr Speaker, it is important to note the phrase ``potential equity investors'' in that statement. What the report is saying is that we cannot reasonably expect a profit-seeking entrepreneur, faced with prospective earnings limited to the revenue projections of this report, to invest enough to satisfy the project's cash needs from the commencement of construction, since the return on his investment over a quite long period of years would be inadequate.
PROJECT FUNDING STRUCTURES

But it is also important not to lose sight of the fact that there is a servicing capacity there, and the test for the project's sponsors and financiers will be to stretch the use of that available cash to its limit.

One way to do that is to rearrange the after-tax cash flows of the project in a way which sharply lowers the effective cost of funds, as is done for example in a leveraged lease. Another is to attract into the project equity investors prepared to accept very low or very late dividends, as could happen if such investors were to perceive substantial indirect advantages or returns from equity participation.

It is of course possible that, even fully-stretched in such ways, the project's net cash flow will prove inadequate for a time and will need supplementing. This is the approach taken by the Railway Executive Group's financial consultant, Wardley Australian Limited, in its assessment of alternative funding structures, when it assumes that the Government will contribute a substantial amount up-front, make annual ``top-up'' contributions and guarantee that lenders will be taken out of the transaction at the scheduled time. A deal of testing of the alternatives remains to be done before my Government will consider entering into commitments of the magnitude suggested by that analysis.

Honourable Members will note, however, the concluding remark in the report of the Railway Executive Group that the equity partnership funding structure can be refined to further reduce the assumed Government contributions. That is a promising start on the financial engineering but much more needs to be recognised about this project before that task goes too much further.
PUBLIC AND PRIVATE BENEFITS
First, this is a project which will generate great national and public benefits.
As I and my predecessors have pointed out many times before, that was recognised in the Federal Government's legislated responsibility to build the line which dates back to 1911.
Legal obligations aside, Canadian Pacific has established a convincing economic case for the line being built as a national project.

Substantial resource savings and Railway earnings will accrue outside the Northern Territory once goods can be put directly onto trains at their point of origin in Adelaide, Sydney or Melbourne for the through trip to Darwin (or even, perhaps, to ports beyond).
Substantial savings will occur also as less resources are used in road maintenance, not only in the Northern Territory but also in the States through which trucks pass on their way.

I remind Honourable Members again of the calculation, made by Canadian Pacific, that the Railway would save the nation more than 2,000 million litres of fuel over 50 years. At today's prices that would even pay for the Parliament House in Canberra, much less our Railway!

It follows that there is sound justification, on both economic and equity grounds, for the long-term investment of public funds in the line, not just by the Territory but by the Federal Government and by those States which stand to benefit in a very real way.

Before leaving the point, Mr Speaker, I wish to deplore the style of response (last seen expressed in the Dibb Report on Australia's defence) which accepts the sort of advantages I have described but takes the stand that no contribution need be made towards the costs of achieving them because someone else will pay for the Railway anyway.

Are we supposed to blindly accept that every dollar in the present defence budget achieves a better return, in terms of defence preparedness, than a dollar spent on completing Australia's standard gauge rail network, particularly when so much of our defence orientation is northwards?
I think not, and have not the slightest doubt that the services of the Railway would be requisitioned the moment our defenders thought they were needed.
While I am sure Territorians are prepared to play their part in enabling that to happen, it would be grossly inequitable if we were to shoulder the entire cost.
The second concluding point that I wish to make is that the Railway will generate substantial benefits to the private sector, over and above the public and external benefits I have described.

These will accrue to the builders who make profits from the construction of the line, to the steelmakers who supply the rail and probably the sleepers as well, to the equipment suppliers who supply the locomotives and rollingstock and to the financiers who put the funding package together.
They will accrue to the transport operators who will have at their disposal, at long last, a truly national standard gauge network.

The list of private beneficiaries does not stop there. The report indicates a number of areas where private sector involvement could be both efficient and profitable-in, for example, the overhaul of locomotives and rollingstock by private contractors, even the contracting-out of labour and management needs at the majority of stations that do not require full-time staffing.

The possible role for private enterprise in this Railway is limited only by the imagination and entrepreneurial spirit of the potential participants. My Government will put no barriers in their way if they have the substance and staying-power required-indeed, we will give them every assistance within our power. As I have indicated before, that could extend if required to a shareholding by the Northern Territory Government in the private company or companies set up to own and operate the Railway. I would hope, following discussions that I have recently reopened, that in due course we will see equally helpful commitments on the part of the Federal and South Australian Governments.

Let me state my Government's position quite clearly. Whilst not excluding the possibility of Northern Territory Government participation, our first and principal objective is to have the line built, owned and operated wholly by private enterprise.

Mr Speaker, my third and final point in conclusion is this. While my Government has accepted the report of the Railway Executive Group in its entirety, and has no qualms whatsoever about the degree of professionalism and amount of commonsense that have been put into preparing it, it should not be assumed that we (or the Group) consider any technical or financial options to be closed off at this stage.

If someone wants to put to us that the better solution is a gas-fired train, or an electrified system, or a different route, or indeed any other variation which can be shown to make sense and to be financially sound, then we are perfectly prepared to sponsor that better solution.
Discussions with potential participants, and the testing of alternatives, has never ceased, and will now accelerate.

About the only option that we close off is that of not having the Alice Springs to Darwin Railway at all, since the report I now table has confirmed to my Government that there is, as I stated at the outset today, a basic Railway task that can be done in a realistic and economical way.

It is now in a very real sense up to the private sector, and particularly those who know more than we do about transportation, construction, finance and the running of Railways, to set about building on the foundation we have established and to join us in taking the next step towards finishing the job.
I commend the report to Honourable Members.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. As can be seen from the statement of the Northern Territory Chief Minister on the tabling of the report, the Executive Group has done its job very well. Time does not permit me to go through all aspects of the report in detail but I would like to make a few points which I think are important for all of us to note. This is a project of national significance which is being proposed, not just something for Territorians. It has a tremendous history. I shall not go over that because it has been brought up in the Senate many times, particularly in the last two years.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I should endorse the comments of the Chief Minister. This is a sober and careful assessment of what the line will cost to build and equip and what it may be expected to earn after meeting operating costs. The report deliberately ignores the Territory's demonstrated capacity since self-government to grow faster and to do many things better than they can be done in other parts of Australia. As a bottom line, the report establishes that the Territory has a basic railway task that can be done in a realistic and economic way. It suggests how the funding of the project might be constructed. The report is based on present road and rail freight movements and assumes a rate of growth in freight requirements commensurate only with population growth. It takes into account only projects which are presently operational and certain to proceed and it assumes no additional traffic will be generated by the presence of a rail line where none has existed before. Even on the basis of these very conservative assumptions, the railway is estimated to gross revenue in its first year of operation of $31.5m measured in today's dollars. The operating costs for the same period are assessed at $23.6m. So the operating surplus would be $8m in today's values.

The line contemplated by the Northern Territory Government will operate at a profit. In that respect it will be unique in Australia. The Northern Territory Government is committed to seeing the line built but on condition that it is a profit making enterprise and not a burden on the resources of the Northern Territory and its people-and Australia for that matter. I stress that unless the line is a profit making enterprise it will not be constructed. The Northern Territory Government wants it to be a benefit to the Northern Territory and no one can doubt that it will be. Not only will it be a benefit to the Northern Territory; it will be a magnificent asset for Australia. Benefits will accrue to builders involved in construction, steel makers supplying the rail and sleepers, equipment suppliers who supply engines and rolling stock, and the financiers who put the funding package together. Transport operators will also benefit, along with many others.

Indeed, as I have said, the project will be of national benefit. While the Northern Territory is proceeding to approach private investors as the next step in seeing the project come to fruition, it is quite justified in hoping for support and commitments on the part of the Federal and South Australian governments in particular. The Chief Minister has not excluded the possibility of Northern Territory Government participation in the scheme but has reiterated that the Northern Territory Government's principal objective is to see the line built, owned and operated wholly by private enterprise. As I said, there is much more information in the report and the statement of the Chief Minister. I have tabled the report and incorporated the statement of the Chief Minister in order that the information might be more readily and widely available, to members of the Federal Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall detain the Senate for only a few moments this evening. I want to make some remarks on a report which was presented to the Parliament today but on which no formal motion that the Senate take note of the paper was moved. I refer to the report of the Commonwealth Department of Health entitled `Australia's response to AIDS'. It is not often that I get the opportunity in what I hope is an entirely non-partisan sense to say in this chamber that there are certain activities which have been undertaken by the Commonwealth Government, and by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) in particular, which I believe are worthy of being noted throughout the Parliament as outstanding examples of the correct way in which a government ought to respond to a major problem developing in the Australian community and a major public health problem which is currently confronting not only Australia but to all intents and purposes also all like countries throughout the Western world and Africa and a number of underdeveloped countries.

SPEECH.PARA: The response of the Australian Government to the acquired immune deficiency syndrome crisis in which Dr Blewett and the Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes, and a number of others have been involved is I think an example of outstanding success by an Australian administration and one which on behalf of a large number of members, if not all members, of the Opposition I wish to be associated with.

The decision of the Minister for Health, on the initiative originally proposed by Mr Peacock when he was the Leader of the Opposition, to establish the parliamentary liaison committee on AIDS I think has indicated the correct way in which a parliament ought to respond to problems of this nature. That committee has been meeting under the chairmanship of the Minister for Health for a number of months. Reports have been presented to it about what the Government is doing on the AIDS situation and the programs which the Government is developing to combat the AIDS crisis. It has had the opportunity to hear from distinguished members of the medical profession-both Australians and overseas visitors. It has had the opportunity to discuss the personal problems involved in the AIDS crisis with a number of people who are actually AIDS sufferers and people who have been involved in the more political side of dealing with the AIDS crisis.

We now have before us a report called `Australia's response to AIDS' prepared by Margaret Duckett-I certainly indicate my congratulations to her on the preparation of this report-which deals with the steps that have been undertaken by the Commonwealth Government and by each of the State and Territory governments in responding to the AIDS crisis. As I say, I do not wish to detain the Senate at any length this evening, but it is important to indicate that the report reveals that the first case in Australia of category A AIDS was diagnosed in November 1982. By 17 September 1986 a total of 296 cases had occurred, of whom 140 had died.

Senator Grimes said in answer to a question today that, on the best of all evidence available, there is no reason to be particularly optimistic about the short term likelihood of a cure being found for this disease. Whether experiments with the new drug AZT, isotrinosine or any of the other drugs which are currently in vogue will turn out to be beneficial in the long run remains to be seen. One can only hope, but at this stage it is a matter of hope.

Australia currently has an incidence of infection of 17 per million, which approximately parallels the situation in the United States of America where the epidemic commenced approximately two years earlier. By 1991 it is likely that in Australia we will have more than 5,000 persons suffering from AIDS. I think the response of the Government has been intelligent and sympathetic. The establishment of the National AIDS Task Force under David Penington and the National Advisory Committee on AIDS under Ita Buttrose I think has contributed substantially not only to public information, which is very important, but also to the capacity of the community to respond because it has the information before it-information which comes to the community from what it perceives to be reliable sources.

I think it is very interesting to note the differing responses in each of the States. This report has indicated, for instance, that in New South Wales there was a considerable problem with the attempt to amend the Public Health Act to require doctors to report cases in a particular fashion. All that happened as a result of that overreaction by the New South Wales Government was that the number of people presenting for testing for AIDS antibody positive status declined dramatically. That was a tragedy. It is only now that in New South Wales there is some attempt to overcome and rectify that problem. It is disappointing to see in the report that in Victoria the Minister responsible for the Office of Corrections has decided against making condoms available to prisoners and that he has not indicated a willingness to deal with the question of the supply of sterile needles or syringes to prisoners. Here is a situation in which within the prison population we have unique and particular problems which ought to be addressed in a far more sympathetic and intelligent fashion than appears to be the case. We have situations in States such as Western Australia and Tasmania where there is still a problem arising as far as AIDS victims are concerned that homosexual acts continue to remain criminal offences. It is almost unbelievable that in 1986 that should continue to be the situation.

It is perhaps most unfortunate to look at the situation in Queensland. I am not one who in the past has been prepared to indulge in any degree of particular bashing of State governments but I think the situation in Queensland is one where the lack of an intelligent response on the part of the Queensland Government has been a national disgrace. It is quite clear that the lack of sympathetic attention to this matter in Queensland and the failure of the Queensland Government to deal with this matter in the same intelligent and sympathetic way as the other State governments, regardless of their views about homosexual behaviour or the criminal status of homosexuality, is something that Australia as a nation must regard as one of the few clear failures of the way in which the AIDS crisis has been responded to.

Senator Grimes today, in answering a question about the supply of clean syringes, made the point that overseas evidence is quite overwhelming that one of the important responses to the AIDS crisis, particularly as it is now more and more likely that AIDS will be passed on by the use of dirty needles by intravenous drug users, should be to look sympathetically at the supply of clean needles in appropriate situations. Professor David Penington, perhaps one of the most distinguished medical practitioners in this country, has urged that course of action. In a letter to the Sydney Morning Herald on 15 November Dr Wodak of the Alcohol and Drug Service, Dr Julian Gold of the Albion Street AIDS Clinic and Dr David Cooper, a staff specialist in immunology at St Vincents Hospital in Sydney, all put their names to a letter advocating that we look at that and that we consider intelligently the clear evidence gained from the Netherlands, where such a system has been in place for a number of years.

As I said, I do not want to delay the Senate at the end of a very long day of significant debate, but when the Department of Health puts down an informative and useful report which deals with an issue which affects the life and death of a large number of our fellow citizens, I believe it is to be congratulated. The presentation of this report gives us an opportunity to say that Australia has responded in an intelligent and positive fashion to this problem. To the best of my knowledge there has been no partisan politics of any description involved and both sides of the chamber and both sides of the political debate have recognised that this is a public health problem, that it is not a moral issue, a dilemma about punishment or anything like that, but a question of how we are prepared in a civilised society to respond to a public health issue. I believe that the Minister is to be congratulated for the role he has played in the preparation of this report.

I know there is one outstanding question of the long term issue of the provision of hospice and other care. I was recently in the United Kingdom and the British Government has just established a committee under the chairmanship of the Deputy Prime Minister, Lord Whitelaw, to try to co-ordinate the Government's response to the AIDS crisis in that country. While I was there his Grace the Archbishop of Canterbury gave an address to a meeting of health and hospital workers in which he made it quite clear that the provision of adequate hospice care was going to be the long term great issue for the public health system in the United Kingdom to cope with. I believe that is going to be the case in Australia. I believe that the medical research is being handled as best it can. The drug research and trials are being handled as best they can.

The actual management in a hospital situation of patients, I think is equal to any in the world, but there is clearly going to be a real problem about the provision of adequate hospice care for those people who are going to be dying of AIDS. At this stage the majority of category A AIDS sufferers are condemned to that fate. The way in which we provide the resources and funds, and the co-ordination of Federal, State and local health authority activities to provide hospice care and to provide a situation in which, in the final stages of this very terrible disease, people can be dealt with in dignified circumstances with a maximum degree of humanity, will be a trial of both the Government's financial resolve and its political resolve. In terms of its political resolve I hope we can ensure that the co-operation which has occurred across the chamber in the way in which this matter has been dealt with as a public health issue can be maintained and advanced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I add my voice to the issues raised by Senator Puplick and congratulate the Government on this report on one of the major health issues facing this country at this stage. It is obvious that a great deal of time, effort and money has gone into the campaign and, from the figures presented here, I confirm that about $24m has been spent by the Federal Government to fight the acquired immune deficiency syndrome since 1984. But there is one particular area that concerns me in terms of the ultimate effectiveness of this campaign. I guess it relates as much as anything else to the type of co-operation that has been gained from the State governments and the coyness which has been shown by a number of authorities, particularly at a State level, about this issue. I refer in particular to the corrective services divisions, whatever they are called in the various States-the departments of corrective services, penal institutions and all of those areas that relate to prisons. We know that prisons generally hold a higher percentage than the general population of people who are in the high risk area as far as AIDS is concerned. I refer to practising homosexuals and those people who are intravenous drug users. In fighting these two problems, the State governments have shown a remarkable coyness through their appropriate institutions in coming to grips with what practically can be done.

SPEECH.PARA: If one surveys this report entitled `Australia's Response to AIDS', one finds that only three States have at this stage even contemplated providing condoms to prisoners through their respective corrective services divisions or departments. In fact, if one looks at the Northern Territory, New South Wales and South Australian surveys, one will find, for example, that ultimately the condoms have not been delivered in the most appropriate way, or have not been delivered at all despite good intentions. I think that the Northern Territory describes distribution problems as being the main reason why condoms have not been issued. New South Wales has brought 20,000. One is not quite sure whether they have actually gone into the prison system. Again, there has just been a statement of intent on the part of the South Australian Government.

The coyness is not restricted to the way in which we treat penal institutions. It also appears in some of the respective legislation in the various States regarding the ease with which young people, in particular, can gain access to condoms. It is certainly made much more difficult by restrictive legislation on licensing and sales through vending machines. It seems to me if the Federal Government is to spend about $24m on this campaign, it ought not stop short of one of the very practical ways of at least preventing the spread of AIDS in the community, particularly through the heterosexual community, but also within the homosexual community. It is about time that we faced that issue, not just as a federal parliament but at the State government level, and made it possible for young people to respond to the sorts of public campaigns that governments are now running about so-called safe sex. It is about time that the coyness that this community has had, not only in regard to contraception but also in regard to the use of condoms and the protection of people against the spread of venereal disease, was ended. The only way it can be ended is by the politicians in various State parliaments and in the Federal Parliament being prepared to stand up and be counted on this issue. If we are talking about the protection, particularly of young people, in the future it is encumbent on us at least to lead that debate. It is one example of where parliaments must lead rather than reflect the lowest common denominator of social prejudice in the community.

I state on the record tonight that we have a long way to go in changing some of the attitudes in a practical direction which may be of assistance in combatting this dreadful scourge which will have very significant effects on community health in Australia. I think that the reason why we have not moved quickly enough has been partly that many people in the community were quite happy, in one sense, to breathe a sigh of relief that their group, their particular area of sexual preference, precluded them from getting into the sorts of difficulties that homosexuals were getting themselves into. For a long time we tended to stand back as a community at large and simply say: `It is not a matter for heterosexuals in the community; it is not a matter for general community health'. Somehow or other there was a view that punishment was being meted out in some biblical sense to homosexuals. It was a sad and tragic attitude on the part of many State governments which were very quick to jump on the bandwagon and talk about the wrath of God. I recall one State Premier who, with a certain degree of glee, mentioned that AIDS was some form of pay-back from a divine entity for sexual practices which were not acceptable to the community at large.

I, like other politicians, wish to be on record at this stage as pushing the viewpoint loudly and clearly throughout this nation that where practical things need to be done, for example in prisons, we ought to stand up and be counted on those issues, regardless of whether the rest of the community is at this stage prepared to follow. We ought to be leading on this issue, not staying 10 years behind, because as far as the AIDS epidemic is concerned, we do not have that much time in hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the matter of the acquired immune deficiency syndrome, which was raised by Senator Puplick and Senator Aulich, I share all the views expressed by both honourable senators. The reason that we have managed to cope in this country, in the way that we have until now has been, I believe, the very sensible approach of parliamentarians in general-not just governments, but parliamentarians as a whole. The Parliamentary Liaison Group in this place is a very good example of what can happen. The very sane and sensible contributions to the debate that we have had in this place can only help. We have also been assisted by the fact that until now the capacity of the very good support groups for people with AIDS, particularly those in the gay community, has been such that the two committees and the health authorities have been able to cope in a fairly adequate way. But that situation will not continue, if one anticipates the difficulty of treatment that will continue, and that initially, for some years, treatment may only prolong life, rather than prevent death. Those support groups will not be able to cope, and it will be up to the parliamentarians of this country and the public health authorities to help cope with the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: That being so, if I can make a personal comment, I firmly believe, for all sorts of reasons-reasons that have been demonstrated in the silly reaction of the New South Wales Government to the reporting of AIDS and the reluctance of other governments, in Western Australia, Tasmania and Queensland, to take adequate steps-that in future as this epidemic gets worse, Federal governments of whatever political persuasion will be in a better position to cope with the situation than any State government of any political persuasion. It will be a national problem. It will need national funding. I think it will need national initiatives to cope with it. I think we will have to face that. I certainly will be putting that, and have put that, to my colleagues in this place.

Senator Puplick and Senator Aulich have pointed out that it is a national problem. The virus knows no State boundaries. We will not get over the problem by ignoring it. It certainly will not go away. If we do not take some of the most sensible actions that have been suggested by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), Senator Puplick and others, if we take the wrong actions, as happened in New South Wales, as Senator Puplick pointed out, the results can be potentially disastrous, although I hope that that situation has been overcome. I commend Senator Puplick and Senator Aulich for the remarks. I hope that in future the debate in this place on this matter will continue in the same way.

In regard to Senator Kilgariff's contribution on the Alice Springs to Darwin railway, I am pleased to hear that he is confident, Mr Hatton in the Northern Territory is confident, that it is a financial proposition, and that it will be profitable. Therefore, there is no need for any Commonwealth government contribution, because I can assure him that he will not get it while this Government is in power. I hope that all of those private financial institutions which will rush in and contribute money to that railway and make big profits out of it, do succeed, and succeed very well. I got a bit concerned towards the end of Senator Kilgariff's speech when he said that it may be necessary for the Northern Territory Government to contribute funds and that it would welcome some contribution in funds from the Federal Government. I hope any contribution that the Northern Territory Government makes to this project will have considerably more success than have its contributions in recent times to the hotel enterprises in Alice Springs and Darwin, which look like being a disaster for the taxpayers of the Northern Territory and therefore, I suppose, indirectly for the taxpayers of Australia. I hope that in future any entrepreneurial efforts of the Northern Territorial Government into railways or hotels will be successfully quarantined there and will not inflict penalties on the taxpayers of the rest of the country. I can assure Senator Kilgariff that my colleague Senator Walsh will be endeavouring to make sure that that happens. I think it is time that we all went home.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.01 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 19 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (i) Did the Special Minister of State, in his instructions of 18 July 1985, request Commissioner Grey to produce a draft Cabinet submission which was due to be completed early in 1986.
(ii) Was such a submission prepared, and has it been received by the Minister.
(iii) Has the Minister given consideration to this submission and has it been put before Cabinet.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (i) Yes.

(ii) and (iii) It has not been the practise of successive Governments, nor is it of this Government, to release details of Cabinet business. AFP staffing resources were, of course, considered by the Government in the context of the 1986/87 Budget with the result that they will be increased by 100 in 1986/87, which will bring the total increase in AFP staffing since the Government came to office to 535, an increase of just under 21%.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many of the nuclear accidents that have occurred since 1965 have occurred in Australian ports or waters.
(2) What warning system is to be employed in the event of a serious nuclear accident occurring and how are people in danger zones to be evacuated.
(3) Have safety plans been initiated to protect the people of Brisbane and other ports.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) None.

(2) Safety procedures, including warning and evacuation arrangements, for visits by nuclear powered warships (NPWs) are developed by State or Territory NPW Visits Committees. The Committees include representatives from police, emergency services, port authority, and health environmental bodies.

Australian NPW radiation monitoring procedures, combined with the US's agreement to notify Australian authorities immediately of any reactor accident would provide adequate warning in the unlikely event of a release of radioactive material. The Commonwealth radiation monitoring team which supervises the program would then provide guidance to State or Territory authorities on the need or otherwise for evacuation of areas in the path of that material. The actual procedures for warning and evacuation would vary in accordance with local conditions.

All nuclear weapons accidents are covered in the general emergency arrangements which include warning and evacuation procedures where necessary, and which apply for all visits by foreign warships. Responsibility for these plans rests with port authorities, naval or civil. The Commanding Officer of a visiting warship would inform these authorities immediately of any weapons accident.
(3) Yes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the P-80-1 spacecraft scheduled for launch from the United States (US) Vandenberg Air Force Base in May 1988 intended to carry the first TEAL RUBY sensor.

(2) Will TEAL RUBY tests conducted with this spacecraft include-(a) target missions demonstrating on-board detection of co-operative airborne targets; or (b) background missions where multispectral radiometric emissions will be recorded.
(3) Has there been any approach, formal or otherwise, to the Government from the United States for Australian co-operation in these tests; if so, what are the details.

(4) Would-(a) RAN vessels; or (b) RAAF aircraft be used for scheduled TEAL RUBY tests; if so (i) what ship or ships, (ii) how many aircraft and what types, and (iii) in each case, for what particular purpose.

(5) Can the Minister for Defence distinguish between those functions of TEAL RUBY applicable-(a) to conventional warfare; (b) to the US SDI, BMD or ABM programmes; and (c) to both conventional and SDI-type programmes; if so, what are-(i) the functions, and (ii) the applications in each case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The launch of the TEAL RUBY experimental satellite has been delayed indefinitely following the Challenger Shuttle disaster. It is unlikely to be launched before 1990, and the launch vehicle and launch site are not firm.
(2) The intent was to conduct both types of tests stated as indicated in The National Times of 10-16 May 1985.
(3) Australian co-operation in the TEAL RUBY experiment was to have taken place under the auspices of The Technical Co-operation Program (TTCP).

(4) The experiment would have provided Australia with infra red data on land and ocean backgrounds, and on the infra red emission of various aircraft and ships. Since the date of the experiment is now uncertain it is impossible to say what platforms might be used at that time.

(5) Australia is interested in TEAL RUBY because it offers a convenient and comprehensive means of measuring infra red background and emissions from ships and aircraft in the Australian region. Had the satellite flown as intended, the data derived from this experiment would have contributed to the total data base on this subject. It was unlikely to aid SDI-type programmes significantly because the systems requirements for the latter are quite different from those of the TEAL RUBY experiment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 16 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister for Education advise, in July 1986 that every effort would be made to review the funding and operation of the Education Centres in a manner that would not lead to the closure of any centre.
(2) Had an assurance previously been given to the Education Centres that funding would remain at the same level throughout the triennium.
(3) What criteria were used to determine whether funding should be withdrawn or reduced.

(4) Would it not have been fairer to have reduced funding to all Education Centres, rather than withdrawing it from some, given that in the present economic climate, certain areas of funding had to be cut.
(5) Will the withdrawal of funding from 9 Centres, 4 of which are in Queensland, result in loss of employment and assets.

(6) Did the Minister announce that services supplied by Education Centres across rural areas would continue to the greatest possible extent; if so, why was funding withdrawn from the Tableland Education Centre which serves 30 rural schools, many of which are in remote areas and cannot be served by an alternative Centre.
(7) Will the Minister supply the answer to this question before the debate on the Education Budget comes into the Senate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. However, the advice provided at the time, which I might remind the honourable senator was given in advance of the Budget decision, was based on advice from the Commonwealth Schools Commission as to how that body would respond should the Government not be able to increase the overall Education Centre budget as recommended in the Commission's report, `Quality and Equality'.

(3) The Government's decision to reduce the level of funding in the Education Centres Program was made in response to the need to reduce overall expenditure within the public sector. Major reductions have occurred in a number of programs within my portfolio.

In applying the reduction to the Education Centres program, the Government sought to maintain the maximum number of centres in a way that would continue services across rural areas and disadvantaged urban areas to the greatest extent possible.

(4) The option of reducing funding to all Education Centres was considered. However, it was the Government's view that any attempt to maintain all thirty-two Centres at this reduced level would threaten the viability of many.

(5) In those Centres where Commonwealth funding will cease in 1987 the Government believes that the lead time given will minimise job loss, especially in Queensland where many centre staff are seconded from the State education system. Should a Centre cease operating, the assets will not be lost as agreements require these to be transferred to agencies providing similar services.

However, it does not follow that those centres no longer funded under the Education Centres Program will necessarily close. Some centres conduct a range of entrepreneurial activities which generate income. These can continue. Some centres may also be able to secure funding under appropriate national elements of other Commonwealth Programs in order to contribute to Commonwealth policy development work in areas like rural education or in-service training for teachers. I have already announced grants for 1987 to enable four centres, which otherwise would have received no Commonwealth funding to build upon their particular areas of expertise.

(6) Yes. The Commonwealth will continue its support for the Tablelands Education Centre through a grant of $35,000 under the Projects of National Significance Program. The grant will assist the Centre in providing important information to the Government on how education works in rural areas. The project will build on a range of activities already carried out by the Centre and will investigate the needs of schools and students in rural areas.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister for Defence explain why it has taken the Department of Defence nearly 12 months to finalise land acquisition for a community child care centre initiated by Army wives in Townsville.

(2) Is the Minister satisfied that this unnecessary delay will be resolved immediately so that the Committee is eligible for funding under the children's services programme in the 1986-87 financial year.

(3) When will the Department of Defence administrators start responding to the Hamilton Report on the needs of Service wives, so that the bureaucratic paper shuffling is eliminated and much needed facilities and programs developed for Service families.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government is in the process of establishing a Defence Housing Authority which will seek to negotiate ownership of the 14,000 houses owned by the states and leased by the Commonwealth for Defence personnel. The houses currently occupied by the Kutunga Community Child Care Centre in Townsville fall into this category.

(2) Because of the time involved in negotiating ownership of these houses, the Minister for Defence has guaranteed the Centre, use of the houses it presently occupies for a further two year period. In the meantime moves to secure permanent facilities and Office of Child Care funding will continue.

(3) A team has been set up to implement the recommendations of the Hamilton Report and the Family Information Liaison Service teams. Steps are being taken to permit the conduct of child care facilities in Commonwealth State Housing Agreement houses being occupied by Service families. The first meeting of the National Consultative Group of Service Spouses occurred recently and valuable exchanges of information took place.
